As a traveller I am constantly running into Ruth's Chris.  Yet even though I am free to eat there on the company dime I had never actually set foot in one until last night.  The occasion was a friend's desire for a whole lot of meat in her mouth.  I couldn't pass that up, could I?

This place is pretty simple.  They got lots of pricey food here, mostly of the broiled meat variety.  They do have a very decent selection of appetizers to choose from.  My choice from the night was the mushrooms stuffed with crab.  They also have all the essential cuts of meat that they broil to your request (why anyone in their right mind would want a good steak more than medium rare I don't know).  I opted for the Cowboy Cut Ribeye, which is just a ribeye with a bone in it.  And then there are the sides, so many tasty sides to chooose from!  The potatoes au gratin are cheesey perfection!

All of this wonderful food is only that much better when there is an old Asian Oracle employee sitting at the table next to you with a gorgeous *escort*.  Especially when she looks like a more ethnic *read HOTTER* darker *read OH SO MUCH MORE HOTTER* Shakira.  Super duper especially if said escort is not wearing a bra and has wonderfully perky B cups perfectly in view while you stuff butter slathered steak and cheesy weezy potatoes au gratin in your mouth.

I should have gotten that girls business card just so I could pay her to eat at the table next to me at every restaurant I dine at.
author: Luis M.

description:
It could just be that there is something about this upscale chain restaurant that doesn't DO anything for me. Crazy since I'm a steak connosseiur? I think not.

My first experience with Ruth Chris was in San Diego, where my ex took me for our prom night. The service was lacking then, which I attribute to our young age and the fact that my ex had dared to ask for A1 Sauce. *gasp* Yes, totally humiliating for both me and the restaurant staff.

But hard feelings aside for the San Diego location, Ruth Chris of SF really bombed it on Dine About Town this year. We were taking my brother out to celebrate a momentous occassion, with a reservation for 3 - showed up 10 minutes early and then were told we'd have to WAIT 30 MINUTES TO BE SEATED. 

UHHHHH ok hold up here. Let's review. 
-First of all, that reservation was made days before. 
-your hostess was a snappish bia who honestly, shouldn't be heading your table seatings if she's going to be condescending to people coming in the door. 
-the mob of people waiing around us did NOT have reservations...and I get it that its Dine About and you want to make a profit and all from the evening by serving 400 dinners at half the price instead of the usual 200 or so (quoted by a staff member, by the way), but overbooking to the point where your actual reservations aren't seated in timely mannner??!?! IT'S CALLED WALK IN FOR A REASON. If you put someone in charge of seating, he or she should be smart enough to know that reservations have priority and shouldn't be put in queue behind those who attempt to get in for a cheap meal. 
-you make enough money, as any establishment in Napa or most of San Francisco with a plate average of $30+ will do, offer to buy your guests a round of drinks. Or if that's not in your budget "because of the economy" offer them bread or a sampling of appetizers. It ain't THAT hard!

Since it was such a late reservation on Dine About Night, we decided to stick out the wait. We were seated an hour later - NOT 30 minutes at our table. Miguel was wonderful, hence the second star. We were served efficiently and with attentive consideration of our tastes. He told us the pros and cons of the Dine About menu options (although when we asked for the special menus, it did take him a few minutes too long for him to get them to us at first....not sure if that was a subtle, disappointed "OH" that we weren't eating off the full-priced menu) and our wine glasses were always full. He, if anything, is what saves this restuarant from getting the horrible rating it deserves. And the fact that of the three steaks, I got the best cut! I think it had to do with my order being rare.

Go to Harris' or better yet, make the drive down to Palo Alto for Fleming's which is fantastic both in San Diego and up here. You'll be much happier with your creamed spinach and steak at any of those locations.
author: Alita M.

description:
I guess I'll update my review and bump Ruth's Chris up 1 star. 

Well you know how I said I would probably not go to Ruth's Chris again.. I lied obviously. I'm not saying I love the place though. It's now ok. 

We arrived a little after our reservations and were seated immediately. Service was attentive, and there was a Summer Celebration (a "5" course meal for two - $89) - 2 Salads, 2 Entrees, 2 Sides, 1Dessert - for two people. I was debating whether to spend $39 versus $45 to get more food, so the natural choice was to get the better deal and get more for what I was paying for. I'm Asian.. (so that's ok.)

I ordered the Steak House Salad with Bleu Cheese Dressing - which sounds like it comes with steak (but I read the description so I wasn't deceived.. if I hadn't I would be mighty disappointed to not find chunks of steak in my greens.) The salad was decent, but the best part was the actual chunky bleu cheese (not really a dressing, more a gloopy paste really..) I love cheese.. Yum. I'm sure my bleu cheese breath was stellar! Someone ordered the Seafood Gumbo.. That looked good.. I think I should've tried that instead.. Salads are salads.. nothing special.

I ordered the Petite Filet and my date ordered the same.. She also ordered the Mash Potatoes for her side.. I guess we should have coordinated or something, but we just kind of randomly paired up for the $89 deal and ordered without hearing each other. I ended up getting to try the Creamed Spinach - flavorful.. very delish!, and the Potatoes Au Gratin - cheesy and delish as well, but if I had more it'd be way too heavy.

My filet was perfectly cooked medium-rare this time.. Still kind of tough in some areas for a piece of filet. I've had better. It also wasn't drowning in butter, which I'm kind of glad about.. I like my steaks more simple.. black pepper and salt. My garlic mashed potatoes were chunky and tasty.. perfect. I also tried a Barbequed Shrimp (Sautéed New Orleans style in reduced white wine, butter, garlic and spices) -- succulent, but overly salty. 

For dessert, my date wanted the cheesecake, so I just let her decide.. At this point, I really couldn't stuff myself anyways. The cheesecake was not too heavy and very tasty. 

Not bad.. and look, now you get an extra star!

And my date was a girl.. I win! -- :D
author: Donna H.

description:
Two words: PRICEY CHAIN.

2nd time here within the past 5 years. Sometimes you need another boot up your ass to remind you why you didn't want to come back. 

Unfortunately the 2nd visit was mom's idea, who had not been out to eat with the family in a while and was thrilled to be out of the kitchen instead. Hopefully after this meal she will go back to home cooking without much hesistation.

Although the average steak here will run you a little over two President Jackson's, you do get a hulking big piece of meat cooked exactly the way you want and as they describe it on the menu. The downside is that the side dishes such as potatoes, veg, are extra and upwards of $8 a plate. As of Saturday night their specials were wild salmon, chilean sea bass, whole lobster, Australian lobster tail, and a Kobe style steak (can't remember which cut) at over $60. Refer to my yelp review of Miyazaki Beef on what "Kobe Style" could mean...

I shared a lobster bisque with my brother, who for this meal did not order his steak HHHHHHHHHRRRRRAAAAAAAREEHHHHHHHHHH
like at Le Charm (although he did get the T-bone). The bisque was one of the worst I've ever had. Practically no lobster flavor, the chunks of meat tasted nothing like lobster, more like shredded crab, and there was more cheap liquor flavor than anything else. Perhaps the version at Whole Foods would be a more worthy contender after having this.

My rib eye did come medium rare, and I swear the thing that caused me to have nightmares again was this melted butter thing on top that just sizzled into a puddle of oily goo on the side once the steak was left to sit on the plate for just a few seconds. Warning do not touch the plate.

The aged beef and quality, including the marination, is no doubt really good. However the greasy outer butter thing or whatever it is, kind of ruined my appetite for me. I have to say that as much as I love rib eye, it kind of pained me to cut away 40% worth of fat, although if I were 6 again  I'd eat this stuff first and even for breakfast without hesistation.
Don't get me wrong, I don't mind butter added to my Benihana steak, or fried rice, but this amount of butter on this $40+ steak and then some, is like asking for a heart attack, a neck choke, a deep wedgie, an orgasm, and sharp objects scratching against a chalkboard at the same time, thus making it hard to enjoy the 2nd to last item.

There was a joke in the family about not coming back again in 5 years (since the first time was that long ago). But no thanks, in 5 years I'd rather go down the street to House of Prime Rib. Never failed me.
Sorry Ruth, unless your first name is Doctor, I'm not interested in the least bit.

What really soured the dinner experience was the table next to us. After we asked for the check, and we had our plates taken away to be boxed, suddenly the guy at the table to our left was screaming bloody murder. Apparently one of the busboys "misunderstood" the meaning of "getting the stuff to go" and just threw down containers and bags.

The man scolded and lectured this busboy whose first language is not English (let's leave it at that), and instead of calling for the manager and his waitress, could not shut his trap at the poor sod. "For this kind of money, YOU should be boxing this up, I can do this at home" etc. Then the waitress gets a personal yelling "why can you box THEIR meals (referring to our table) but not ours?" Then the manager comes over, and this guy continues his sh*t fit. "Get this outta my sight (referring to the food)" and repeats the same lecture to the manager as he did with the busboy and waitress.

The table behind us and to our right starts to take notice and get annoyed. The dude behind me was on his date, turned to the guy and said hey stop ruining it for everyone. The complainer obviously didn't care and was ready to get the bill and get out (and never come back obviously). The madder he got, the louder he bellowed. Except he didn't turn into the Hulk, but an Ass.

Our waitress, who waited the complainer's table almost broke down in tears. My single brother, who took pity at our pretty blonde Italian or European waitress, didn't miss a beat and told her "hey don't let him get to you. He wasn't loved as a child". To which he mustered a small laugh out of her.
author: Ken K.

description:
Ruth's Chris Steak House.  What kind of name is that?  And why don't they tell you on their website?  

Here's why:  Apparently some chick named Ruth back in the day bought Chris Steak House in New Orleans.  She kept the name because it was bomb diggity.  One day there was a fire so she decided to move down the street.  But, and this is a big but, the purchase agreement said that Chris Steak House could be at no other location, so she had to change the name to Ruth's Chris Steak House.  So now you don't really pronounce it Ruth's Chris Steak House, you pronounce it Ruth's "Chris Steak House."  Get it?  Good.

Ruth wanted there to be a steak house that served high quality prime beef steaks with great, honorable service.  And to be quite honest, I think she got exactly what she wanted.  This place is bomb.  The steaks are so yummy, I ate all mine.  And it came with shrimps in a wheel.  We also got the broccoli au gratin (mega cheese), and the lyonnaise potatoes.  Everything delic.  Also got the chocolate souffle dessert for free because I was there for a birthday.  

All I have to say is this place is YUM.  Dark woodsy sophosticated atmosphere and lovely ambiance.  The one con is that it is e'spensive!  Expect to spend a couple hundo on 2 peeps.
author: Vanessa Z.

description: One of my favorite restaurants and always a real treat! Not inexpensive but you get what you pay for. Great atmosphere, great food and an impressive wine list.
author: Anthony V.

description: So great! Their calamari is really good as well. Every time I go here I am absolutely satisfied! My family and I usually go for special occasions like birthdays and Ruth's Chris has never disappointed.
author: Athina L.

description:
How come I make a reservation and I still have to wait half an hour before being seated????  Apparently this is not a complaint that only I have, but others as well.  Listen up restaurant, you should fix your reservations system and pacing OR not have one at all.  You piss off all the people with reservations and if they're anything like me, they come up very frequently once the reservation time has passed and bug the crap out of the hostess to get seated.

Went for my second time, another DAT event.  Mashed potatoes still got cold really fast, and the shrimp was way too creamy/heavy.  Service was hard to get although our waiter was fairly nice.  What I really hate about American restaurants, or maybe this restaurant in general, is that NO ONE would come help us when we had a problem.  AND no one would bother to offer and get us our waiter.  WTF.

I would only come here for a DAT event but after two times of not so great service, I might just have to never come here again.
author: Yosie G.

description:
Overpriced chain with mediocre rushed service.

Our table was beside an area where the staff congregated to get their napkins and cutlery etc.  We also discovered shortly after sitting down that this was also the area that the staff went into to complain about the customers that they had in the restaurant.  The service was rushed and patronizing.  

After being rushed in out out in less than an hour, spending $200 for two people I was left with the following question:
The steak was good quality and delicious, but what would you expect from such a popular chain steak restaurant?
In answer for the price, a lot more!
author: Claire m.

description:
I think we're all familiar with the risk factors of heart attack: family history, obesity, high cholesterol & blood pressure...

Add to that list: eating at Ruth's Chris Steak house!

I kept hearing the voice of Fabio in my head...but this time he was saying, "I can't believe it's ALL butter."

Yes, everything here pretty much comes with copious amounts of butter. Am I complaining? Four stars says no.

We started with the "barbecue" shrimp. I was confused as to why they coined it barbecue, because it didn't resemble anything barbecue like. I think what they should call it is BUTTER shrimp. Mmmmm...yes, 5 delicious plump little shrimp covered with a butter, garlic sauce. The sauce was probably better than the shrimp because we had to ask for more bread to make sure we cleaned up every last bit. So good...

I ordered the filet (medium) topped with blue cheese. The BF had the ribeye - I kept trying to convince him to get the Kobe, but he said no =(

Both cuts came out perfectly cooked, melt in your mouth tender and hot. I really like that they bring out the meat on a hot plate, it keeps the meat from getting cold, and more importantly, keeps the butter from coagulating!

We also shared an amazing bottle of Caymus 2005 Cabernet. OMG it was so amazing and went well with everything. The meat brought out the spicy notes of the wine and really enhanced the finish. 

For sides, we ordered the potatoes au gratin and sauteed mushrooms. Very good! The potatoes had more cheese than I had expected, but it still managed to be delicious. The mushrooms were a nice compliment to everything.

Dessert: chocolate EXPLOSION cake...they call it that because after you eat it, you're ready to explode. Well, I'm not sure about that, but that's how i felt. It was so delicious and big enough to share!

The service was exceptional - our waiter was wonderful (Kevin). Witty, patient, accommodating and fun. 

All in all, it was a wonderful experience. My only complaint about the whole evening - the cost. Yeah, it's a lame complaint, but I really felt like $10 for potatoes au gratin was way overpriced. I guess I anticipate paying these amounts at Boulevard or Farallon, but not at a chain steak joint. 

And that said, I need to go to the gym - my heart is hurting...
author: Christy L.

description:
Could you improve a waiter by drowning him in burning hot butter? Because it sure works with the steaks at Ruth's Chris.

When it comes to steak, I'm a purist. Salt, pepper, then chuck that hunk of meat onto the grill. Burn it to make sure it's dead, then toss it onto my plate. Steak appeals to my inner hunter -- bloody and dead like I killed it myself. The steaks here are good. Better than I can remember any other time I've executed a cow in 6, 12, or 16 oz. portions. But these steaks aren't so much steaks as butter sponges.

"Careful, the plate's hot." That warning has never been warranted to my ears until now. I like my food hot, but Ruth's is trying to burn my taste buds or something. My rib eye came out on a small plate that was practically boiling with butter -- the steak was submersed in easily a stick's worth of butter. The plate is necessarily hot to keep the butter from congealing over the course of the meal. Unfortunately, the heat of the plate continues to cook your steak over course of the meal, and is also hot enough to scald your tongue if you foolishly assume that resting your utensil on your plate is a generally safe thing to do.

No argument, the steak is damn good, but I think it's primarily because of the butter -- something about seas of saturated fat appeals to your tongue like explicit porn to your dirty, dirty eyes. It's somewhat a smart idea -- the butter keeps the meat moist, juicy, and warm -- but a few of these steaks every month and you'd be starring in your own BBW porn. I could go on about the mediocrity of the sides and dessert, but honestly, we are Men of Meat. Talk of sides does not become us.

Fortunately for us all, the bang-for-the-buck here is so outrageous, visits once in a blue moon is the most anyone could suffer. What kills me here isn't the food. It's the "decor" and the "service" --- or what passes for it. When you're dropping "upscale" cash, you justly expect better than a diner experience. I can't speak for the other Ruth's Chris franchises, but I swear the Van Ness location used to be a cheap diner. Ruth's put up faux hardwood walls, but they skimped on a full remodel. They still have cramped booths and cheap acoustic office ceiling tiles. To complete the ambiance, big cheap speakers mounted flush with the ceiling tiles play loud 60's and 70's hits. Just what every fine dining experience needs: The BeeGee's.

As for service... first thing's first: they lost my dinner reservation. On a busy night, with a date, or a business meeting, this would have been more than embarrassing. We were seated by the bar, and apparently, this is where the wait staff kills their time, chatting about the guests. They were probably talking about us. Unfortunately, I couldn't overhear what they were saying, three feet away from my table all night, over the din of Barry Manilow and The Supremes.

To say the waiters were inattentive would be a disservice. They never once came to refill the water, but they did come over and ask if I wanted coffee, while I was still having my wine. They also did make sure to ask if I wanted dessert, while I was only half-way through my steak. At least we weren't being avoided. Multiple waiters came to the table, often interrupting each other. And on our way out, they were indeed nice enough to locate my scarf, which they misplaced when they put it into the coat check.

I could just chalk up the incompetence to a series of bad luck. But I won't. Instead I'm going to blame whoever is their obviously blind and deaf general manager for delivering possibly the worst service I've had outside of fast food. Even in comparison to other diners --- Ruth's true peers --- at least the rude waitresses with the funny odors remember what tables are theirs. Go here for very pricey but tasty butter and steak. Do not go here with anyone else. They'll think you're an idiot. Unless they're one too. And then it's okay. Convince them to pay.
author: Perci N.

description:
Take note Ruth's Chris Steak House.....I came, I saw, and I should kick your ass.

This wasn't my first time here, so I should have known.....but it wasn't my idea this time, so I was trying to be a nice fucking guy.

A party of us went to wine and dine here. We know it's not cheap. We are not cheap. That being said, both Ruth's Chris and ourselves knew there was gonna be some serious coin flying around our table.

Maybe we look like tourists who won't be able to make it back to fatten your wallets again.....maybe we look like idiots that can be easily fooled. Either way, your service from greet to the seat - SUCKS!

I'll give you a little advice.....send your staff to Alfred's, Bob's, or Morton's (that's right, I said it - Morton's) and let them teach you a thing or two about manners, etiquette, and respect.

We were led to a table that could accomodate our party, and left there.....alone - no water, no bread, no drinks, no server.....nothing. When someone finally came to take our order, they seemed to wish they were somewhere else.....as we all were starting to wish.

We like to eat. We really like to drink.

Our wine (we ordered a few bottles) ran out before the appetizers came.....where the Hell is our server? 

Once we got replenished on the wine and started in on our appetizers, our server pulls another disappearing trick. Some other kids (why is everyone so young?) brought out our food and we played musical plates until the music stopped and everyone finally had the right meal in front of them.

Never saw our server again. No one came to ask if everything was OK, no one came to see if we needed more wine.....maybe they are trying to limit the amount you can spend so that the tip gets limited, too.

Maybe they think that their food is so good that we would be lost in our meals and slip away into oblivion.....we didn't. It's not that good.

We tracked down the Manager who was working at the time, (they seem to turn staff over more than Wilt Chamberlain got laid) to get us our last round of wine, and our server popped up out of nowhere and handed us a bill. That was it.....just handed us a bill.

It felt like this: "Hi. This is where you will sit and spend your money. I am the one who will be taking your money from you. This is what you will be able to spend your money on. Here is how much money you are spending. I see from your party size that I am allowed to calculate how much money you will be spending on me for a tip. Now get the fuck out."

Here's the breakdown:
1 star for inginuity.....you've found a way to charge the most money in town while providing the worst service.
1 star for bravery.....you are still open and not looking over your shoulder.

Waitstaff.....check this out - when you are staring down the barrel of a bill that tops out over $1200.00, please give the very best in service.....or at least a reach-around when you bring the bill.
author: Big J.

description: Great food and service! Went here for a date with my hubby last week. 9pm seating was perfect- not too busy, not too empty. It was pouring outside so we paid the $10 for valet parking- totally worth it! I had the Mendo Fog chardonnay and we shared the harvest salad- really good- and the cajun jumbo shrimp (I think they sub'd lobster though?) in cream sauce and that was awesome too. He had the ribeye steak and a side of creamed spinach- both great. I had the lobster tail with lemon and drawn butter- simple and perfect. For dessert, we shared the caramelized banana cream pie- WOW! Best dessert I've had in a long time! We had a nice evening there and we would definitely go back for more! We had a gift card so the cost didn't hit us in the wallet too bad but it is a pricey place- like $30-plus entrees with sides sold separately. Pretty steep but the quality is top notch!
author: Jen G.

description:
I was very much looking to this visit to RC San Francisco location. We drove from San Jose, 45 miles south of SF. Frankly I wouldn't because we have very good restaurants in the San Jose, but we had a $200 gift certificate. We vent there for my sister's birthday.  I knew that RC steak house has a great reputation and my expectation was set pretty high. We were at the restaurant July 27th 2014.
Review:
First of all, it is a pricey place.  The service was good and the staff was welcoming and polite. The décor was outdated and stuck back in 80s, but that doesn't matter much when you expect a great meal.
First we ordered appetizers. I had a Caesar salad. The was so much dressing on the salad that green leaves of lettuce were drowning in and it was not crunchy. We then proceeded to main course, which were a New York steak ($48), gratin potatoes ($10) and sauteed mushrooms  ($8).  The gratin potatoes were over cheesed with yellow American cheese and potatoes were not cooked thoroughly. The mushroomed were tasteless, blend and rather boiled. Now, about those stakes.... First of all, I have asked for medium, but got rather medium rare cocked meet. The meet was rather a poor quality. It was woody and chewy.  For the price the charge I was expecting a better quality cut of meat. You can buy a steak like that probably at Safeway for $10. I want to finish on the positive note. When they have learned that my sister had her birthday on that day, they have brought us a very good desert for free, I believe. Like I have said, service and attention was good.  Overall: I would skip.  Quality of food and cooking skills were poor. I believe you can have a better dining experience at other places for the money they charge their customers.
author: Vlad L.

description:
I'm always disgruntled with steakhouses because I feel like anything other than steak is mediocre and totally not worth the money.  Plus, I can grill up a great steak myself, so no thanks to paying $30+ for one that I can make in my own kitchen.

Having said that, this place is good if you like lots of meat, want a more date-y place, and don't mind paying a bajillion dollars for dinner.  This place is bad if you don't like meat, prefer hole-in-the-wall joints like I do, and don't want to be broke after dinner.

My favorite part of the meal was probably the dessert (sad, right?).  I'd ordered a salad when I came here with my family (all huge steak-eaters who believe that I'll somehow be malnourished if I don't eat red meat), and that was completely unappetizing to me, because really, who orders salad that even looks sad?  It's like it felt ashamed of itself for being so boring next to big hunks of bloody meat.

Anyway, I try to avoid this place.  To me, living in San Francisco means going to authentic little places where you can get great food at decent prices, not going to a chain and eating overpriced food with snooty service.
author: Tori S.

description:
RECOMMENDATIONS: make a reservation =)

*~*~*~* FOOD *~*~*
YUM had the Petite Filet and my bf had the New York Strip
...we also ordered the Sweet Potato Casserole with pecan crust...
OMG the sweet potato casserole is to die for seriously this was the best side that I had in my life...our waiter said that this one lady comes in and orders that for her dessert because it can seriously be a dessert also...

***SERVICE***
The service was awesome because they knew it was our anniversary and surprised us with Chocolate Sin Cake with a candle...so romantic!

***PARKING***
Had a parking lot nearby... had to pay for parking 

***PRICE***
Reasonable for what you get

***AMBIANCE***
dim lighting...empty wine bottle on display...romantic
author: Omi Y.

description:
You know, for the amount of money you have to spend here, I wasn't very impressed. 

The first thing that really peeved me was that it took forever for us to get seated. With an 8:30 reservation, they should have paced the tables better, or known how long it would take them to serve most people the dine about town 3 course meal. They have a tiny foyer, and it gets very loud out there while you are waiting, and there are not a lot of seats. I would say we waited between 30-45 minutes for a table, and in my opinion, that really sets the tone for the entire evening. There were definitely other people that came in after us, and got seated before. I don't know if it was because it was Dine About Town, but it irritated me none the less.

Everything seemed just...OK. I had whined pretty mercilessly about going to Ruth's Chris in the first place, seeing that it is a chain, and there were other better places (blahblahblah), and it did not live up to the hype. Both my friends got the Ribeye, and I got the Shrimp. We had mashed potatoes, creamed spinach, and some french fries, along with a bottle of wine. 

The server came up, and was very friendly about explaining the Process that Ruth's Chris 1800 degree grill, and how they heat their plates to 500 degrees so that your meat stays warm. 

Think about it. That means your meat is STILL cooking if you order say, a rare steak, which really isn't the best idea. My friend's ribeye was definintely overcooked by the time he got to the middle of his medium rare steak. 

My shrimp was OK, but nothing to write home about. It just seemed like a bunch of shrimp (at least they didn't skimp) with some creamy sauce without a lot of flavor over a bed of mashed potatoes. The creamed spinach was just ok - at least it didn't need salt, but it felt very very production line, since it didn't come out hot. The shoestring fries were just a snore, 

Honestly, I wouldn't come back to Ruth's Chris, Dine About Town or no. I am happy that I got to spend time with my friends, but there were (and are) definitely better places in the city I could have spent those dimes.
author: Jessica S.

description: Came here for dinner for a special occasion. Ambience look great, a good romantic setting.  We had a reservation and was seated promptly when we arrived.  We ordered the Ribeye and the Filet.  We also had the spicy lobster for appetizers, and i was delighted by the flavor... Probably my favorite dish by far... Our entrees came out a little late and the waitress apologized and gave us a complimentary dessert.  Other than that, the Service was excellent.
author: Vincent C.

description:
You MUST LOVE BUTTER to come here. Every steak is served in a pool of sizzling butter and the smell of butter slathers the air. By the time we left I felt sick from breathing the heavy sent of sizzling butter and I thought my hair was going to be a grease slick. 

I, while liking butter well enough, am lactose intolerant and cannot eat butter without becoming sick. I did not know that every steak was served in a pool of butter until it was in front of me. But the server, to her wonderful credit, did not hesitate to say "It's ok, we'll get you another one!" And whisked it away and brought another butter-less steak within 5 minutes. 

My steak then was naked, just as nature intended. No seasonings, just grilling. Which was fine with me. Good quality meat, cooked perfectly. Loved it. 

Did not love that for DAT menu I had to share my chocolate cake dessert. WHAT's UP WITH DAT?!?! What's next, we have to share the steak too???!?!?! 

Oh and totally bring your own wine, for the $15 corkage fee it is so totally worth it. The wine on the DAT menu runs about $42/bottle.
author: Victoria M.

description:
RECOMMENDATION:
Petite Filet and Shrimp- Well, this was what I got. For, I think, $39.95, this was a three course meal. A loaf of bread which was REALLY good and extremely fresh, came with an appetizer, entree, and dessert. For appetizer, I got the Harvard Salad coming with mixed springs, goat cheese, and oil/ vinaigrette. Really good! Then came the filet and shrimp. The shrimp was good but it seemed like the filet came in a bit greasy. Definitely, it came right out from the kitchen b/c you wouldn't dare touch the place. It was THAT hot. Don't let your food cool down b/c after the mash potato cooled off, it just came right out from the dish just like the dish. They probably added a whole lotta butter to make the potatoes good. Dessert was a slice of carrot cake and a chocolate cupped mousse cake. The mousse cake was good but carrot cake was on the dry side. Didn't really like that. 

Other than that, no wait compared to House of Prime Ribs (which was our first choice but because there was a 2-3 hours wait, we decided to come here). Definitely try to food and wine pairing (taste soooo much better when you have a slice of the filet and sip on some fine wine. Too bad they don't do the picture taking like House of Prime. Maybe next time.
author: Eudora Z.

description: Haven't been here for several years and considering the fact that a friend of mine had a gift certificate figured it would be a good time to have myself a steak for dinner. The food def did not disappoint!!!!!! Had the lobster bisque which was delicious, for an appetizer had the BBQ shrimp which were were just as amazing.  For the entree i had a filet with a side of cream of spinach. I went with the petite filet because i figured that we had ordered plenty of food plus i was stuffing my face on the delicious fresh warm bread they bring out. Im glad i went with the petite filet cause otherwise i probably wouldn't be able to move after dinner. Also have to mention the cocktail were really good, two thumbs up to the bartender!!!!!! My only complaint would have to be that filet had a pretty big piece of fat on it which was a little disappointing, i ordered a filet primarily because i hate the fat part. The waiter offered to give me a new piece of filet but i was getting fairly full as is and didn't want to waste it.
author: Dmitriy G.

description:
Overall rating: 4.5 Stars

As an avid steak lover it is only fitting that my first review be of this fine steak house. Thanks to Dine About Town my girlfriend and I were able to enjoy a great meal at a reasonable price.

We started with some warm, fresh french bread and probably the finest beef carpaccio I've had yet. The paper thin slices of raw filet were melt in your mouth tender and accompanied by garden greens and some white sauce.

The first course of the D.A.T. meal was a mixed greens salad which was identical to what was included with the carpaccio. Pleasant enough but nothing more than a simple, "healthy" start.

As expected the steaks were the highlight of the meal. I upgraded to the 16oz boneless ribeye and my girlfriend ordered the 8oz filet, both cooked to a perfect medium rare. The sizzle and aroma of the melted butter on the steaks is intoxicating. Few things can rival the flavor of a good ribeye, and this steak was no exception. The additional marbling in this USDA Prime cut of beef yielded an extremely flavorful, if not overly fatty steak. The filet was extremely tender and quite flavorful as well. Their signature melted butter is an excellent complement to both cuts of beef.

For dessert (which we hardly had any room left for) they served a moist carrot cake and decadent chocolate mousse. A sweet and satisfying close to a great meal.

Service was good overall. Our waiter was friendly and fairly attentive, though at times it seemed he was overextended among tables. The restaurant was clean and nicely appointed and the overall atmosphere was pleasant (the aroma of all the seared steak and butter didn't hurt!).
author: Matt T.

description:
I've been hearing about Ruth's Chris Steak house for a long time in fact since I first move here to San Francisco.  Everybody says "You have to try it, their meat is the best."   Well you know me, I am all about the meat.  I'll pretty much take what I can get if you know what I mean.

Over the weekend our gang woke up from a night of too much tequila and way too much shaking what our mamas gave us.  First choice was some little joint in North Beach which nobody wanted to make the trek to so we decided on meat and potatoes.  I am still in a food coma but it was worth it and I'd go back for more.
author: Clementine D.

description:
If I wanted a pat of butter on my meal, I'd order toast. Leave the butter for the bread and give me the beef! 

Yes, I'm a beer purist and I think that butter is stepping over the line. Salt, pepper, garlic, etc. is great to enhance the flavor of steak, but I believe butter absolutely changes the flavor profiles of the flavorful fat found in fine cuts of meat.
author: Al L.

description:
Do you like being served steaks sizzling in butter?  Well, then this just may be the place for you!

As the others have mentioned, everything here comes a la carte.  I'm not that fond of restaurants that serve entrees with all sides charged a la carte.  Oh, well.  The most interesting a la carte item I got here was escargot!  Tastes like buttered rubber bands...I suppose it's an acquired taste.

I'm not giving this place more than four stars, because the overall flavor did not impress me.  The steak was not as tender and good as I have had at other establishments.  I ate here a few times, because my friend was hooked on eating here.  Maybe she talked it up so much, I was just not very impressed.  I know the difference between good/fresh steak vs steak drenched in butter.  It was alright.

The setting?  Dude, it's dark in here...it's like an overpriced Black Angus...the times I've been it's been a bit noisy and not quiet for such a dimly lit place.  I guess it may be a good place to go if you're a couple or on a blind date and you are just more attractive in the dark.  Again, it was alright.  If you don't eat out a whole lot, it may even be quite good.  I eat out a lot though, so to me the food and atmosphere are subpar.  Then again, that's typical of a chain.
author: Ladi Da A.

description:
On behalf a non-yelper who had a wonderful experience here, I must yelp:

Last night she had the petite fillet medium rare with some sort of crispy, blue cheese concoction smothered all over the juicy vittles. With a wave of a knife over the fillet, the steak parted and revealed a tender pink-hued middle. She exuded joy as she told me, "It was the best steak I ever had". Then she added, "For 35 bucks, it damn well should have been".  Well said, my friend, well said.
author: Jessica D.

description:
I ordered off the Ruth's Chris classic menu and got a bowl of seafood gumbo, a 16 oz rib eye, creamed spinach and for dessert they brought out a chocolate mousse and fruit w/ custard. All of this for $49.95. HE had the fillet, broccoli and a salad + the same dessert for about the same price. Along with our meals, we decided to go all out and order the crabtini as an appetizer ($16). For drinks, I had the orange citrus mojito, he had a beer. 

First off, the crabtini was yummy, especially since it was made with huge chunks of fresh crab. Unless you're starving, don't get the seafood gumbo - it's VERY filling and you'll enjoy your entree more if you just get a salad. The steaks arrive to the table sizzling and straight from the broiler topped with butter & parsley. After first cut, I see that my steak is cooked EXACTLY how i like it, medium rare. After first bite, I fall in love. Perfect texture -- thin crunchy texture on the outside, perfect and juicy on the inside. Sides were just normal sides, nothing great. It's pretty pricey, but definitely worth visiting if you're a steak fan. 

Transportation to restaurant: there's a parking garage behind the place. They also do valet - but it's a lot of fun if you take the trolley in and very convenient since it stops right in front of the restaurant on California and Van Ness ($5 one way).
author: Melissa P.

description:
I'm with Elin, I'm also a certified cheap ass, so when my friend checked out the list for dine about town...she chose this spot because it's the best deal outta this promotion.

So I called them up, a few days in advance and was able to get a reservation for 3 on Sunday at 7:45. A couple of days later, my friend invited her roommates so I called them up and was able to easily change my res to 5 people, but got bumped to 8:15. NP!

We showed up at 8pm, a bit early, but was quickly seated even tho the rest of the crew wasn't here yet. We looked at the menu and realized that we needed to ask for the separate dine about town menu. 

So all 5 of us ordered the 12oz ribeye. Some got mash potatoes, some got creamed spinach.

After sitting around for maybe 5 or so minutes, our waiter came back and apologized that they ran out of 12oz ribeye and was replacing it with buffalo ribeye (really meant nothing to me...) and New York steak. I just went for the buffalo and called it a night.

Another 5 minutes later, he came back again to let us know that there's no more buffalo! So I just resorted to the 6oz filet that was also on the menu. Since I was just gonna pack half the amount of meat, I decided that now I room for bread.

Salad: Nothing special at all. It was flat and hard to pick up. I wish I had chop sticks.

Creamed Spinach: YUM. Full of flavor and still tasted kinda fresh.

Mashed Potatoes: YUM too, also flavorful.

The Meat: My filet came out a slight bit on the small side than what I've seen at other places, but it was simmering in herb buttaa. I cut a tiny piece of it and was completely WOWed. It was so tender, it's kinda like liver! (well..the liver thing was mostly on the outside). The meat at great heat and was slightly rarer than medium rare. It might be the blood, but damn it was juicy as hell. 

It didn't get cold until the near last bite when I already have been yappin' away. I was so glad that they ran out of 12oz because this filet was already more than enough...and every bite was awweesome.

Keylime Pie: Very tart as every keylime pie should be, portion was kinda big. It was soft almost pudding like. I couldn't finish it tho as my stomach started acting up. Eeps.

Overall Ruth's Chris is a great place to dine. The staff is super professional, friendly and attentive. The atmosphere is sophisticated but relaxed. Service was great, despite the steak shortage. Definitely a place for me to come back to on the next special occasion. 

Best steak I've had in the city thus far!

Now if I can only figure out why it is called "Ruth's Chris..." hm so good, maybe it's human meat!! 

Just kidding.
author: Faffy L.

description:
Really effing good.

I had heard of this place, their hot sizzling plates, their buttered steaks, their shoestring fries...but I had never been.

Well, I went the other night, and all the hype lived up.  The steak was cooked perfectly.  I only got the petite fillet, but just a head's up...it's not so small.  My friend got the same but with the blue cheese topping (delicious, but really heavy).  I got a side of hot peppers with my steak, which were also very good.  For a starter we shared a salad and the french onion soup, and to be really indulgent we got the shoestring fries.  The f.o. soup has been my favorite restaurant version to date, which is saying a lot, because I usually order it when I see it on the menu.

The salad was great, and a perfect size to split, as was the soup...I could have done without the fries, they were good, but I really didn't need them, or eat too many.  

I wish this place wasn't a chain, or so darn expensive, but it's nice, and deserves all the hype that it gets!
author: Kristin E.

description:
I came here on two occasions, once in San Diego and once in San Francisco for Dine About Town.  When I went to the one in San Diego, for 2 people, 2 steaks, 2 side dishes, no wine, we spent $200.

So, if you can imagine, going here for Dine About town is DEFINITELY worth it.  I love their steaks.  They cook it really well and have a unique way of doing it.  They do a dry rub and cook it in butter on the plate, so when you get the steak, the plate will be VERY VERY VERY HOT.  don't even think about seeing how hot the plate is... trust me, ITS HOT.  If the steak isn't cooked the way you want it, they are happy to re-do the steak for you, which is really nice.  For DAT, the steaks are a little bit smaller, but by the end of the meal, you are stuffed.  I like the creamed spinach and creamed corn side dishes.  What's also great is that you can choose between 3 different steaks for DAT.  

I would come here again for sure!
author: Diane L.

description:
We came here for a friends birthday.  It was his first time there and I was quite ashamed by the service.

We were seated quickly since it wasn't too busy.  We were seated in the back room and they had five tables at best with a ton of servers walking around.  

I ordered the veal chop with a side of potato au gratin.  It was tender, juicy, but the lemon butter just tasted like butter.  The au gratin was good at best, but their sides were never spectacular (except the sweet potato).

My friends ordered from the set menu (not dine about town).

Two ordered the ribeye and the other ordered the filet.  The meat was cooked perfectly.

Their meal also came with a choice of a side, starter, and dessert.

They ordered:

seafood gumbo-small shrimp, and needed more kick.  There wasn't much going on with the flavor profile.

Creamed spinach-more liquid than cream and it needed salt.

Garlic mash-that was nice and creamy, but not much garlic flavor.

Brussel sprouts with bacon-the shining star of the night! It had a smokeless from the Bacon, and it was slightly sweet in a good way (we're guessing they prepared it with brown sugar).

Dessert:

Symphony-dark chocolate bark embedded with toasted almonds and sprinkled with a bit of sea salt accompanied by a cheesecake.  I say accompanied because the chocolate was far superior to the cheese cake.  The cake was dense and didn't have the richness you'd think you'd get since it's so dense.

Creme brulee-I was really disappointed that the shell didn't not crack with a tap or several taps for that matter.  My friend just stabbed it with the form afterwards.  No crunch = :'(

Chocolate explosion-molten lava cake topped with a scoop of vanilla ice cream.  It's large enough for three people.  It was light, moist, and good.

So food gets 3.5 stars because the sides and dessert were hit & miss.

Now onto the service.  I am considered the slowest water drinker out of my friends and yet I still managed to stare around the room and wonder where our server went.  Did she have a family emergency? Leave for a meal herself? Who knows, all we knew were that we needed our water refilled to make the butter food go down.  We asked other another server that walked by and she said ok only to never return either.  I noticed the table in the back was wondering the same thing.  Everyone was done with their entrees and thirsty.  There were plenty of servers, but only ours were missing.  I finally flagged down another server and told her we lost ours.  The manager came by and apologized and our server magically reappeared with no apologies.  I can sense she was upset.  Sorry Courtney, but you were gone for more than half an hour.  The other table that belonged to her was able to quickly leave shortly after her return.

The service here just didn't cut it.  There are many other steak houses with exceptional service that I won't be in a hurry to come back.
author: Michelle S.

description:
Best steaks by far anywhere.  It ain't cheap , and neither am I ;-)
Its worth getting dressed up and shelling out the cash!  From appetizers , salads, steaks and desert are second to none!  The wine list is extensive and reasonably priced for SF.  Our server Andy was gracious, friendly and might I say handsome. Always a great place to go for that special business or celebration!
author: Kurt H.

description:
Ruth's Chris Steak House
1601 Van Ness Ave
San Francisco, Ca

This is a traditional steak house.  From the waiters in tuxedo shirts, to the leather booths, to the hefty prices.  I have never walked out of RC without paying at Least $200.00 Yes it is very high quality grade beef and I always drink wine with my dinner, so its not really a complaint its more of a statement....
On my most recent visit I had a wedge salad, Filet Mignon, Broccoli au Gratin, & mash potatoes.  For dessert I had a Graham Cracker crusted cheesecake with Muscat.  The wine I selected was the Flora Springs trilogy...delish!!
Gina in special events is my girl.  Every time I visit she always see's to it that I have a great booth and awesome service.  Gabby, my waitress was wonderful...I actually will request her next time I stop in for my RC Fix!!!!
Thank you Gabby & Gina
author: Michele K.

description:
Let it be known that I grew up on Outback Steakhouse. I LOVED Outback Steakhouse. I have particularly fond memories of ordering my first legal drink at an Outback in San Diego and then devouring their steak and potatoes with reckless abandon.

Until now.

Ruth's Chris has destroyed any appreciation or regard I may have had towards Outback. I have tasted the meat of gods, and I am not going back. Never again will I settle for a $30 steak meal. If Ruth's Chris had a Bloomin' Onion then I would have no need for Outback whatsoever.

Appetizers: Crab cakes were buttery and melted away in my mouth. Scallops were AMAZING - make sure to eat the pesto with them - they're not the same without! And finally, I HATE calamari. Ok, not hate it. Strongly dislike. But not here. The calamari is fantastic. I may start becoming a calamari-holic and just go here for it as a happy hour eat.

Steak: Generally when I order my steak medium well, it comes out brown throughout. I generally don't complain because I'd rather it be overcooked than still moo-ing. But RC actually got medium well done right with a little bit of pink on the inside! YES! The meat itself melts in your mouth and is served in butter, which completes the indulgence.

Sides: Hard to mess up a baked potato, but as someone who eats the skin, it's always appreciated when the skin is actually edible and doesn't resemble beef jerky. And their asparagus with hollandaise is also quite good - they give you way more sauce than asparagus so feel free to load up!

Great wine selection as well - we had the Silver Oak, and you really can't go wrong with a good Silver Oak cabernet. Good choices abound on the dessert wine/port menu, as well.

It IS pricey - expect to spend at least $60-$70 per person. And it IS a la carte - expect to order your sides separately from your steak. But I have to appreciate any restaurant that has enough respect for its main dish to let it stand as its own entity on the menu. The wait IS long - even with a reservation, expect to wait at least 30-45 minutes. But the bar is pretty accessable: my friends and I all got bloody marys, and they had a good strong kick to them. 

I am not well versed in upscale dining as of yet, but I would not recommend taking a sip of a bloody mary and then exclaiming loudly, "Wow! This reminds me of being 5 years old at the Colorado River!" 

They were VIRGIN bloody marys, people, I PROMISE! Stop staring at me!

My childhood is gone. These days I can substitute Berryessa or the delta for the river if I want to go water skiing, but Outback is now nothing but a sad distant memory. Thanks a lot, Ruth's Chris. 

(Shhh don't worry...I'll be back next month.)
author: Devon S.

description:
Dine About Town Dinner 2009

Blue Cheese Crusted Ribeye sitting in pool of hot butter = good
DAT value = good
MIA Waiter = bad
author: Jen C.

description:
This will be the second Ruth Chris I've dined at.  The other one was back east a few years back and I remembered not really enjoying it then either.  However, a friend was in town and he chose this place.  I had not dined at this location so thought I'd give it a try.  Unfortunately it reminded me why I have only dined at Ruth Chris only once prior to this time.  The food was blah.

Salad and bread was boring.  Boycott boring bread and lettuce in Bay Area!
Rib Eye was too fatty, not nicely marbled - just fatty.  In fact more fat than meat I'm sure.
Mashed Potatoes were a bit cold and frankly didn't taste fresh.

Our waiter was nice and competent (so 3 stars for him) but food was so poor that it doesn't rate more than 2 stars total.
author: Lev E.

description: Who would like some steak with their butter? Ruth's is a descent enough place with adequate service, but nothing here blows any wind up my quilt. The side dishes, while not bad, are nothing to write your ma ma about. It's a shame because the beef is of good quality, but they should throttle back on the drum of butter they cook their meats in. There are many other better steak houses in the City. Pet peeve: my martini was clearly stirred and not shaken; bring in the wreaking ball.
author: Michael G.

description:
So my bf decided that he wanted me to take him to Ruth's Cris for his birthday since he had never been here.  I had been to other locations a while back, but never the one in SF.  Let me tell you - the quality of the steaks has not changed :)

This is not a place where I could visit on a regular basis - the steaks are drenched in butter and I believe everything else is too - which makes it all taste so amazing! (But it doesn't help my diet whatsoever).  Our waitress was very friendly and knowledgeable on all the food and wine - which was very helpful.  

For dessert - my bf decided to get a cheesecake - and it literally was a whole mini cheesecake! HUGE!! The wait-staff was so sweet and they even gave him a little candle to blow out after we sang happy birthday to him.  

I highly recommend this place if you're craving a nice juicy steak, some great wine, and rich desserts!
author: Cherlyn M.

description:
There really isn't anything spectacular about this steakhouse. The fillet and prime rib are just okay. It was slightly overcooked, medium rare should be pinkish red, not beige pink. It also wasn't as flavorful as aged meat should be. The sides are huge, but everything is cooked in butter, salt and fresh ground pepper. 
The wait staff are a bit stiff so if you aren't dressed at least business casual don't expect to get treated well. My group wasn't ill treated, but I saw others snubbed. People come in for good food and treatment, the prices don't change so neither should attitudes.
author: Ready To Be S.

description:
I had been saving my 300th review to try this place... only to be not entirely impressed.

I expected it to be amazing. Golden cuts of meaty greatness slathered in sizzling butter that just melted as it touched your tongue. But I was sorely disappointed. Described as marbleized and mouthwatering, the cowboy rib-eye (bone in) was just a big hunk of meat. Not particularly succulent or savory in any way. It was an ok steak, but it didn't blow my mind or anything.

The sides were good, we had the creamed spinach, and steak fries. I would skip the appetizers all together. It's already too much food just eating a la carte. Service was really great though.

I think the bill ended up to be like 170 per person. I had  gotten a 100 dollar gift card from some raffle ages ago, so that cushioned the blow, then found a $25 dollars coupon online. To round down our costs to 50 bucks. That I would say was a fair price for our meal. 

It was not the value even for me. And I normally *heart* beefy goodnesses.
author: Jessica C.

description:
I made a reservation and requested for a quiet corner because we were celebrating our anniversary and would like to be undistributed.  We sat at a corner table and pretty comfortable but just too dark for taking pictures.

We came for the DAT menu but we also needed to ask for it.  Hey, why could the waiters just offer that automatically?  I guess that there were so many people going there for that - a $35 set for a steak dinner.

OK, talk about the dishes: -

- The bread was warm and the butter was delicious.  I could not help to finish quite a bit.

- The salad was just OK, quite small in portion, no character.  It's just like taken out from a packed veggie salad bag and add the little tomatoes plus dressing.  For a fine steakhouse like Ruth, I expect a better salad.

- Both I and DH ordered the 10oz ribeye steak, medium well as entree.  The sauce was so delicious (of course, there were so much salt and pepper and butter) but the steak was a bit disappointing.  DH's steak contained a lot of fat and he cut out almost 1/4 of the steak size of fat.  Mine was leaner but I found it a bit overcooked.  I needed to really cut it with force and it's a bit dry inside.

- We ordered creamed spinach as the side dish.  It's very tasty, soft but just too creamy.  Also, it's just warm not hot, most likely it's well prepared before, sat aside and be taken out to serve.

- We tried key lime pie and bread pudding as desserts.  DH liked the key lime pie but I thought that it's too sweet.  The bread pudding, on the other hand, tasted plain.

- DH ordered a bottle of bear and I ordered a glass of orange citrus mojito.  This cocktail did not taste like anything with alcohol.  It's just like orange juice with a lot of ice, seltzer and some basil leaves which did not worth $10/glass.

We paid $108 for the dinner including tip.  DH considered it too much for a OK dinner.  I think that Ruth's Chris has been over-rated.  The service was not really that good, just OK and the food did not worth the price (even though it's a cheaper menu already).  Parking is really a problem in that area, particularly after July 1 when the meter parking time extended to 8pm.  We possibly won't come back, sorry.
author: Roserrele W.

description:
Chrstina L said it best.....MMMMmm... Meat

Let me describe a situation to demonstrate why the 5 star.

When Christina left her seat after being done......I was very tempted to just swoop on her (OMG) left over 5 bite piece of rib eye steak.  

But I held my own.  Although my friend and I had no shame in taking over our other friend's bread pudding which looked done, yet was in the middle of an intimate moment.  

Alas, good food, good people at Ruth's Chris makes a great dining experience.  Definitely loved the 12 oz rib eye which went well with our wine which was the mix of different red wines.  Salad was alright, but light with JUST 2 croutons to prepare for the meatfest and sides of mashed potatoes and cream of spinach.

When asked whether Ruth Chris or House of Prime Rib, my answer remains: prime rib and steak is two totally different species.  They all come from the same being and is nonetheless, beef  cooked and served different.  I can't say one is better than the other and when served both at once, I'll say I'd boldly say I'll take a bite of the prime rib first, followed by a bite of the steak.
author: Vincent K.

description:
There are 2 thing I am certain I love in this crazy world: steak and butter. So when those two ingredients are mixed together, I am a happy, happy girl.

This was my first Ruth's Chris Steak House experience, and I must say, it was lovely. My date was a seasoned veteran (shout out to Mike!) and his recommendations were spot on. We started out with the fried calamari, served on top of sweet, sauteed red bell peppers. We each ordered the filet  (mine was medium rare), a side of mashed potatoes, and sauteed mushrooms. Rightfully so, the filet stood out. Mine was cooked perfectly, with a rare red center, and the simple salt and pepper seasoning was SO GOOD. Every bite of steak, paired with mashed potatoes (both drenched in butter) was delicious.

In addition to the delicious food, I must note that our server was very attentive and knowledgeable as well. The restaurant had a romantic ambience as well, dimly lit with cozy booths. I think it was the perfect way to end a lazy, rainy Sunday.
author: Laura D.

description:
Ok, don't get the lamb chops.  They're thick-cut, which is never a good idea.  I ordered mine medium rare, and they came fully cooked and tough.  The first chop I sliced into was barely pink in the middle.  And, I got the shrimp add-on.  MISTAKE.  I can't believe I paid $2 for one of these "jumbo" shrimp.  They were much smaller than the ones I buy frozen at Safeway.  They tasted fine, I guess, but it wasn't anything I couldn't do myself at home with a bottle of Cajun Seasoning.

Mashed potatoes were kind of gross.  They tasted fine, but they were clumpy and retained the shape of the bowl when you scooped some up.  Reminded me of school cafeteria mashed potatoes.  Not something I would pay $9 for.

Our waiter, Keith, was an angel.  Extremely attentive and helpful, and taking care to make sure the BF's dessert was OK (he's yogurt-based stuff intolerant.  I know, weird, huh?).  A+ for him.

Creme brulee bumps the rating up one star.  It's served with berries, ingenious!  Probably one of the best creme brulees I've ever had.  And this is comparing Ruth's Chris with France.
author: Cathy Y.

description:
Went here for our anniversary in 2004...place was golden!  The ambience, hostess (wow), & service staff set the right tone for a romantic dinner.  Looking back, i dont think I've had a better steak since.

The food was pricey but well worth it.  We had some lyonnaise potatoes and creamed spinach.  Way better sides than the House of prime rib.  Creme Brulee dessert was also bad ass.  Cocktails had the right liquor-filler balance.

The Ruths Chris in Vanness is way better than the one in Walnut Creek.  The Mortons in SJ was nice but the food wasnt as good.  The Alexanders in Cupertino had slighly better service but I still prefer this SF Ruths Chris over all those.
 
I hope this place has kept its good quality, service, and ambiance!
author: slbvic c.

description: went here for our anniversary before we went to see wicket. it was ok the steak came sizzling on a hot plate .didn't think about it at the time, but the steak was over cooked not due to the restaurant .because if you don't eat the steak right away it will continue to cook.we also had mac & cheese , creamed spinach and a baked potatoe . all were decent not great we had a lobster it was good. price was about $400 kind of high not worth the price. wouldn't come here again .quality of the food is not great. not worth the price..
author: Nellie J.

description: the food here is awesome. only thing l dont like is it is on van ness street. service was great food excellent
author: Hung M.

description:
I came here with mis padres and my sister, and we had a fantastic time.  Maybe it was because we had great company, but I really think there's something to be said for the food here.  

I ordered the $39.95 3-course "Ruth's Special", which comes with your choice of starter, entree, personal side, and dessert.  I chose the seafood gumbo (with fresh crab!), 6-oz. filet plus three shrimp, and green beans sauteed with garlic.  

The gumbo was good and the filet was pretty solid - tender, moist, juicy, and cooked to medium-rare perfection.  It could have used a tad more flavor, surprisingly, since I could see that it was sitting in a pool of butter.  I initially tried to save half as leftovers for the next day, but who was I kidding?!  My plate had nary a crumb left at the end.  Definitely stick to the green beans as your side if you come here.  Even though they were a little too salty, the sweet potatoes were too sweet, the mashed potatoes too buttery, and the creamed spinach was too thick in consistency to enjoy.  

I switched out the chocolate mousse and carrot cake for the cheesecake as my dessert.  Suffice it to say dessert is not RC's forte.  They took the "cheese" in cheesecake a little too literally.  The chocolate explosion was a little better, but I could have passed on dessert altogether.

All in all, I'd say this is a great little steakhouse that fits the bill when you want a decent steak in a low-key setting.
author: Kira K.

description:
I know, I know. Who cares what I think about a steak house.  I have no idea what the steak tastes like.  I don't eat land animals.  

What I can tell you is this: M. was so into his fillet (which was topped with a blue cheese crust) that he actually seemed sort of depressed when he got to the last bite.  So, I'd guess the steaks are pretty awesome.  The wine list is decent, the salad fresh.  My lobster tail was a little on the dry side, but not bad.  I love good bread pudding, and was pleased with theirs.  The thing that makes this place five star worthy though is the service.  Everyone seemed intent upon making sure we had the best meal ever.  I haven't seen a staff this attentive in years. Well done.
author: Amanda B.

description:
This place is lucky that I am even giving it two stars...

My kobe came out medium-rare! Boo! Boo! (thumbs down) I like it rare. They forgot to put the butter on top. The meat didn't melt in my mouth. I wasn't in ecstacy.

Steph's cowboy was Gross (with a capital G). I could have bought a bone-in ribeye from Safeway and overcook it myself! The filet mignon was mediocre. The porterhouse was short some ounces. 

One star for the excellent service and another for the carpaccio. 

I would not suggest this place for the next outing. Only if I am invited to a birthday dinner. 

They better please me next time!!!
author: Stephanie P.

description: I've been here a few times now and always have a fantastic experience. The food is amazing and the service is fantastic. I will definitely return.
author: Captain B.

description:
Great food, great service

My wife describes her chicken here as "the best chicken ever" whenever we go here or talk about going here. Steaks are always perfection! Try it!
author: Chris L.

description:
I was in Frisco for work, so my mother and stepfather drove up from San Jose to visit. Had the night off, hey, let's go get some steaks.

Okay, it's a chain, but a good one. This and Morton's are consistently good all around the country.

I ate my filet mignon without using a knife, it was THAT tender. It compared favorably to the best Texas beef I've had. Salad and sides were great, too.

Service was excellent, polite and prompt without being rushed.

Wine made the filets taste even better. The boys had the house pinot and Mom had the Sonoma Cutrer chardonnay.

The chocolate cake was the capper... and with espresso and cognac side by side... ooh

Pricy? Who cares?! I love decadence, and this is a great place for it!
author: Steve G.

description:
Ugh.....  Empty restaurant at 6:00 p.m. on a Saturday with the exception of the three tables of strangers they crowded into one corner (cuz, we all should get to know each other.....).

Ordered Surf and Turf.  Have had much, much better steaks at much cheaper restaurants.  Lobster was like rubber.

Had theatre tickets and informed waiter.  Could not get the bill till 7:43.  Curtain was at 8:00.  Missed the theatre thanks to slow service.  Should not take two hours to have an entree, no first course and no dessert.

Service was courteous and the atmosphere was wonderful.

With the wealth of restaurants in the area, will probably not be back. 

Feels overall like the fake corporate version of those elegant steak houses our parents would take us to.  Sort of the Disney version.....

Perfect for "non-foodies" who are pretty happy eating just about anything.....
author: Robert R.

description:
**updated Feb 5, 2008**

Did the Dine About Town with some friends.  We got the calamari and ravioli appetizers.  They were ok, nothing special.  The bottle of pinot we had was excellent.  For the steak, we all ordered the rib eye, from the dine about town menu.  After having our steak, we all agreed that our rib eyes were sub par.  They were missing flavor; mainly salt in my opinion.  I did hit like 2 pockets of flavor on my steak but otherwise the rest of my cut was fairly bland.  Disappointing this time around.
author: Sam T.

description:
I had such a heavenly meal at Ruth's Chris this past Sunday!  My friends and I were there for the Dine About Town menu, and I must say, it was one of the more worthwhile DAT experiences I've had.  I loved the fresh baked bread that arrived at our table along with the whipped-but-not-too-whipped butter; it totally made me almost too full to stuff all of my 12 oz. ribeye down (but I did since it was toooooo good to waste).  The first course of arugula salad with cherry tomatoes and balsamic vinaigrette wasn't anything to write home about, though it was a good appetite whetter (if the bread weren't enough).  

What made my meal was, of course, the steak.  God, thinking about it now is making me salivate.  My medium rare ribeye came out still sizzling in a small pool of butter on the 500-degree plate.  The meat almost melted in my mouth - it was so tender and juicy.  I've never eaten the fat layer around steak before, but I found myself eating both meat and fat with equal gusto - that fat tasted wicked good.  (argh... still salivating over the thought...)

I got the key lime pie for dessert.  It wasn't spectacular, but it's still a decent key lime pie.  After tasting a bite of my friend's bread pudding though, I have to say that I ordered the wrong one, especially for a cold winter's night.  That bread pudding was comfort dessert through and through.  Yum.

Wow, what an experience.  It was $58 per person - this includes wine, tax, and tip - but it was sooooo worth it.  I can't wait for the next DAT so that I can revisit Ruth's Chris.  I probably wouldn't go normally cuz it costs an arm and a leg, but I would 100% go back for DAT.  Yowza, what a deal!  :)
author: Diana C.

description:
I had high expectations going to this restaurant, as my friends have been raving about this place. I usually go to House of Prime Rib across the street, and going to Ruths Chris never really crossed my mind. My boyfriend had also heard good things about this place, and being partial to HOPR himself, he also had never really thought about trying this place.  So on a whim one day (withouth consulting Yelp, shame on us!) we decided to try this place.

The service was great, we were seated right away (we DID have reservations) and we were able to sit in a semi private booth towards the back. All the wait staff smiled and greeted us as we walked toward our seat. Once seated, we ordered the ribeye (for him), and the petite filet (for me). We also got shoestring potatoes and broccoli au gratin. Upon receiving the food, we weren't incredibly impressed like we were hoping. I mean, the steaks were definitely better than something you would get at Black Angus or Outback, but not $35-40 worth better. My steak was not tough but it wasn't as tender as I was hoping (and I got medium rare). The shoestring potatoes were crispy and over salted. The broccoli was more appealing to me than the steak (probably because it was covered in cheesy goodness).

I'd say this place is slightly overpriced for what you get. The atmosphere is cozy enough and the wait staff friendly. If you're going to impress someone on a first date with steak (assuming it's their favorite), you may not want to come here (try Alexanders in Cupertino) but its worth at least a try so that you can judge for yourself (this place is either loved or hated, it seems).
author: Katherine P.

description: This steak is so superyummylicious! All I have to say is butter! And the augratin potatoes are a must have!!!! Make sure to reserve a spot its always busy! Great place for an anniversary dinner or celebration dinners! Drinks are great and strong!!!! Whoooo hooooo!!!! Dress cute but comfy, cus you're going to leave here with a full yet satisfied tummy!!!!
author: Venus R.

description:
Seriously?! Seriously.

I went for dine about town (thank god, or else I may have really hated myself for paying full price).

You enter the restaurant and are instantly flooded with the scent of butter - clothes, hair, skin, all drenched in vaporized butter.

Another guest at my table got a dirty plate - I'm talkin so dirty, it stained the white table cloth.

My napkin was dirty - there were clearly visible brown/pink stains.

I ordered the filet. Truthfully, yes, the quality of the meat was fantastic. Cooked perfectly. I appreciated the searing hot plate - I do love my food burning hot. But the butter is a bit overkill, I think. I ate the whole thing, but then couldn't bear to smell the scent of butter any longer. I had to push my plate to the end of the table. 

I had mashed potatoes as my side - nothing spectacular, just some standard mashed potatoes. 

Someone else at my table ordered the lobster - tough, dry, overcooked. I could tell just by watching them cut it that it was not too appetizing.

Another table received their entrees, and the scent of butter induced my gag reflex. I almost vomited. 

Dessert came. Key lime pie. Nice and tart, but I was so sick from the smell of butter, I could barely eat it.

Ruth's Chris is great if you have dry skin and need some vaporized butter moisturizer. The meat is fantastic quality, but I think you have to really enjoy the flavor of butter to enjoy the meat.
author: Joanne T.

description:
This is the first Ruth's Chris that I've been to, and I actually found it quite good.  I am definitely do enjoy steaks too and have been to various steakhouses in NYC, Boston, Texas, Chicago, etc.  It has to be unhealthy with the meat coming out on a plate of boiling butter, but the meat definitely has taste and was cooked just as I had ordered.

My friend unfortuantely had his overdone only because they were giving smaller portions of the ribeye for the dine about town event (I had the petite filet mignon).  The service was excellent as they offered to get him another steak or comp his wine or dessert.

The sides were so-so and not as impressive as other steak houses I've been to.  I don't want a heart attack, but I'll likely end up back there some time.  Still though, the best steak I've had in SF is the kobe beef rib eye at Harris.
author: Clarence K.

description: Still 5 star for customer service and food. Reservations are not crazy like Harris and House of Prime Rib.  I really love the ribeye. The filet was a good too and can pass as filet mignon that other places try to serve. Also, i always have the creme brulee. Me and the gf usually order the seabass but they didnt have it this time around because it was out of season.
author: Jeff C.

description:
This is the Starbucks of steak. No matter where you go in the country you are likely to find a Ruth's Chris, the food is better than average and over-priced. I used to work in the Van Ness area and this was the quiet bar to plot in after work. After leaving that job I have refused to ever step foot in a Ruth's Chris again. 

So if you want safe, better than average food, well here you go...
author: Seamus M.

description:
I've said it elsewhere, but I'll say it again: My husband and I decided a few years ago to make it our mission to try every steakhouse listed in Zagat SF, and at the end of the journey and 10 lb. heavier, we believe that Ruth's is consistently the best overall experience. I was even deflowered as a buffalo virgin there. And we've taken my husband's mom there for dinner. We've taken my mom there. And we dined there with our son when he was a newbie (he slept most of the time), and the staff didn't bat an eyelash. We ate here when I was so pregnant that I had to sit near the bathroom (if you don't know why, I will tell you that my bladder was reduced to the size of a pea, OK?). I think I ate at Ruth's in a dream.

I hate that this place is so popular because we sometimes can't get in for reservations the same evening we get a sudden yearning for primo beef.
author: Jennifer P.

description:
Dine about town was really worth it. 
nice ambience, i love restaurants with dim lighting. very busy but we got a booth so that was nice, our server elyse was great. 
i had the 6 oz. petite filet which was more than enough and my boy had the 12 oz. rib eye which was huge and we ended up taking it home. sides were good, the spinach was great but the mash potatoes was plain. desert was ok. i just wish the desert was a little more creative and they had more salad choices, but im giving it a 4 because my filet was super good and superrrrr soft!!!! best filet i've ever had!
author: emily p.

description:
3.5 stars

Its been said by several Yelpers. The one word in almost every review: BUTTER! a little butter is fine, but this place just overdoes it.

Steak? butter
mashed potaters? butter
creamed spinach? butter
bread pudding? butter
water? butter (Well not really, but if it were up to them, they'd probably manage to get butter in it too.)

Our party of 6 came here for DAT dinner for $31.95. This is probably one of the few places worth doing DAT considering the reg price of each individual item.

Appetizer:

free house bread w/butter

Salad - your typical salad, nothing special, fresh greens, one tomato (uh huh), your pick of dressing, but it's a viniagrette by default, perfect portion - The salad is about $8-9 reg menu price.

Entrees:

6 ounce filet - loved it minus the butter. I asked for medium and it came out medium, a little pink on the inside. juicy. perfect size. - The 6 ounce filet is about $32 reg menu price. Good steaks don't need a ton of butter to cover up its great taste. Ruth's already has a great steak, just go easy on the butter and stop going butter happy. Keep it simple.

ribeye - not too bad, just okay, not as great as the filet....over $40 reg menu price

Sides:

mashed potaters - floating in butter, but it had a good consistency and was flavorful, could taste the slight hint of garlic, my grandpa normally does not enjoy American food, but he almost killed this on his own, portion is very generous. 

creamed spinach - very buttery again, not as good as House of Prime Rib

about $8-9 reg menu price

Dessert:

key lime pie - good tasting, i'm not a fan of lime and i found it just perfect, not too tangy for my liking

bread pudding - loved it! warm and moist, more importantly, it was not overly sweet

about $8-9 reg menu price

Overall: would only come back again (maybe) for DAT, some items are overpriced, not for the health conscious people, service is just ok (our waiter was a little off and kept forgetting certain things we requested) It took four people to finally bring us some straws. Def make reservations in advance.
author: Veronica H.

description:
My boyfriend and I went here for our anniversary and it was WONDERFUL.  The waitress was great, the food was EXCELLENT and the atmosphere was great.  I hate steak houses that are supposed to be romantic but are load and crowded, but this wasn't that way AT ALL.  
It is expensive though, $170 for the two of us, we both had 2 cocktails.  So keep that in mind :-)
author: Tiffani C.

description:
I love this place... once again let me remind you that I do not eat steak.  However everything else on the menu is fantastic.  I always order the stuffed chicken.  It is so wonderful.  The crème brulée is the best I have ever had.  After ordering it here 5 years ago I search for something as good and haven't found it yet. 

Ruth's Chris is a great place to go for a special occasion, plus they will give you a free dessert if you are celebrating. Score! 

Very high class, professional service.  Take your next date there.
author: Sara H.
