description:
In terms of the quality of the steak, this is one of my fav steak houses. Better than Morton's and Harris. I'd rate the steak about the same as flemings.

In terms of sides... they need more options. The options are a bit "old-fashioned" and need some revamp.

All food is served mixed with a pound of butter which makes any and all food taste scrumptious. Hey... everything in moderation.
author: David S.

description:
This is your typical overpriced chain steak joint.  With so many great steakhouses within a few blocks in the city, you could definitely get more bang for your buck elsewhere.

My steak came dripping in butter.  It was a liquid heart attack waiting to happen.  It also came way more cooked than medium rare.  No thanks.
author: Jenny L.

description:
Is it weird that my 12 oz. Rib eye steak tastes better as a leftover the day after than at the actual restaurant? 

Anyway... one of my gfs got lucky enough to score Sat night dinner reservations here during Dine about Town. Sooo since I've heard good things about this place and have never been, I happily accepted the invitation and off we went. Parking was a bit of a pain, had to circle around the block a few times (took 20 minutes). 

Got seated almost immediately. Our server was nice, and we both ordered fairly light cocktails since I was hungover and she's not a heavy drinker - the berry cocktail and strawberry daiquiri. They were good, but I wasn't impressed by their cocktail list. 

Sooo the entire time I was here I kept thinking how we could've easily skipped out on our reservations and just went to House of Prime Rib instead. 

The salad is whatever. We both ordered the 12 oz. Rib eye, and the presentation of the steak is soo unappealing - basically it comes out in a small white oval shaped 300 degree sizzling plate. Bread pudding for dessert... ehhhh. I would say that definitely the highlight was.... the BREAD. 

I am definitely disappointed, but again - the meat WAS delicious the day after, so.... 3 stars?
author: Leily P.

description:
Don't even let the word 'diet' creep into your mind when you go to this restaurant.  The steaks are served on a hot plate laying on melted butter.  Oh my!  As gross as that sounds, it tasted soooooo good.  I tried not to eat too much of the butter with my filet, but you can't help it.  The steaks seems to absorb it - and it just adds to that wonderful flavor of the meat.

As most steakhouses do nowadays, sides are separate.  If you don't want your poor steak to be lonely, then pick out some sides.  The potatoes au gratin are so rich and creamy and dreamy.  And you gotta have the creamed spinach.  

Sorry, the dinners usually fill me up so I don't get to try the dessert, but if they're running along the same theme, I'm sure they're rich and delicious.
author: Denise M.

description:
Sometimes a girl just needs a hot and buttered, solid piece of beef.

The petite Fillet Mignon is more than your average carnivorous snack, it reflects a distinguished palate and an air of sophistication.  Well, it's good beef cooked to a rare perfection.

Not needing to use a knife is more than ladylike, forks are sexy - especially when used on meat.

Only four stars because you just can't eat food like this very often or, and I'm not a doctor or anything, but I'm relatively sure you'll die of coronary heart disease brought on by obesity.

Seriously, the steaks here can satisfy most and the decor is dark and romantic in a sort of chain restaurant, secluded mineshaft kinda way.

Sure to please and I've heard the lam chops are also fabulous.
author: Lauren G.

description: The food quality is great but the service was extremely terrible. I went there in my casual clothes and just wanted a nice meal. I don't mean to sound self entitled but the when I spend $200 on a dinner, I expect great service. I told them to box my food but instead they threw it away. The food was basically untouched. They said they couldn't remake it because they were "out" of the right ingredients.
author: Raymond L.

description:
Dinner for four, a little over $300, not including more than 1 glass of wine, but including salads, and a few sides, and one dessert.

Worth it?  DEFINITELY!

My steak was RIDIC-culously good, so was everything else.  And don't get me started on the bread pudding, don't you dare!  It was heavenly, scrumptious, out of this world, and all this coming from someone who doesn't EVEN LIKE bread pudding!

P.S. This is my little brother's favorite place, and he's gone more than I have (brat!).  Thank  goodness for him though, if it weren't for him wanting to go, my parents would have opted for something else on the visit!
author: Jennifer H.

description:
This was our first visit to the SF location.  All in all, we were happy with the meal, but not as impressed as we were after our experience in Wailea, HI.  That may be an unfair comparison, considering that the service we received in Hawaii, not to mention the food, was stellar.  

First thing that struck me as funny was our valet.  Did his job, and did it well, but as he got into our car, he says, "Have a good one, bro." Now I'm no snob, but I did work as a valet for several months out of the year for two years.  In the places where I parked cars, calling customers "bro" wouldn't get you fired, but certainly would affect your tip.  Anyway, no big deal, we got a good chuckle out of that as we sat at the bar waiting for our table.  

Our booth was ready just as we finished our first round.  Great timing. 

We ordered a fried calamari appetizer... No, not because we thought we were at TGI Fridays, but because that is the only seafood that my wife and I will eat together. Plus, a fried calamari at an upper scale restaurant piqued our interest.  Drizzled with a sweet and spicy thai sauce, it didn't disappoint.  

Being our cutsie selves, wifey and I sampled each other's steaks - my ribeye and her filet, both medium rare.  My steak was pretty damn good, but my feeling of contentment turned into a little bit of butt-hurt when I tried her filet.  It was PERFECT.  So from then on, although I enjoyed my ribeye, there was the little voice in my head saying, "You should have ordered the filet, dumbass."  

But the sides, au gratin potato and creamed spinach, were to die for.  Those were a hit with both of us. Simple and delicious. 

We ordered BR Cohn Cab, which paired very nicely with all of the courses.  Good wine, but pricey... DUH, I know, and I fully expected the ridiculous markup, but this was the BR Cohn Silver (about $12-16/bottle) at $16/glass.  BR Cohn Gold at BevMo is $50....  My advice, BYO and pay the corkage.  We didn't BYO because I only expected a million% markup, not a billion%.  Oh well. 

We came close to finishing our steaks, but not quite.  We were absolutely stuffed, but that does not stop the good 'ol dessert upsell at the end of the meal.  "Well, if your stuffed, we have some wonderful sorbet..."  

NO, you smoothly transitioning to the close bastard.  I'm full.   

Overall, a great meal.  Oh, and the valet didn't call me "bro" on the way out.  He called me "dude."  He got $3.00.
author: K. I.

description:
Had a friend in from out of town and started at the bar which was good service.  Continued to our table where it took forever to get our wine.
the steaks came out undercooked, we sent them back and they were OVERcooked!  by the time the waiter came back to take our order for after dinner drinks we were already finished with our dessert.  This is supposed to be a great restaurant and we will never go back!
author: Michelle M.

description: high end steakhouse chain that you can't go wrong with. dark and formal decor, solid if unspectacular service, and pricey but they had a set menu (salad, steak, side, dessert for 40 bucks or something like that) that was actually quite reasonable. as for the food, caesar salad had more cheese than salad, steaks are buttery and cooked to the right temperature, lobster mac and cheese was underwhelming, and everything was just a bit salty for my taste.
author: Sherman L.

description:
Guys night out and where better to go then to a steak house? (OK... guys night out, I can think of a few better places BUT mind out the gutter guys) 

Ruth's Chris SF is freakin amazing. I have been to some pretty high end steak houses from San Diego to the Bay and Ruth's Chris is TOP NOTCH! Too bad its a chain! =( 

We went for dine about town but ended up ordering off the regular menu. 
I started with the asparagus salad which came with a really good vinaigrette, crispy asparagus and fresh greens. My Fillet was perfectly MR and melt in your mouth tender. It was actually the side dishes that stole the show though. We all split Creamed Spinach - which might have been the best ever, Potatoes Au Gratin - which I would have died happy if I choked on it, and Sweet Potato Casserole - which words cannot describe. Dessert was good too but I was too full to really enjoy it. 

Thanks Ruth's Chris. I love you.
author: Nick B.

description: Ruth's Chris is a "brand name" in steakhouses.  Looking for a good steak & haven't been here? You will not be disappointed. They have the cooking technique down to perfection. Rare = Rare every time. Standard fare for steakhouse - surf & turf is available, order the sides separately etc.  A good, if not, very good, wine list (but better to bring your own & pay the corkage).  I'm a fan of the boneless rib eye. Perfection in a piece of steak. I've eaten at Ruth's Chris locations all around the country & always leave satisfied.
author: Aaron B.

description:
If you love a good consistent steak, this is the place to go.  The service is on mark and attentive.  Dine about town is a great value here, but they've been having a special for more options which is just as reasonable.  They have the most delicious chicken I have ever had and sometimes dream about.

If you go have the fresh berritini.  It's work the like $s.

I say go!!  Yummy
author: Debora B.

description:
Went during Dine-About-Town, and probably the only reason why I would go back to this restaurant.

Although the food was excellent, the price wouldn't be worth it at full price.  For the special offer of Dine-About-Town we were given an appetizer of the house salad (Wasn't special at all), a choice of either 8oz fillet, stuffed chicken, or BBQ shrimp (Chose the fillet).  The Fillet also came with a choice of creamed spinach or mashed potatoes.  For dessert they served a bite sized carrot cake which I though was very good, and chocolate mouse which was only OK.

The fillet was cooked rare, and very delicious meat, however not the best I've had.  The creamed spinach was quite tasty and complimented the meat nicely.  I also added an order of the Sweet Potato Casserole with Pecan Crust.  It was better served as a dessert, but it was probably the BEST THING I HAD.  

The whole tasting menu was 35$.  The fillet itself on the regular menu was 35$.  I must say that I would not go back again to Ruth's Chris just because of the money, but if you have money to spend this restaurant would be a good choice.
author: Greg T.

description:
The best item on the menu is the Cowboy Ribeye - medium rare. The second best item, the sweet potato casserole. Both items are not on the Dine About Town menu.

The DAT menu at Ruth Chris is the best value by far, but come VERY hungry. Make certain to digest a good few hours before sleeping. When I go to bed that full, I get zombie nightmares. But damn, it was worth it!
author: Judy L.

description:
Holy Heaven.  Steaks are to DIE for.  They come out to you on 500 degree plates surrounded by a drizzle of sizzling butter, and your arteries cringe at the sight but MMMMM!  ALTHOUGH the side dishes were VERY below average.  One big star off for that...the Au Gratin was boring, and the fries were over crispy---to the point where the potato on the inside of the fry was so overcooked that the fry was just a hollow husk of grease soaked crispyness.  Basically they tasted like REALLY greasy potato chips.

Get salad dressing on the side of your salad or youre in for a soggy dressing drenched experience...but hey the dressing is so good (homemade I think) that you really dont mind THAT much.
author: Cathleya G.

description:
The only great thing there is the valet parking...

The medium rare steak was too medium and not enough rare, the potato was barely warm, the salad had nothing exceptional. The service was very "pushy" (hurry up, don't you see the long line of customers outside, waiting for your table?!?). Can you believe this: we had a table for 7:15 and at 8:20 they were already handing me the check! (and what a check $$$!!!).

Oh well, it was my pre-Mother's day dinner with my sweet teen: the star is for her company XOXO.
author: Lili G.

description:
Ruth's Chris never dissappoints for a great, satisfying meal.  My boyfriend and I always go to this location for special occassions and holidays, and I have never dissappointed with any aspect of our night.  From the hostesses up at the front, to when our waiter gives us our check at the end of our meal, they are 100% efficient in everything they do.  The food is always top quality and always leaves you wanting more, even if you feel as if you are going to explode!

Hands down...one of the best restaraunts in the city!
author: Rebekah H.

description:
This is only my second time to Ruth Chris, the first being the location in Walnut Creek. My first experience was fantastic, great service, great food, great atmosphere. Fast forward to Easter 2012. We arrived for our reservations around 4:30 and the restaurant was still pretty empty, but despite that our service was extremely slow. I have high expectations for restaurants of this caliber when it comes to service and they absolutely dropped the ball. When I have to ask my server for everything or make eye contact to get him to come over, you know it's not going right. Super attentive is what the description of service should be.. they were so inattentive it bordered on the line of being lackadaisical. 

The food was ok. I ordered my steak well done and it still came out Medium, not even Medium Well. I am a trained chef, so I know the difference. They happily took it back to re fire it, but left my sides, so by the time my steak came back out cooked the way I originally requested it, my sides were cold and they didn't even offer to bring out new sides. For the amount of money that is spent, they should have immediately took my sides and steak to the back and brought both back hot.

Our bill for a table of 3 was $200(inexpensive considering), and we still left the waiter a $30 tip despite his lack of service.

I am definitely not impressed with the SF location, but I will revisit  Walnut Creek to hopefully bring back my original good feelings about this brand.
author: N B.

description:
My favorite steakhouse in the city - and i've been to them all.  I know its a chain, but come on.  The steaks kick ass, the sides are to die for (beefsteak tomato is killer), the desserts are good, they have a reasonable wine selection and the bread they give before the meal is worth the coming in for by itself. 

I really like this place.
author: D S.

description:
I will keep this short because there are better places to be discovered, and you should spend time trying to find them rather than eating here.  THERE ARE MUCH BETTER STEAK HOUSES IN THE CITY!

Expensive
Steak is ok, but not worth the price
Sides are not interesting
Desserts are not even notable
Wine list is overpriced, even for SF standards

If you want a good steak for a reasonable price, go to Harris.  The steak was way better, service was good, and the sides came with the meal, and were better...all for the price of the steak and Ruth's.  If you want to spend the money, go to Morton's.
author: Kapeli M.

description: I came here for by annual dinner.. Thank you 'Dine About Town.' You really get what you pay for. Food is great and service is remarkable. This was the first time at a fine dining spot where I didn't feel discriminated against my age. I can't say how much I love their service here. It's better than their steaks!
author: A W.

description: This was the first time I've ever been to a Ruth's Chris.  Called from the road to make a reservation on a Saturday evening. Got in right away at 5:00.  Service was great! Waitress was very helpful with my menu selection.  I chose the Cowboy ribeye with loaded baked potato and a house salad. The salad was topped with a delicious ranch dressing... just the right amount.  The loaded baked potato was perfect.  I didn't have high expectations for the steak, since I was told that it was seasoned with salt and pepper only.  My steak arrived sizzling on a very hot plate.  It  was a bigger portion than I expected, I think enough for 2.  I took my first bite and realized I've been missing out!  This was the best steak I have ever eaten in my life!  It was well worth the price.  I just hope the Ruth's Chris closer to my home is just as good.
author: B R.

description:
Impeccable service.  Friendly and attentive. 

One of the best steaks I've had.  Definitely will be going back again and again...

We went for the Summer Special -- a 3 course meal for two people for $89.  What a deal!
author: Di W.

description: Felt as though we had the "B" team taking care of our table. Food was good, service was just ok...
author: A. B.

description: This is still my absolute favorite steak house in SFC. The meat is delicious, the wine menu huge, but what I mostly love the a ambient and the extraordinary service, this makes the difference to Mortons or Alexanders, e.g..
author: Marc B.

description:
Came here for dine about town but got some of the fixings (toppings for the steaks and wine and pre-dinner drinks) so the price more than doubled from what it would have been originally for two people. 

Let's see: 

For the entree she got the 8oz Petite Filet with Blue Cheese Crust and I got the 12oz Ribeye Oscar Style (topped with crabcake, asparagus and bearnaise sauce). We got these steaks rare or reeeee as mickey blue eyes might say....rflol

The sides are rather large so we each ordered different ones with the keen idea of sharing....they were mashed potatoes and creamed spinach.... the sides were good but I wish they had offered better ones.

For desert we got the bread pudding which isn't very large but if you finished your meal then it will complete the process of filling you up rather easily. 

*****NOTE that you only get one dessert for every two people at your table. I think this is lame and am removing a star because of it seeing as someone eating alone would get one dessert for themselves obviously, so why do they have to become stingy the second someone else arrives???****

As for the drinks we each had one of the wine pairings with the meal and while waiting for the meal she had a sapphire and tonic and I had a grey goose and tonic.

The pre-dinner bread was also amazing...but hey.... I love bread!

Anyway the total bill was just about $150 with a 20% tip. 

The service was great and they let us sit at our table and converse as long as we wanted even after paying or in other words they did not kick us out to usher in more customers and that is a plus in my books.

I would say 4.5 stars but I can't do that so I am going with 4 because I don't think it should quite get a 5....

The petite filet was by far the most delicious piece at our table but everything was of excellent quality.
author: Brandon T.

description:
I ate here last sunday for dine about town, which isn't a bad deal.  That afforded us salad, a 12oz rib eye, and desert for just about thirty-two bucks.

The salad was better than I expected.  The steak is broiled at a very high temperature and served on a sizzling plates.  That was pretty cool, but I did find that the taste wasn't jump-out-of-my-seat spectacular.  We were also served mashed potatoes as a side dish.  Standard, and yummy.

Off the dine about town menu, we also ordered the lobster bisque.  This was actually my first time tasting lobster bisque.  It was creamy with almost a caramel sweet finish, and served with two anemic morsels of lobster.

For desert, it was key lime pie and bread pudding.  The bread pudding was awesome, served hot with a sweet condensed milk and juicy raisins.  The pie, on the other hand, was overpoweringly sweet.  Not recommended.

Thanks to the lobster bisque and a corkage fee, our dinners came out to about 55 bucks a head.  Unfortunately, I was still expecting a little bit more.  And while the service was excellent, the food was just OK.  I could see myself coming back here for dine about town.  Otherwise, I'm not sure if Ruth's Chris is really worth it.
author: Tony L.

description: Hands down the best filet mignon in San Francisco. Great service and good wine list.
author: Mahta P.

description:
Way overrated!  I must be a slow learner, been there 5 times and still haven't learned.  
Service = Actually not bad
Ambiance = best thing about this joint
Food = mediocre, to many other i rather go, but guess slow learner.  Over buttered, lacks flavor and always manage to be slightly overcooked.  take your pick
Price = Among upscale steakhouse, reasonable
Crowd = casual, business, couples, mature, good blend
Worst = the steaks
Meal for two = 120
Final Say = Go elsewhere
author: M C.

description:
I have been to many of the great steakhouses in SF, and Ruth's Chris Steak House takes the [chocolate sin] cake every time.   

I went last night (Friday) without a reservation and we were told it would be a 45 minute wait.  Next time I'll call ahead for sure.  No matter, the bar had two seats open. The bar has full food service, so wait time was now 0, and I was happy to sit with Jose, the bartender.

On opening the menu, I noticed that it had changed.  Its been about 6 months since I've been here, and I was saddened to find out that they removed the Australian Rock Lobster Tail. That dish is incredible. They had replaced my dish with a less expensive Caribbean Lobster Tail, which is not quite the same, but actually works well on the menu.

When you order the appetizers, please order the bbq shrimp. There is a reason its in red bold letters on the menu. Perfectly cooked shrimp nesting in a sauce so dangerously delicious that you will continue to sop up with bread, long after the shrimp are gone.  Sometimes I keep it around for the meal.
 
I ordered the Caribbean lobster tail, which was nothing short of excellent - and its hard to follow the shrimp dish.  I also ordered the Petite Fillet, which was the perfectly medium rare and *insert deep sigh here*.  It cut like butter and just melts in your mouth.  I didnt need to season it. they use just the right amount of salt and pepper, and the steak does the rest. You can order this combo as a Special, and the tail is stuffed with crab meat too. My friend ordered the Special and he just about licked his plate clean.  (under $40 - no kidding)

Sitting at the bar was perfect. You have your waiter right there if you need anything at all. When our table did open up, we opted to remain at the bar rather than move.

I've eaten at Ruth's Chris Steak House in several states, and it has been consistently excellent. Its business casual to dressy, but I've never been turned away for jeans. Presentable is probably the best word. 

I'm sure to be back again and again.
author: J K.

description:
Why is everyone so down on butter?  The filet is awesome and when those Au gratin potatoes hit your sizzling butter filled plate it makes a statement. 
Don't forget your Kleenex because you will cry once you take the first bite.  
Save room for creme brulee....
author: Laurin A.

description:
Simply not very good.

RC, in a nutshell, is the Olive Garden of steak.  If you are the kind of person who thinks the Olive Garden has awesome Italian food, then you're going to love RC.

Terrible, terrible, terrible service.  We had to beg for bread.  Plates are just tossed in front of us.  Our waiter or waitress disappeared for long periods of time.  No one smiles, or gives a rats ass if we lived or died.  Oh, and the hostess scowled at us when we walked in.  Lovely.

Zero presentation on the dishes.  The steaks are just slopped onto a plate.  The sides are no different.  Hey, why do I have to order sides separately, anyway?  For a $35 steak, at the lowest possible end, can't I get a some steamed veggies, maybe a drizzle, a sprig or f**king parsley?!?  No, I can't.

The steaks that are absolutely *drowned* in butter.  I love butter and all, but COME ON!

The place has no class.  I couldn't wait to get the hell out the minute I got there.
author: John L.

description:
sabrinasdad and I had a date night and ended up here.  We ordered two appetizers, one salad, two entrees, two sides, two glasses of wine, one dessert and a cappuchino.  Total with tip - $300.

Yikes pricy.  Luckily for us, we don't go on very many date nights.

Two appetizers:
Crab Stuffed Mushrooms (4) - very big and cheesy.  Lots of crab.  A great gooey start.

Calamari - Note to self (again) do not order calamari here - it is served drizzled (drenched) in sweet chili sauce.

One salad: Ruth's chopped - it is presented as a stack topped with fried onions - I can't tell you what was in it - but good flavor profile.

Entree - We both ordered the "Kobe" wagyu ribeyes.  Very tender - the meat was very tender (can't say that enough).  You can't go wrong with ribeye, especially ribeyes cooked in butter.

Wine - I don't drink but sabrinasdad had whatever Red was recommended with the steak.  He liked it.

Sides - the chef's recommendation was the "hash brown" - it was a crispy potato pancake as big as a plate.  Eh - I felt like eating a loaded baked potato, I should have stuck with my craving.

Broccoli Au Gratin - broccoli covered with cheese.  This was not served with the meal.  After asking, it was eventually brought to the table and removed from the bill.  Nice.

Dessert - Lemon sorbet - to cleanse the palate.

Cappuchino - kept the mister up until the wee hours of the morning.

Very nice.  Valet people very courteous.  

We were in a booth but a large table for 12 was directly in front, ear hustling was at a premium.
author: Sabrinasmom S.

description:
Aside from Fleming's in Newport, I've always had a great experience at Aunt Ruthy's Steak House.  I can call her that now, because I've been so many times to pretty much all of the locations in california and nevada. (Las Vegas on Flamingo is my favorite, they always have crab legs!)  With that, I've decided my words of love for Aunt Ruthy and her delicious steak and crab legs are best described by my good friend and poet, Ludacris............

author: Jamie B.

description:
so i wrote a not so nice review about ruth chris' at walnut creek, about how the service was horrific. I went to ruth chris' in san francisco this time though. Everyone was really nice, thehost was very polite. Our server was JOSH, who was more than fabulous, he checked in every now and then and also was very prompt. THe bussers and foodrunners were also very polite and helpful. SO heres what i got:

Luxurita: its theyre signature margarita with patron silver and remy martin cognac. I thought it was fabulous, a littel on the strong side, but you'll only have to drink one to get a buzz. 

Ceasar Salad: Very good, i love it when places give the whole romaine leaf, its just seems so much more fresh. 

Filet Mignon: I got this Medium Rare ( i know, still mooing). It was amazing, best filet ive ever taken. It was enough to split since it was such a hunk of meat. It was served sizzling and split tableside.

Banana Pie: If you eat at Ruth Chris you MUST GET THE BANANA CREAM PIE. you wont regret it! IT was carmelized and the bananas were still fresh. 

In conclusion, serive was great, food was even better, and atmosphere is very classy. Its a bit dark in there, so i couldnt take a decent pictures, but thats what sets the mood.
author: Heidi M.

description: This is my favorite place steakhouse in SF.  The meat is always cooked to perfection.  I have had the petite filet and the ribeye.  So good!  I can't wait to go back!
author: Ren A.

description:
Oh my god!  how can this not be rated five stars?  Okay, it is a little bit pricey, but well worth it (especially if you can get a well-off relative to pay or get treated for your birthday.) 

One comes here for the steaks and they are well worth the price.  They are are flash cooked, seared and roasted in butter on VERY hot plates and continue to cook at the table.  They are the best steaks I have ever eaten (better than Morton's or even Alexander's.)

The wine list is excellent.  The service is discrete and professional.  They will always get you in, but you might have to eat at the bar.  (The one in LA is also good, the one in SD has its moments, the one on Maui is impeccable, the one in NJ is awesome, you look out over Manhattan, and the one in Dallas is better than the local steak houses.)  

The side dishes are built for sharing and so good that they must be very bad for you (but what the hell, you just ate a 12 oz. steak - creamed spinach is almost health food at that point.)  My kids always want the scalloped potatoes, which are sinfully delicious.  I keep ordering the  mushrooms in the hope they will improve.  

The coffee drinks are superb.  They used to have incredible coffee 'milk-shakes' but they disappeared from the menu quite a few years ago (a New Orleans original recipe - must have got lost in the hurricane.)  The desserts are very good.

I have never had anything but excellent meals at any of these restaurants.  (Okay, the one in SD wasn't that good, but then we had some underage kids with us which probably made a difference...)

Again we had excellent service, showed up at 10:30 and they sat us, and set a table where we asked.  I had an excellent margarita (great wine list) excellent steak - no, the best steak anywhere.  Great sides (I love the creamed spinach.) And the decor is great.  Really love this place.
author: mike r.

description:
Dine About Town 2009:

The 8oz Petit Filet with $3 Bleu Cheese Crust was good.

Everything else (the salad, the mashed potatoes, the key lime pie) was very meh.  The service and decore reminded me of a Spaghetti Factory (noisy, energetic, crowded, and absent-minded).  No need to go here ever again.
author: Tessa M.

description:
I had to update my review because in the past, Ruth's Chris did not offer meals for one price. You would order the steak...and all you got was a steak on a plate. Sides were ordered separately. 
Now they offer a meal which has a soup or salad, the steak and a side, plus a dessert...all for about $50. What a steal! 

This place just got upgraded to 6 stars! =)

----------------
This is by far, the best steakhouse I have ever eaten at. I noticed that other yelper's complained about this place and there is a trend in what cut they ordered...filet mignon. I'm not a fan of that cut so I can't really speak on it.  But what I can speak on is the RIB-EYE. That is the only cut I ever order because it is the tastiest. The butter they melt on the steak makes it taste even better. 

The sides can (and should) be shared. I would suggest ordering one side for every 2 people at first and then order more later if it is not enough. My faves are potatoes au gratin and creamed spinach. Yum! 

I've also had the lobster tail which is very succulent and tender. They give you warm melted butter for dipping (of course) with lemon. 

I went there another time and had a steak that was cooked way too long. And although I ate about half of the steak, when they asked how everything was going, I told them nicely that my steak was a bit overcooked and they happily offered another steak or to remove the steak from the final bill. WOW. Now that is great customer service!

I highly recommend this place to steak and lobster lovers. Make sure to get there early to find parking if you don't want to pay for valet.
author: Jackilyn B.

description: It's a Ruth's Chris. It's exactly what you expect. Not the best steak in the city - but very consistent and very good at what they do.
author: Victor K.

description:
*Dine About Town 2009: Go here for your money's worth!

Best Petit Fliet i've had in my life (the butter on top helps)

cooked to perfection (medium rare as all steaks should be)

Salad, Yum

Dont bother trying the cream of spinach...stick with the mashed potatoes

Chocolate cake...rich and dense...the strawberries make up for the sinfulness of this desert.
author: Gladys D.

description:
Yum! Despite all the $$$ we spent here, we had a great, and delicious time. I loved the sauce on the barbeque shrimp (I was mopping it up with all the bread), the ahi tuna appetizer was tasty, and the onion soup delicious. However, the real star (as it should be) was the steak. It was cooked to perfection, served sizzling in butter and parsley on the plate. I loved the well-seasoned (w/salt and pepper only) crust and juicy inside (we both ordered the filet). It's too bad I was already so full from the appetizers and bread and butter, I couldn't even finish it. I wasn't too big on the sides we ordered (mashed potatoes and spinach a gratin) but it might have been I was too stuffed to enjoy them.

A big plus: yummy, strong cocktails! I really liked my bf's fusion martini (lemon) and my citrus mojito was pretty delicious. We got some good wine (mm get the moscato with dessert). Our server was also super on point and made for a very pleasant experience. 

Overall, would definitely do again for a (very) special treat.
author: Stephanie M.

description:
Two words for you: RIP OFF!! 

I'm glad I went here for Dine About Town because if I had payed full price I would have been severely disappointed and full of remorse that I would want to barf up my food and get a refund. With the DAT menu you get a salad, choice of main course, side, and dessert. Sounds like a good deal (which it is) but there is just nothing exciting about it. So I ordered the stuffed mushroom appetizer and a side of sweet potato mash. Might I add this was shared with the whole table (I'm not that much of a hog.). But I didn't even have wine and my $39.95 DAT bill turned into an $80 contribution. The salad was alright (coulda skipped it), the steak was just a petit fillet drowned in butter, the creamed spinach was ultra rich... drowned in butter, and the bread pudding dessert which was really built up "to die for" was really bland. The stuffed mushrooms were barely stuffed with crab and also again drowned in butter. The sweet potato mash was really good though (sweetened with brown sugar, pecany, and drowned in butter). One of the dessert choices offered was out of stock so the waiter substituted my friend's dessert with THE TINIEST SCOOP OF ICE CREAM ever!!! It might as well been a scoop of butter. On our way out, I swear I saw that the table of two guys next to us had a dish of melted butter on the side for their steaks. So moral of the story is if you want to spend a million dollars on mediocre choices and build your way up to coronary heart disease with butter- go to Ruths Chris.
author: Rachel A.

description:
Although the "happy birthday" confetti is extremely charming, the food is okay but our stomachs were hurting from all the butter when we left. Not too mention the bill...$150 for two without drinks...
Much rather go to House of Prime Rib any day...
author: Diana D.

description:
My sister invited my parents and I to Ruth's Chris to celebrate my parents' anniversary.  Reservations were made and it's a good thing that they were.  We arrived at the restaurant a few minutes late and it was packed.  People were waiting at the bar and in the lobby area to be seated.  I'm guessing they either arrived early for their reservations or they were walk-ins.  We didn't have to wait long to be seated; our table was being cleared off when we arrived.  Yay!  No long wait for the steak.

Service was excellent.  Sabrina was our server and she was on top of everything.  She recommended the appropriate wine pairings for our meal.  

I had the house salad.  I enjoyed the dressing, but they could use different vegetables and replace the iceberg lettuce.

The piece(s) de resistance were the mouthwatering rib eye and the creme de pot!  

Unfortunately, the first rib eye I received was a bit overcooked for my liking; however, they quickly replaced it.  The second steak was cooked perfectly, but it was a bit more grisly than the first.  Nevertheless, I enjoyed the mouthwatering bites of meat and the herbed butter topping was yummy!

For dessert, we ordered creme brulee and the creme de pot.  I absolutely loved the ceme de pot!  So much, that I was oohhing and ahhing about it that Sabrina was kind enough to bring me another...  on the house.  

I can't wait to indulge once again!  Hopefully, sooner rather than later.
author: Annalynn C.

description:
Porterhouse For Two

NO - I didn't eat it all by myself....tempting as it had been though, I digress I had to leave room for the wine. ;D

The meat was perfect......I would almost want to say it was "pure" in a way. Something just screams pure...or perhaps it was her screaming at me to not eat it all. I don't remember, I was that enamored by the food. The wine selection was great, I'm still perfecting my palate of course...gives me an excuse to be ignorant of all the rules and enjoy what I enjoy. lmao 

The ambiance is nice and cozy, kind of old school if you will. I love the wood treatment. The staff was very kind and helpful...and given the particular occasion they were overwhelmingly considerate and discreet. Perhaps discreet is a bad use of the word.....let's just say they gave us our privacy as much as can be given in such a cozy place. On a side note, the lacerations from her knife will heal in time. See...the food was that great that we'd fight almost to the death over the last bite. Watch out!
author: John-Michael C.

description:
*3.5 stars*

John T., Mimi and I took Hung here for his birthday (and because none of us had eaten here before).  The four of us shared: the crab stuffed mushrooms (too peppery for me), seared ahi tuna (good sauce), the ribeye with bone (called the cowboy), the ribeye without the bone (both pieces of meat medium rare), potatoes lyonnaise (eh - nothing special and just tasted like fries), and the steamed asparagus.  John got a glass of really good red wine (I didn't catch the name) and I got a pom martini (it was delish!).  I thought the food was only ok.  While the portions are large, I was not impressed with the flavors.  Mimi likes the ribeye with the bone in it because she liked how fatty it was.  John liked the one without the bone because he said it had a more pronounced beef flavor.  You should pass on the two sides we ordered.

What we all agreed on was the bread they brought out.  It was so so good!  I could eat that all day.  What was weird, though, was how the first loaf came out hot and crunchy, but as each loaf kept coming out (Meems loves bread), they were considerably colder and less crispy.  Maybe not enough time in the oven to warm up because we were chowing through them so fast?  Ridiculous.  Also, the decor was really nice.  We saw a lot of people out for a "special" evening.
author: Lynnie P.

description: Good steak but not the best. You can get good steak anywhere else with the price you pay here, just wait for dine around town and come here to eat instead.
author: Sandy L.

description:
I came here for Dine About Town. $34.95 for a salad, steak, side dish, and dessert. How can anyone resist? 

We got there 30 minutes early so we could have a drink at the bar before dinner. One drink turned into two drinks, and we brought two bottles of wine to share between four people... so you can imagine how the night turned out. 

I got their 8 oz. filet mignon medium rare with a side of creamed spinach and added six shrimp for $12. The steaks were served on 500 degree plates and drowned in butter. I almost burned myself on the plate but the meat smelled and tasted sooooo good! Even when I was full I wanted to eat all the delicious smelling steaks that were coming out. I thought their salad and dessert were both okay, nothing too special. 

They had really good service and the waitress was really nice and attentive even though we were ordering off the Dine About Town menu. You also have to ask for the menu separately.

I am definitely coming back for the next Dine About Town!
author: Diana C.

description:
Okay, laugh if you must...that's right...mock me...I love this place.  In fact, I have loved every Ruths Chris at which I have dined.  I love their consistency.  I love that I know my steak will be delicious....mouth wateringly delicious....buttery....savory....scrumptious.  I LOVE RED MEAT!!!!  I simply can't get enough.

I also love, love, love their creme brulee....the crispy top, the creamy center...the warm (and never cold or chilled) creamy center....mmmmm....luscious!  I would make sweet love to that creme brulee if I could....really, I would.

The ambiance is....well....its upscale steakhouse ambiance, and the bill reflects this, but oooooohhhhh, it is such good sex...um...I mean food.

They are also really cool about not having a reservation on a weekend.  It is nice that they are willing to accommodate my last minute I-have-to-eat-at-Ruths-Chris-now cravings and not "we're way too uber hip and cool for you NOT to make a reservation".  There is no pretension here.  They actually seem to be appreciative of your business....such a novel idea.

The service has always been great at any Ruths Chris.  Its always nice to have good service....but I go there for the filet mignon and creme brulee~
author: s r.

description:
My "special friend" and I tried the dine about town deal here, it was roughly $31/person excluding tax and tip. After leaving with a full stomach, I was one happy person. The rib eye was nice and tender, but the filet mignon... mmm... it was like tasting a bite of heaven. Just thinking about that part of the cow makes me drool! 

I would definitely recommend trying out the dine about town deal they have annually. (You save a lot of money too.)

Plus our waiter was also very nice and accomodating. You know how it is, sometimes a restaurant will have good food, but the horrible waiter just makes you not wanna spend money at that place ever again.
author: Ede S.

description:
Five stars for the ribeye, without a doubt!

-1/2 star for having to share a dessert for the DAT menu
-1star for seating us at the worst table in the restaurant when it's 5:30 and there's a perfectly good booth just 2 steps away. I really hate being treated like I'm stupid just because me and the BF look young. I'm not an idiot. I know that that's the worst table in the room and you're seating us here because the hostess sized us up as soon as we walked in and thought that she could get away with seating us at a crappy table and save the booth for a "big tipper"

Anyway...there's not much that I can say about the food that hasn't been said already. It's a really good steak, but it's really expensive and all the sides come a la carte which doesn't help the pocketbook much. For the money, House of Prime Rib is a much better deal when you need a red meat fix.
author: Melanie V.

description:
Came here without a reservation on a Saturday night and no surprise it was PACKED! 

The good news is that I walked to the bar and found an empty seat and was able to enjoy the same delicious dinner (had I made a reservation) with very good service.

I keep my order simple at Ruth's Chris: steak and red wine. That's all I need because 1) the prices and 2) the steak is so amazing that I don't need any filler food.
author: Minnie F.

description:
Beef, err ... correction BUTTER, that's what's for dinner.  I came here with friends for Dine About Town after reading great reviews about Ruths'.  What I didn't expect was a butter overload.  If you like your red meat and sides drenched in butter, this is the place for you.  

Here's the rundown: 

The first course of salad was pretty standard fare, nothing special.  The presentation gave the appearance that there was a little more effort involved in preparation than just scooping pre-made salad onto a plate.  

Then came the rib-eye steaks, which were all swimming in a pool of butter.  A little butter may accentuate the taste of the meat, but this was just overkill.  The amount of butter they used pretty much overpowered the flavor and the natural juices of the meat.  (To be fair, I found out afterwards that you can request your steak without butter.  It would have been nice if the waiter pointed that out while we were ordering.)  The sides, creamed spinach and potatoes au gratin, were also loaded with a buttery taste and the latter undercooked and slightly crunchy.  

The Key Lime Pie desert, decent, but it tasted like something I could have gotten at any ordinary bakery.

Simply put: Ruth's came up short.  While an excellent value for Dine About Town, quality trumps value any day.  I was expecting more from an establishment of this caliber.  For the same price as Ruth's regular menu, I recommend that you head down the street to Bobo's and enjoy a much more satisfying steak dinner.  Bobo's has same comfy leather booths, is a little less uppity and they even have a clown on the wall that will share a laugh with you.  That is, after you down one or two drinks.
author: Wei K.

description:
I would give the service and the Sweet Potato Casserole five stars.  But...I mean....70 bucks for my dinner?  I can make steak as good as that, and it wouldn't even have to be in the same room as that much butter.

The asparagus was absolutely forgettable.  The Ruth's Chop salad was good.  Although painful, as I had just bitten my lip two days before and it was really sore.  That tangy dressing was like molten lava on my lip.

And you know - my steak was overdone.  Just around the edges, but still.  For 45 bucks just for the steak, you'd think it would be perfect.

I know, I know.  It's just a chain.  

But those sweet potatoes.  Five stars, sister.  It was like having pie as a side dish.  Which, yeah, that's a good idea.
author: Jeney P.

description:
Disappointing! What a waste of a hundred bucks. :x There are a ton of better steakhouses in the city than this one.

The only good thing I can say about Ruth's Chris is the impeccable service. Our waiter was helpful and personable. The manager came by in the middle of our meal just to see how we were doing. We also used 4 forms of payment and did not get a single dirty look. ha.

Otherwise, the steak itself was bland, though our waitor told us that the beef is so good we won't need any thing to top it (oh so wrong). We were also told the hash browns are fantastic... but it was only so-so.

I'd skip Ruth's Chris if you're not into spending money on mediocre food.
author: Han C.

description:
You want a big juicy steak. Maybe you want some potatoes with it. Maybe you don't. Maybe you wanted those garlic mushrooms instead. Oh, and you want a big glass of red wine to throw down with it. You want your steak cooked as you ordered it, and you want to know that it might cause you some heart issues down the line (see the description of butter use).
 You will pay generously, and be treated decently by the staff. Sometimes this is what you need. There's no specific ambience, there's nothing terribly unique, but you can hear yourself talking to your dinner companion, and it does feel like a restaurant.
author: Sadie R.

description:
My boyfriend and I went here to celebrate our 5 month anniversary.

Street parking wasnt really an option.. but luckily they have a parking garage ($10 flat rate) or you can have valet park it for $10 as well.

Once inside we were seated immediately (we had reservations) and the waiters/waitresses were attentive in serving us bread, water refills and cleaning up our dishes.

We ordered Calamari as an appetizer, which was DELICIOUS. It had a sweet sauce with (I believe) bell peppers. YUM! For entrees, the boyfriend order NY strip and steak fries, and I had the petite filet and shrimp with a caesar salad. I LOVED the food I had (and I think the boyfriend did as well). 

PROBLEMS and the reason why Im giving 4 stars instead of 5:
- I personally think that the prices for the steak was kinda high for the portion you receive
- Our waitress took awhile to realize that we had no ordered yet and had been sitting there for awhile, waiting..

The sad thing was, she was gonna surprise us with a candle and stuff on our dessert but I felt sick and couldnt stand to sit through the dessert portion of our meal, which kinda sucked =(

But all-in-all, this place was great! It has a very intimate setting =] I'd definitely go again.. but probably not in SF. It's kinda out of the way for me.
author: L. C.

description:
went back for yet another B-day. seemed more $$ than last time (and the time before and before and before... you get the idea.) and the HUB musta told them that it was my birthday cause there was "HAPPY BIRTHDAY" GLITTER SPRINKLED ON THE TABLE. 

*****GASP**** 

If I wanted to go to Chuck E Chez for my birthday, I woulda. 

But as always, butter soaked filet does not disappoint.
author: nicole w.

description:
I've dined at all the major chain steakhouses which serve Prime steaks, including Morton's, Smith & Wollensky, The Palm, Shula's and of course, Ruth's Chris.  One thing that can be said of all these chain restaurants is that they are consistent, whether you are dining at The Palm in Mexico City, New York City or Las Vegas or at Ruth's Chris in Orlando or Cabo San Lucas.

They are all gimmicky to some extent, Morton's brings out raw slabs of beef for viewing, Ruth's Chris has the sizzling butter, The Palm has drawings of locals and cartoons on its walls, Smith & Wollensky for its older, gruff waiters, but of all these restaurant chains, Ruth Fertels, Ruth's Chris Steak House is the best of the lot.

Prices at all of these restaurants are in the same range as is the grade of beef used, Prime, so how are they different, besides the gimmicks? I've found that the preparation of Ruth's Chris steaks wins hands down.  

I've dined at 30+ different Ruth's Chris over the past 18 or so years and can honestly say that of all the steak restaurants, including independent steak restaurants, Ruth's is my favorite, and I am a pretty adamant chain restaurant hater.  In fact, our visits to Ruth's Chris started before they offered steak knives, that is how tender the steak is.  When steak knives were introduced years later we were shipped a set to let us know that they now provided steak knives for ones dining pleasure.  Steaks are seared cooked at 1800 degrees and with the exception of a few occasions, they have always been cooked to perfection, not bad after nearly 100 visits to this palace of beef.

Yes, the prices can be somewhat high, but you are dining on Prime grade beef, not Choice, or worse "Good or Better" grade.  This is not The Sizzler and one should be prepared to have to order each dish individually, such as sides, like the delicious Potatoes Au Gratin, full of cream and oozing with cheese.  Steaks are served nearly floating in butter, so this is not a place to have dinner at if you are on a diet either.  

The service at the San Francisco location is pretty consistent and cordial.  There are occasional specials as well, both on the menu and specially priced dinner combinations.  This particular location tends to attract the convention and tourist crowd, as I suspect that the locals head over to Lark Creek Steak at the SF Center, or other local steak houses, such as Harris'.

The banana cream pie is wonderful, but it is enough for two people to share, a must have, even if you are full.
author: Rafael R.

description:
I guess my experiences at this chain in Chicago and Boston have raised my expectations. I eat pretty much the same meals whenever I go to a Ruth Chris. For lunch I have a rare burger, for dinner I order the large filet rare and au poivre, with lyonnaise potatoes and a creamed spinach. I usually get the gumbo or a salad for a starter. The steak meal described here is what I had this visit. So all things being equal, this place was not as good. With dozens of counter examples of this exact meal this was just not up to snuff. Steak was cooked  to order, the sauce and potatoes were off a bit and the spinach was just fair. The interior is really dated, they could pick up a star or two on a remodel. Service was a tad slow but friendly.  At these prices, service, food and atmosphere should be better.

* Dingy room in dire need of an update
* Kitchen staff may need a refresher course or R-C boot camp.
* Some unnamed Raiders Rookie was going in when we were leaving, or so the doorman said.
author: Sean M.

description:
$60 steak a la carte? Sure, if you're made of money. I've been here several times and as much as the service is good and the steak arrives with sizzling butter, it's a bit too expensive for my taste!

The steaks are pretty good. I would recommend this place for a special occasion.
author: C. T.

description:
This should have been a five stars restaurant because of their friendly and professional workers. A place where you should be able to fully enjoy your celebration... I arrived one hour earlier than my reservation and was seated within ten minutes. It is obvious that they know my time is very valuable. My wine was served by Tim although I kept calling him Ted. Tim is a professional and very entertaining. I gave him a star just because I enjoyed the service. Oh but he did missed the stuffed mushroom...The filet and rib-eye were cooked to what I had expected from this restaurant nothing less would have been acceptable from a place like Ruth's and the main course was served  as desired (on-time!!!) I did not finished what I order so I wanted to take the leftovers home to enjoy in front of Yelp. I took off one star because one of the bus-boy-man-person wanted to embarrassed my guess by asking if she really wanted to take the bread home. Years ago... i was only 15 years old. Working as a bus-boy, the first thing I was trained to say is YES politely. Now you have to say the YES word with friendliness and with heart...it is so much more work now...
And Ruth's Brulee vs. M-hotel Las Vegas style Brulee... M-hotel Win... it is what it is...
author: JL J.

description: People said that the steak was the best, for me...eeeeeeee...it was OK. I mean, I am not a big fan of steaks anyways. I ordered a bowl of crab soup and expected it to be warm but it was super cold. I think they put it in fridge right before serving. However, service was excellent; they made an effort putting roses on the table knowing that it was a special day for us. :)
author: Vinchia O.

description:
My friends and I came here during the week of Dine About Town.

The first great thing about Ruth's Chris is that they offer valet parking. Yes, you still have to pay for it, but it sure beats driving around and around on an empty stomach that's angrily groaning "meaAattt.. MEaaTt.." at every stoplight and stop sign.

Once we stepped into the restaurant, it was super packed. I'm not sure how the wait is when it's not DAT week, but it took us an extra 45min to be seated, even with a reservation. Luckily, our friend had gotten there a little early and we were able to squeeze in with him at the bar. We ordered a few drinks to kill some time. The two boys got their Jack and Cokes, while I, normally a Henny-neat girl, decided to try something new. The bartender recommended the Orange Mojito, which at first I was kinda iffy about, because everyone knows I only drink dark liquor and I especially dislike drinks that have too many flavors mixed in - they sound cool and fancy, but usually taste gross. So I asked if he preferred the Orange Mojito over a plain Mo- I didn't get to finish because "Orange" came out of his mouth without hesitation. I was sold. And lordy.. that was the best mojito I've ever had. I honestly have cravings for it to this day. I've scoured happy hour to happy hour in search of anything comparable, but to no avail.

Luckily, we were then seated soon after, because I wanted to be coherent enough to taste the actual dinner portion of our visit. The three of us looked over the DAT menu, and since I had already done my research before going, I decided on the 8oz Petite Filet - medium rare, with no extra funny business (sauces and such). Like my drinks, I like my beef unadulterated, its flavor as close to its purest form. The two boys, being boys, decided to upgrade from the 8oz Petite FIlet to the 16oz Ribeye - "Mo' Meat, Mo' Betta"

After we ordered, we started off with Bread and the Steak House Salad. The bread was warm, soft, and fluffy. SO GOOD. I think ate a whole roll myself. The salad wasn't really memorable but it allowed my stomach to warm-up for the main meat attraction.

When our entrees arrived, it was like a symphony of sizzle, a Mozart of meat, just glorious gloriousness. I had to refrain from my usual cavewoman meat-eating tactics, and remind myself that tonight, I was a lady.

I took my first bite of the filet and moaned. No joke; a slow motion, eyes closed, head back, shoulders slumped, hands falling, throaty, erotic moan. It was absolutely sublime. The only word I could think of to describe the meat: Butter.

[After a cold shower..] So now that I've just relived that first-bite memory, I honestly barely remember the end of the meal. Something about chocolate? I don't know. Read someone else's review if you want to know about the dessert.
author: Jackie L.

description:
i went here a few months ago.  haven't been there for about 8 years.  i grew up in the city and live real close.  i'm going to keep it short.  it was good 8 years ago i believe.  this time most horrible piece of kobe steak ever.  how dare they try to charge $69 for that piece of *&*%!!!  i told the manager and he took it off the bill, i said don't take it off charge me double so you guys can find real kobe.  i said i rather go sizzler's for $8.99 and get a top sirlion and nonstop fried shrimp.  and that's what me and a buddy from that dinner did for lunch the following wknd.  never going to ruth chris for steak again.  my friends had rib eye and filets which were pretty crap as well.

go to harris or bobo's - the best
author: Kevin L.

description: u hear ruth chris and u think over rated but i have celebrated many bdays here either for myself or for a friend.  Their rib eye my favorite part of the cow is amazing, melts in your mouth with  the sizzling buttery taste.  Their sides sweet potato casserole is amazing, its a dessert in itself but their creme brule is silky smooth and scrumptous.  Waiters are friendly depending on who u get.  But the food, top steak house for me.
author: kini m.

description:
A full five stars for a place that exceeded my expectations and delivered a fantastic meal.

Came in hear for the first night of Dine About Town, so the fixed price dinner was $35. Here's a great suggestion - bring your own wine, and pay the corkage of $15. As we had a party of six, we prenegotiated to bring six bottles and pay corkage for only two - how freaking cool is that?

Had the 12oz Ribeye - it was amazing. One of the best steaks I have ever had. Side of mash potatoes, a jack and coke and bread pudding and walked out  full and $65 lighter.

That's a great deal for a great night.
author: Joseph T.

description: Overrated.  Salty, charred steak and we asked for medium rare.   Not good at all.  Typical chain restaurant quality food. Not worth the price.
author: Bayarea K.

description: Ruth's Chris is the best steak house ever!  I'm a big meat lover and have been to many steak houses but this still has to be my favorite place to eat.  The fillet minon *mediam rare* just melts in the mouth.  It has the butter sauce that adds a special touch to it.  You can even ask for extra butter sauce and they give it to you with a little candle to keep it melted.  Their service is great and ambiance is perfect for a romantic meal!
author: Jenny H.

description:
Meat and butter. Need I say more?

The ribeye is superb here. I would skip any salads and apps...and just order the rib eye. hehe. Who needs veggies when there is meat and butter on a 500 degree plate? 

The staff is friendly and asked how I was doing as they escorted us to our table. They brought our fries when we were already half-way done with our steaks...not very cool, but I guess we were too focused on devouring our rib-eyes. The wine selection is ok, I'm not sure if the waiter knew what he was recommending. The desserts are not that great...especially after having a superb piece of steak!
author: Vanessa W.

description:
The boyfriend took me here for our 1-month Anniversary Dinner.  We had a 7:45pm reservation and were seated promptly at a booth when we arrived.  I loved the service, there's always a wait staff available; all very attentive, helpful and friendly.  I felt really welcomed and comfortable.  

For starters, we shared some ahi tuna -- seared with a spicy kick, and grilled scallops -- nothing special, I liked the garnish more than the scallop itself, but to be fair, I've never liked scallops... ever...  We also had a bottle of wine, Acacia 2005 Pinot Noir, went well with all the food; smooth finish.  

Ian had the New York Strip (USDA Prime cut -- a full-bodied texture that is slightly firmer than a rib eye) with a baked potato.  He was disappointed, not as good of a cut that he was expecting.  I think he still enjoyed it though.  Being a pescetarian, I had the Chef's fish special, Alaskan Wild Salmon, cooked to perfection with three grilled-jumbo prawns on a bed of spinach.  I also had a side of mashed potatoes with a hint of garlic.  Yumm...  It was delicious :-)!

For dessert, we had the cheesecake -- homemade, creamy  and served with fresh berries.  Ian picked it.  I would have personally ordered the Chocolate Sin Cake or Warm Apple Crumb Tart.  Cheesecake tasted like an ordinary cheesecake... 'nuff said.  I enjoyed sipping my glass of Cockborn Port -- slightly sweet, flavorful.   Ian had a different kind of Port wine, it was light and tasted like Whiskey... Yuck -- I don't like.

Atmosphere is nice, but I think it's a bit pricey -- we could have eaten someplace better for $250.  Nonetheless, I had a wonderful time.  Thanks Ian :-)!
author: Celeste M.

description:
Believe it or not, I had never been to a Ruth Chris' steakhouse before! I had only heard of their legendary big-as-your-head cuts of meat, sizzling with brown butter and evoking many oohs and ahhs from the patrons ordering them. Naturally, it was to my delight when my boyfriend suggested we have dinner there.

We started the night off right with champagne for him and a white peach Bellini for me. After we were seated, we were served one of my favorite parts of the meal: the bread and butter. Why b&b you ask? Because I'm a butter snob. Seriously. To me, there is absolutely nothing more delicious than a thick creamy slab of French butter on soft, warm bread. Heaven. The butter test is a very crucial part of my judgement of all the fine dining I do.

After the butter of course came more champagne, which my boyfriend intelligently brought himself and coughed up the $25 corkage fee. Ouch, but whatever. Our appetizers included BBQed shrimp and lobster bisque. Both were excellent, although I wish they would have thrown us at least 2 more shrimp for what they charged for them. The lobster bisque was nice and smooth with lots of lobster bits in it. Manifique.

My bf got a rib eye, myself the filet minon, and we shared a order of potatoes au gratin. Both were fantastic, especially mine because it was slathered with lots of bernaise sauce. It cut like butter. Wow. I felt so spoiled. The gratin was good, but was on the heavier side and it needed salt and pepper, but that's okay. After I saw the huge baked potato and the broccoli gratin the people next to us had ordered, I wished that's what we had gotten. Too bad my bf won't touch broccoli. It's okay, I always end up envying my nieghor's food whenever I go out to eat anyways. It's to be expected from this little filly.

We rounded out the meal with fresh berries in sweet cream which was wonderful! Imagine the best vanilla pudding you've ever had in your life with a bunch of berries tossed in. After all that meat, fat, and butter, you couldn't pay me to eat chocolate. We also ordered a hot toddy which they made SUPER strong. After polishing off the bottle of champagne, it did us good, although I can never quite get used to the taste of brandy.

This moring we both woke up feeling like we had a hangover from all the good food/meat/butter we ate. Not to mention, our breakfast of leftovers was pretty fabulous this morning. Overall, it's a a great place for steaks if you got the $$$$ or so to spare.
author: Rosie B.

description:
We went for DAT and the service was friendly and complete... The only problem was the butter. I believe in butter, as a spread, as something that gives you a bit of extra flavor, but Ruth's really took that to the next level. I'd heard that they cook their steaks in butter and I thought I would love it, but I found it a bit much.

I got the blue cheese crust and that was quite good, and if I ever go here again, I will ask for that and my steak sans butter (which is an option, as well as the "extra butter" option)
author: christine l.

description:
I was here last weekend for DAT, which is pretty worth it considering the filet mignon is normally about $35 and the ribeye is about $43 alone on the menu.  

My whole party agreed that the steaks were cooked to perfection but I can't say there was much flavor to it. The meal left a few of us feeling pretty sick...actually more like feeling like our arteries just got clogged. The steaks came out smothered in butter!  Even the mashed potatoes and creamy spinach sides were oozing with butter.  I was forewarned by all the yelpers commenting about the amount of butter this place uses but it still caught me by surprise! The salad was your ordinary salad but the vinegarette was very yummy! To end the meal, I had the key lime pie, which was one of the better key lime pies I've had. The tartness was just the right amount. I had some of my bf's bread pudding too and that was very good. But because of the amount of butter used, I'm minusing one star.

And, I'm minusing two stars due to our incompetent waitress. Here's a few of the many things that happened: To get some straws, we had to ask three separate people (manager was the one that finally got us the straws)! Our waitress was really reluctant to let some of us change the dressing on the salad. For some reason she kept insisting we keep the vinegarette since it was the standard dressing (not sure why that really matters b/c it's not like they pre-mixed the dressing in the salad!)  Also, while she was taking our order, we asked for NO butter on the steaks..what did we get? Butter on the steaks AND two sides of melted butter on top of butter warmers!! I didn't know "no butter" translated to "extra butter".  I figure that for the amount of money I pay, the service should have been better than what we received. I was just completely annoyed of their service the entire night.

Overall, would I come back here? Most likely not.
author: Sylvia H.

description:
I was very pleased with my ribeye and didn't mind the butter .. actually loved it. Extremely flavorful. My best friend planned on getting the filet but changed his mind and got the ribeye as well ... lucky for him! We both felt dizzy afterwards from the protein overload .. so be prepared.

We both asked for rare knowing that the hot plate will continue to cook the steak, and we were right. It ended up as a perfect medium rare steak (albeit a tiny bit bloody but oh so yummy).

The mashed potatoes were good and the hash brown needed ketchup (the edges were overcooked and too crispy/dry). We were so stuffed that we barely had any room for dessert, but the key lime pie was so fantastic. It was very light and fluffy, and I loved the graham cracker crust.

I didn't finish my steak but reheated it in the microwave at work the next day. IT WAS STILL FREAKING GOOD. I let my coworkers try and they agreed.

Oh, BTW, this was a DAT meal so the price was a steal .. let's hope Ruth's Chris participates this summer.

Update: wtf ... I just checked their current menu, and they don't serve key lime pie ... is this a mistake? was it just a DAT dessert? please say it aint so.
author: Anvy A.

description:
Steak?  Butter?  Steak in LOTS of butter?? That's a winner right there.

My whole life I've never had a taste for meat.  I was and still am for the most part, a fruit and veggies girl.  But ever since I started law school a year and a half ago I've not only enjoyed eating steak, but I actually crave it!  Talk about developing a taste for blood.  

The first time I went to Ruth's Chris was in Honolulu, HI, and was EVEN better than the SF location.  But I think it's just because of the amazingly wonderful wait-staff that they have in Hawaii.  The past 2 years I've gone to Ruth's Chris for dine about town.  It's a great deal for an salad, steak, side, and dessert.  The food is MORE than enough and both times I've taken half the steak and half the side home to my boyfriend.  Their mashed potatoes are really delicious and a perfect complement for the buttery steak.  The prime rib steak....*gasp*....so good.  I LOVE when it first comes out, sizzling in the butter on the hot plate, screaming for me to take that first delectable bite.  We always end up spending a lot because we get wine, but it's so worth that once a year experience.

Can't wait for next year!!!
author: Cindy K.

description: Went here on Valentine's day with my boyfriend and 2 other couples. I made the reservation a month in advance. We arrived about 10 min early to reservation and it took about 30-35 min to get seated. It was kind of annoying but we were patient. Our server was really knowledgeable and friendly and let me sample different wines to see what I like. For my order I did the Ruth chris special I think, I cant really remember but basically it was a starter (soup) , appetizer (mashed potatoes) main course (6oz petite filet), and dessert (chocolate something basically like a big ass reeses pieces) for about $49 ish. I was already full by the time I got my dessert. Everything was delicious and I also tried my bf's 12 oz rib eye (YUM). The steaks here are slowly roasted and seasoned with salt pepper and garlic butter (i think). So you dont need a1 steak sauce lol and asking for one may be frowned upon. But the meat was perfectly seasoned and cooked. I would like to come back here again to get my own 12 oz rib eye.
author: Brigitte M.

description:
This is still my reigning favourite steak house around.  I'm guessing it's because of the abundant amounts of melted butter on my rib eye cooked to perfection.  I have yet to be disappointed at this particular branch.  Funnily enough, I didn't like one of the Vegas branches I tried.

Try as I might, I still haven't found anywhere close to the fresh farm experience of free range freshly aged and slaughtered home raise steer.  I know it sounds brutal but I'm an omnivore and there are many things underneath me in the food chain.  Talking about chains, I can't bring myself to give this place five stars solely because it's part of a vast restaurant chain.  But I still go back semi-regularly.
author: Chris C.

description:
I've been here twice, always on great dates so perhaps I'm a bit biased. I'm also from Colorado so I know what a real steak is supposed to taste like and when you slather, no BATHE it in butter it's AWESOME! I am a medium-rare steak kind of girl. Those of you who get medium to well done  don't know what you're missing out on. Tsk Tsk. It's too tough and not juicy enough by then! Trust me...don't worry about germs . Get it medium-rare, pinkish-red on the inside. Okay..sorry. I'll get of my cowgirl high-horse. 

Back to the review, I suggest you get a steak...beyond that everything else is just so so. But if you come to a steakhouse for the veggies you're crazy in the first place. Oh, and don't forget to stuff your face with the bread you give you...good lordy. The service has been awesome both times I was there and so was the wine and cocktails. I'd go anyday. If you want to try it out please take me! :)
author: Cassy R.

description:
It's a little strange to think of this place as a chain restaurant.  I can't really imagine one of these at the food court.  But if I were the world's most decadent shopping mall I would have one of them in my food court.

The food ain't cheap, but it's good.  The meat was definitely in a different league than the sides.  But to be honest, I made a mean Costco tri tip in my own oven for 15 bucks that could compete with the Porterhouse/filet mignon we got at Ruth's Chris.  So it's a bit hard to find the additional $70 in value.  One place to look could be the ambiance of the place and the service.  Everything is old boy's clubby mahogany and rich.  The service was good and the people were friendly.

When I'm really rich, I can see myself making a lot of trips to this place.
author: Dan C.

description:
I give Ruth's Chris 3 stars because I have been to other steakhouses and this location, although good, pales in comparison to what you can get for your money elsewhere.  The service was earnest, we could tell the guy was really trying, but he was not a real pro.  If you've ever had a professional server, you know what I'm talking about.  He wasn't able to give us answers to our questions beyond what the manual said, it was basically 1 or 2 sentences and we were looking for more detail.  

The tomato mozzarella salad was good, although it could have used more cheese (especially considering it cost $16, the most expensive tomato/mozzarella I've ever had).  The cowboy rib eye was too thin for my taste and the plate was too small to really maneuver anything.  I also wonder why a steakhouse that supposedly serves the most flavorful beef available in the U.S. , prime, would have to resort to piling on a half cup of butter to make it taste good.  Outback does that too, by the way.  

The asparagus was cooked perfectly but I like a little seasoning, this only came with a hollandaise sauce on the side.  The real standout of the meal was the sweet potato casserole which was covered in a pecan crust.  It was fantastic, I plan on trying to recreate it at Thanksgiving.

Overall, try Ruth's Chris if you must, you will certainly get a great meal but if you want a truly outstanding steakhouse experience from a national chain, try The Capital Grille or The Grill on the Alley.
author: Ryan J.

description:
Like the last 1000 reviews we went here for DAT on a Thursday night.  I don't know what its like on a normal night but we had to wait 40 minutes for our reservation.  I felt like I was in a Seinfeld episode.  I don't make a reservation to wait.  I make a reservation to be seated.

Yeah the meat is cooked with butter and yeah it's served to you on a 500 degree plate.  I was pleased with the quality of my filet (be warned - what they consider medium-rare here practically MOOs).  You can definitely tell the meat is good quality.  The spinach and mashed potatoes weren't super exciting.  I was a little disappointed in the key lime pie (my mom's is WAY better).  The wine list is extensive although if you're only looking to get a glass your choices are somewhat limited.  The service was great, and even though she was running around like a chicken (or cow) with her head cut off, our server did a nice job and was attentive.

I guess there's 111 of these around the country now and they're looking to put one in downtown San Jose.  And if you have a conscience you might question giving them your patronage after they moved their HQ permanently out of New Orleans right after Katrina.  All in all it was good, nothing too special or exciting.  I doubt I'd come back and pay full price.
author: Jaime C.

description:
Went to dinner with the bf and ordered from the DAT menu. I got the fillet and he got the ribeye. They were both seasoned well and tasted delicious, but the fillet especially, was just an amazing pillowly piece of meaty goodness. The garlic mashed potato had the right fluffy texture and wasn't too garlicy. The creamed spinach was just okay. I would probably order two garlic mashed potato instead of one of each next time, but I never had creamed spinach, so I had to try it out. The desserts were excellent also. It was really good meal for the price, but I would not go for full price. 

The only downside is that after a meal, you would probably have to run 5 miles just to burn off the delicious butter that was inhaled with every bite of your food. Other than that, yummmmyy. 

Dress: not as formal as the website suggests, girls- jeans are okay with nice top and heels. men- the usual sweater over nice dress shirt and slacks.
author: Tiffany T.

description:
Ruth's is a nice place to go with nice service, but I really don't see all the hype. At the end I wasn't satisfied with the steak for the price I paid. It is doused in butter for flavoring. I also think my steak (Rib-eye) was about 50% fat. I think I might have been able to send it back to the kitchen but I hate being a pain. My girlfriend had better luck with hers. I should also mention that I've been to different Ruth's Chris twice before and had much better steaks there. 

Parking was easy, I paid for valet parking and they were awesome. However I can never really talk poorly about valet people as I am one myself. 

Oh, and if you do end up coming here, make reservations, as I did.

In the end, I don't think I'll be coming to this particular location again. The next time I want an expensive steak I'll try somewhere else.
author: Aaron M.

description:
Went formy first Dine About Town a couple years ago after just moving to the US, man was I happy to be here after one phat meal.  I do like House of Prime Rib, I do love my girl Nicole's homemade prime rib and I dont do such a bad job with a chunk of beef myself but this has to be my favorite steak in the US to date. For reals. 

Did I go here for a healthy eating experience, hell no. Did I get an awesome meal yes. Steak was so damn hot on arrival, seriously impressive, perfectly cooked, wonderful blend of butter and herbs, good sides and a great (but pricey) winelist.

The atmosphere is not as relaxed as HOPR and feels older and colder fo shizzle but that's cool, I'm happy to bring down the average customer age some for the experience of their steaks! Gimme more. Beef, not heart attacks ok.
author: Steve S.

description:
One of my more memorable nights in San Francisco involved Ruth's Chris Steak House.

While still attending school, my roommate and I decided not to wallow in self pity, sitting in front of the television all night, get up, get dressed and go to a nice dinner.

He made a last minute reservations, so we got right in.

Without intending to, we ended up with "the perfect check".  This means we ordered cocktails, appetizers, wine, entrees, sides, desserts and coffee.  What a goal for a server.  Who was great, btw.  What a gem, she was.  The roommate was drooling, haha.

The food was great, but seriously, if you can't cook a Filet correctly in a steakhouse, you shouldn't be working there.
