The highlight of the evening for us were the desserts.  I ordered something chocolate and Vince ordered the most delicious apple crisp ever.  Seriously, I think we could have died right there after eating it (I quickly put the chocolate aside and helped him with the apple crisp).

After we rolled home, full, but $300 lighter, I preceded to throw it all up.  I know, I know that's gross, what a waste, etc.  It was all the richness of what we ordered and ate and drank.  To this day, Vince still teases me about it, but I'd do it all over again.
author: B C.

description:
5 stars for the food quality, 0 star for the service

Last night was our second time dining at Ruth's chris. Last time, we had a great time, great food, and great service. But this time, I was very very very disappointed.

We came for the DAT, but we had to ask for the menu (just like what other yelp-ers had mentioned). The breads were good; the mixed greens were good. However, they mixed up the order; I order medium rare rib eye, and my mother ordered medium cooked filet. And when they serve, we ended up getting a medium cooked rib eye, and a medium rare filet. um.... I tried to get my server's attention to this. but he was not around, and no other server was willing to come to our table either. So, what can we do other than just eat it?! and we had to ask the server to serve desert and clean the plates. For a 5-star place, why do customers have to raise their hands for things that the server is suppose to do automatically? Through this 2-hour dinner, the server NEVER came to our table, asking if everything is okay, or how was everything. I was very disappointed at my server! 

Nonetheless, the food is great!! But the service is very bad!!!
author: Rebegi G.

description:
Whenever I've had a Ruth's Chris rib-eye, I come out wanting to evangelize the vegans and vegetarians of the world.   You don't have to be deprived of its goodness no more!  No more, I say!  It's okay...embrace it. 

Out of all the DAT restaurants, Ruth's Chris is one of my favorites.  I think it's also one of the few places that's absolutely worth the $34.95.  

The food is consistent and always reliable.  You know what you're gonna get.  The rib-eye always comes out sizzling on a hot plate.  The mashed potatoes are never too salty, never too bland. And the key lime pie is a great ending to a perfect dinner.  

They've extended their DAT menu to June 19th.  It goes on for one more week, so embrace the beef!
author: Stella K.

description:
I actually really liked this place, and at first I thought it would be totally overpriced, an old-people tourist trap restaurant.  

Truth be told, even as 'big business' as this place kind of seemed, the food was just darn good.  Excellent steak, good wine, great beer, ok/good atmosphere.  There were all these old-timers at the bar who were regulars, listening to Sinatra (not a fan, but occasionally I respect the guy since my grandmother hung out with him in his boxing days in West New York and my great grandmother helped deliver him!), watching baseball.  For some reason this moment reminded me of being back in New York at some bar/restaurant where there's no nonsense and all good food and drink.   

Let's put it this way: if you are treating yourself or someone else to a slap-bang smashing expensive dinner and want to leave with an extra 3000 calories in your digestive system and semi-nauseous from all the well-prepared comfort food you ate, Ruth's is the place for you. 

Especially if you've just finished buying a bunch of guitar equipment from the crappy Guitar center nextdoor which I will also yelp at some point.
author: betty b.

description:
This is the Best Steak ever!  I go and get the Filet Medium Rare with Shrimp (which are HUGE) and a Lobster tail.  I like steak and have had them all.  No one comes close.  
Not all Ruth Chris Steak Houses are the same.  I didnt care for the one in Walnut Creek or the one in Hawaii.  I dont know why?  Maybe the chef? The cut?  
But for a nice meal go here....
author: Just J.

description: Im in the middle of the road about this place, Its pretty good but I hate that you have to order everything ala carte. You  can order a great steak but  you have to order some expensive sides.  The steak basically comes in a pool of butter but I really cant complain because butter is the nectar of the gods.  I always get the ribeye and a couple of other Ruth Chris places that I tried had the bone in ribeye....nice!  Food is great but for the price.....ehhh
author: Mike K.

description:
We went here to celebrate my brother's 25th birthday. Thanks to Dine About Town we saved ourselves the hefty price and got a fixed rate for $32 each, which comes with salad, entree, sides, desserts. We had a table of four and choice the rib eye prime and a desert of key lime pie and bread pudding. First off, we were served a roll of bread and butter. There's nothing special about the bread, but the butter was so fluffy and creamy!  Next salad was served. Salad was your typical mixed greens from Safeway with Balsamic steak sauce and croutons. Nothing impressive. The steak however, was delish! Smoked savory to medium rare and oh soo buttery and garlicky good. The meat was grilled to the way i like it, pink in the middle and tender to the bite. The 12 oz morsel was more than enough.  Sides were also served between the options of spinach and mashed potatoes. I`m a fan of mashed potatoes, it was buttery and fluffy good.

Lastly, dessert. I shared a key lime pie and bread pudding. The key lime was good but not the best i've had. You could taste the citrusyness in the pie which is a good indicator, but it isn't strong.  The bread pudding was sweet and moist. I was particularly intrigued by the complimentary sauce. It had a strong rummy initiation and then a slight mangoey after taste. Over all the experience was okay-decent. Would I have paid full price for the meal. nah. But it's an experience worth a try.
author: Fat C.

description:
I don't know if its the butter, but this was one juicy steak I had.  We ordered out of the DAT menu, except for my bf as he has no desire for greens or sweets.  It was a double date and my buddy treated us for dinner =).  I had a small salad, rib-eye, side of mash, and key-lime pie.  I thought they were pretty generous with their portions. I usually finish my dessert, but the key lime pie was way too tangy for my taste. Too bad it wasn't anything with chocolate. I would have devoured it!

Overall, I had a great time with good service and  great company.
author: Lily T.

description:
LOVEEEE this restaurant from bottom of my heart.

I used to rate this restaurant 4 star Good cuz I was student and this restaurant was quite expensive for poor students. 

but now .. hmmm  it's ok, I wouldn't choose this restaurant if someone is taking me there!
author: Cindy N.

description:
Ruth's Chris
So last night, my fiancee and I drive from San Jose to Ruth's Chris. I was homesick and missed the city. We took the valet parking option and proceeded into the restaurant. My Texan had his briefcase in hand and I had my Dooney in Bourke on my shoulder. I think something happened to the place because I was overly dressed in my short black dress with silver sandals, and my Texan was in slacks, a tie and a leather coat. Most people were dressed in Levi's, sweaters, and very few were in slacks and dresses. I was a bit in shock, because normally people are dressed formal. 

Appetizers: Crab cakes, Calamari, French onion soup
Entree: New York for him, Bone in Ribeye for me
Sides: Grilled Onions, sauteed whole mushrooms
Dessert: Creme Brulee, Chocolate Explosion
Drinks: 2 iced teas, and regular iced water
Total with tax and tip $240.00

The complimentary warm bread arrived and was delicious and tender to my mouth. It had soft butter as an accompinament. 
The iced teas were refilled at every opportunity.
The crab cakes were huge, very lumpy crabmeat. Delicious.
The calamari was sauteed in a sweet and sour lightly coated battered crispiness. 

The Texan loved the french onion soup, and picture cheese gooeyness as he spooned each mouthful. The steaks were both prepared medium, and were fine cuts of pure mouth pleasing deliciousness. 

The chocolate explosion needed more chocolate ganache filling but was huge in size. My creme brulee was sinfully creamy and delicious with a dollop of whipped cream on the top.

I was holding hands and looking into my Texan's eyes and sharing some laughs. He was the perfect southern gentleman who made me feel loved, cared about, and with the lovely food and dim lighting, we were in our own world.
author: Charlene C.

description:
Pros:  serving staff complimentary.  Ambience as expected.  Price as expected.
Beef quality as expected but flavor unsatisfactory.  Seafood unsatisfactory.
Cons (reason for two stars):  1.  Filet was unreasonably salty  2.  Lobster was unreasonably salty as well and much to our disappointment not only tough but not fresh.  Minuses perhaps due to franchise ownership?   Cannot recommend and will not return.  For consistent quality, overall service and upscale ambience, Harris' continues to rank above the more pedestrian Ruth Chris.
author: Chris S.

description:
I would have to say this place is one of my favorite, but at the same time I can feel the fat going through my body LOL! 

This place really does have a fantastic steak, I order a rib eye and ask for medium rare and wow! right on the $$$ it was cook perfectly.  What made it extremely unique was the blue cheese melted on top. I never thought melted cheese would taste so good on a ribeye. 

What disappointed me was the salad. It just didn't pop my eyes since it taste so plain to me.
author: William C.

description:
went with a group so tried all their sides and desserts.
i liked the brussels sprouts.  
their chocolate sin cake with the berries was so chocolaty i could only take a few bites.  it may be because I'm not a big fan of chocolate.  
all the desserts were on the sweet side.  
i had the filet mignon, medium.
not a good idea.  the waiter told me the meat was flattened to make it cook evenly, but the sides were all dry and chewy.  should've gotten medium-rare.
i had their beet salad.  it was pretty good for a salad but ask for dressing on the side.  i didn't, and i felt like the salad was kind of drowning in sauce.  
the waiter was good.  i think his name was robin.  

mostly couples eat here.  they have rose petals on tables with couples.
author: Candy Y.

description: Can someone please tell me why their lamb chops are out of this world?! I've been quite a few times and sampled their menu, though all are good, the lamb is to die for! Always fills me up with a nice glass of Pinot or a few Vodka Martinis... Don't let me forget to mention the Broccoli au gratin is great too! I'll be back, though when I'm in the mood for prime rib, I go elsewhere.
author: Christopher M.

description:
Went here for my 30th birthday celebration and I didn't know what to expect.  I knew it was pricey, but I wasn't sure if it was really worth it.  My group of 20 arrived on time (for once) and even though we had a reservation, we still had to wait 45 minutes to get seated.  

Once we were seated, the wait staff was awesome and very attentive.  I ordered from the prefixed menu, I got the rib eye with a side of garlic mash... It came out on a hot plate and was heaven in my mouth!  WOWSA.  This was the perfect steak - i got it well done, but it was still tender.  Everyone else loved their food, everyone at the table gave it raving reviews.  The side of the night, cream of spinach!  

I appreciated the fact that unlike ALL the restaurants of SF, they did NOT force us to give them gratuity.  They asked us if we wanted that included in the bill, and we said yes.  It wasn't too bad for 20 people.

The experience here was great, except for the long wait to be seated.  I was super irritated because we had a reservation....
author: Marylouise R.

description:
Went here the other night for the Dine About Town special.  This place has been highly regarded by many for quite a while now, but I have never seen what the big deal was about.  However this time around the food was certainly better than what I remembered from previous experiences, but the 1 hour wait I had to endure past the time of my reservation definitely soured the mood.

As for the aforementioned cuisine, the butter was definitely at the forefront as usual at Ruth's Chris.  This gives the restaurant an overwhelming buttery odor, that is great - depending on how much you like butter that is.  This time around the food was excellent - tender rib eye steak and buttery sides.  Overall, I was pleasantly surprised and had an enjoyable time.  For the price, I don't know that I would go back if not for the Dine About Town special though...
author: Gordon M.

description:
If you've never been, you'd be hard pressed to know there existed 100 of these restaurants. The undisputed facts: pricey, exquisite, fine dining and arguably the best steaks around. When you sear a steak at 1800 degree, you're cooking steak in a manner that's rarely match. When your cuts consist of fillet's, ribeyes, new york strips, t-bones and a 40oz. porterhouse for two - you've already won me over.

With that being said, the service is strictly server dependent. Win some, lose some. I personally find it hard to not enjoy my steak even if I had to wait a few extra moments. I'll live.

Reservations: on-line reservations? Yep...I love it.
Parking: the valet parking tops off this establishments list of perks. 

Remember: you ALWAYS get what you're billed for at a Ruth's Chris.
author: Randall B.

description: This time around, I got the Fillet.  The fillet was big and cooked perfectly. You can definitely tasted all the butter they used to cook their steaks.  It's good... well for the first few bites.  After a while... all that butter starts to get to you.  The things that disappointed me where all the side dishes.  I think the only side I liked was the Onion rings.  The creamed spinach was bland and kinda tasteless.  I just expected more... and came up short.  on the bright side, the bar has a good selection of scotch.
author: Sam C.

description:
Not wanting to deal with a "special event" (otherwise known as massively overpriced) menu on New Year's Eve, we opted for reservations at Ruth's Chris. Even though I lived in New Orleans for years- home of the original- this was my first visit. It was my husband's 72nd, I believe.

Both the food and service were very good- the sizzling steak was excellent and huge. And we discovered a little known gem on the wine list with a teeny mark-up. That made our night.
author: Amy K.

description: Second time at this restaurant just different location. My boyfriend took ^me here for my birthday and once again they never fail ^me. The food was once again delicious and yummy. This place seemed a little.smaller then the one in LA. I gave it four stars once again because parking sucks. I loved that when I came in the table was set for ^me with happy birthday confetti all over, made ^me feel super special. Overall, yummy food and great service. Would come again even if parking sucks.
author: Rachelle H.

description: Been coming here for almost 20 years and because the whole experience is always always always AWESOME.  The cocktails, the atmosphere, the service  and of course the food is always excellent.  Dirty GG martini, caesar salad, filet mignon medium rare and the au gratin potatoes.  Best meal EVER. If there is a better steak in the bay area, shoot me a note, cuz I'd like to hear about it.
author: Tom D.

description: This restaurant and the one located in Walnut Creek are the only places I will eat beef.  I always order medium rare filet mignon and it is always perfect.  Every thing they offer is fantastic.  From the onion rings to the deserts it's all premium quality.
author: Tom N.

description: I was at RC last Christmas (2006) and liked it a lot since it is different compare with House of Prime Ribs, then this Christmas (2007) I went there again and the food is still great and service is great as well except it took my waiter 20 minutes to bring the bill can't really blame him since it was pretty busy. Anyway good place to go.
author: William C.

description:
I ate here for the first time tonight and LOVED it. If you're willing to spend the money, you should definitely plan a romantic dinner here. My best friend and I came here on a whim (or perhaps trying to "seize the day" after finding out that Michael Jackson died earlier today) and weren't wearing what we'd consider the "proper" clothing for such a lovely restaurant, but it didn't seem to matter. The staff was very friendly and didn't make us feel uncomfotable for wearing scuffed jeans and flipflops. 

I had one of their summer specials... salad (the ceasar is quite good) + 6 oz. filet and spicy shrimp + 1 side dish (I chose the creamed spinach) + dessert (raspberry sorbet and fresh berries)... and all for $39.99, I believe. I had a $13 glass of wine, though... their wines by the glass are pretty damn expensive for my non-profit salary... but hey, you only live once, right?
author: Suzi G.

description:
The steak melts in your mouth. Everything, veggies included, is soaked in either butter, cream, or cheese and in some cases all three. My dream, a dieters nightmare. The waitor recommended this amazing pinot that I'm kicking myself for not remembering the name of, but it almost tasted like a sparkling wine and bursted with a cherry flavor. Too good.
Really expensive though, don't go unless you're planning on dropping some serious cash.
author: Taylor E.

description:
I'm convinced that San Francisco Dine About Town is a scam....they load up the reservations so that you will get tipsy at their bar while waiting 45 mins. for a table and order an expensive bottle of wine when seated.  Or maybe I'm just a lush.  

I had a fantastic meal here.  I ordered the petit filet which was cooked to perfection.  My companion had the Ribeye which was also perfectly prepared.  The sides of spinach and potatoes went well with the main courses, and the desert portions of key lime pie and bread pudding were HUGE!  but worth it....so worth it.  

Keep in mind I was ordering from a special menu (http://www.onlyinsanfrancisco.com/dineabouttown/), but  would definitely go back and try some of their regular entrees.  This place was a nut-house on a Thursday night, so make sure to make a reservation!
author: Kerry D.

description:
If you like fantastic near-raw meat, would contemplate eating a stick of butter like an ice cream cone, and have a couple bills burning a hole in your pocket...

www.opentable.com
author: Matthew R.

description:
Food - 3.5
Service - 2.5
Ambience - 3.5

My hubby & I made reservations for a Tuesday night at 7:00 p.m. for the DAT special menu ($31.95 pp for a 3-course prix fixe menu). Arrived at 6:45ish and was seated about five minutes later. They gave us the regular menu and it took a while for our waiter to introduce himself, so that we could tell him we wanted the DAT menu. Strike 1.

The salad starter was okay - fairly typical. I asked for my balsamic vinagrette dressing on the side; it arrived on the salad. Strike 2. Luckily, it wasn't drenched in dressing, so I didn't make a fuss. We also ordered crab cakes as an additional app. Big o' chunks of crab, very reminiscent of my recent trip to Baltimore, so I was in heaven. The deliciousness factor helped us to swallow the $20 price tag for 2 small-medium-sized crab cakes.

Hubby & I both ordered the filet - I mean, we ARE at a steak house, after all. He ordered his medium-rare (it arrived more rare than medium) and I ordered mine medium/medium-rare (which the waiter suggested since I couldn't decide which I wanted and he assured me he could do something in between). It arrived more medium than medium-rare. Stike 3. Since we were hungry and it wasn't terribly bad (afterall, hubby could just "cook" his meat a little more on his 500 degree plate), we decided against sending it back. Both steaks were quite delicious and we devoured them.

The sides from the DAT menu - creamy, garlic mashed potatoes (divine) and creamed spinach (okay, but not great). Portions were good and I even had some steak and sides to wrap up for leftovers.

Desserts - key lime pie and bread pudding. Both were delicious and had I not been so stuffed, I probably would have finished off the pie.

Net-net, I'm really glad we finally got ourselves to Ruth's Chris and it felt so decadent to go out to a nice steak house on a random Tuesday night, but were it not for DAT, I probably would have given this a 2-star review.
author: Lynn H.

description:
Tried out this place at Dine about Town with $75 for a three course meal for two with smaller portions than usual. The portions were easily big enough. If you upgrade it a little, the total came out a little over $100. 

The steak was good. It's a great cut of meat, great service, great atmosphere. However, the service was no where close to Alexander or Sundance level.  The wait was long at 45 minutes. The dessert was great too. I recommend it. However, it does not compete with Alexander's at all, which is priced about the same and much better. Did not mind trying it out for the reduced price for dine about town, but would not go here at regular prices. Your money is better spend elsewhere.
author: Ahmed S.

description:
A very, very buttery and delicious restaurant. Once I walked in, waves of buttery scent never ceased throughout my meal. Butter on my mashed potatoes, even more butter on my creamed spinach, and my steak was almost wading in butter... But is that a problem? Well, because everything tasted so good, not really! :)

I came here for Dine About Town, and had the House Salad, the Rib-Eye with mashed potatoes side, Key Lime pie for dessert. The salad and dessert (pie and bread pudding) were so-so, but since this is a steak house, and the quality of the ingredients weren't so bad, I didn't mind very much.

Which brings us to the steak. Very, very delicious steak -- truly came to the table sizzling! It was skillfully prepared, tender on the inside, sizzling on the outside, juicy and tasty. I do hear that Alexander's makes better steak, but I have to say that Ruth's Chris probably offers one of the best steaks in the city for its price. I'm salivating just reliving the memory of that steak. Come here if you like a good steak! 

Also, Ruth's Chris has really solid, gold-standard service. The waiters are extremely polite. Seat you, serve you, refill your water, show you to the bathroom, etc. in a very warm, professional manner.
author: Deanne C.

description:
4 stars for service.

5 stars for the shrimp (on Kobe beef). Can't really taste the difference in cows otherwise.

0 stars for price. I'd only come here on someone else's dime.
author: Inigo M.

description:
We went for the DAT menu.
We had a few issues with service. 
1)My husband's plate cracked and broke bc it was so hot.
2)They gave me the wrong meat, a ribeye, instead of the filet.
My filet was overcooked. It was more medium than medium rare. However the steaks were still pretty flavorful. I didn't really enjoy the creamed spinach. The key lime pie and bread pudding were pretty standard. I had the Big Easy cocktail, which I thought was very tasty. If not for the DAT deal, I'm pretty sure I won't be back.
author: Diana S.

description:
Good service. Nice sizzling steak.

Pretty much hit all the tick boxes on the "American Steak House" list.

I like this place because it doesn't require you to be decked out for dinner.

You come as you are and leave full, happy, and sleepy.
author: Eugene L.

description: Booked this on Open Table and it worked perfectly.  The Filet Mignon, on the 500 degree plate with melted butter is to die for.  I have been to the best steakhouse in the world, London, Paris, China, USA, and Ruths Chris gets the best Filet Mignon hands down.  The service was impeccable and drinks were good.  I could have taken off half a star because it was my birthday and the greeters normally wish you a birthday when reservations are made but she didnt.  Otherwise, it was fantastic.!
author: Erwin R.

description: I promised my husband that we would treat ourselves here each time I receive a bonus check. So when the extra money came in, we immediately made reservations to dine at Ruth's. Everything was excellent and mouth watering as always. I am forever amazed at the amount of butter that is used/consumed here...from the whipped butter served with the heated sliced soft bread, to the sizzling crabcake appetizer and cuts of steak that are drenched with it...even the berries and cream dessert! A most rich and decadent experience for both the stomach and the wallet! Top notch service too.
author: Elaine W.

description: I had heard really wonderful things about this place and I have to say they lived up to all expectations.  The staff was wonderful and the FOOD was to die for the steak was wonderfully tender that it was like butter melting in your mouth.  We went there for a family dinner and they had a smaller menu for my daughter and she loved every bite.    We will be back!
author: Marnie W.

description: My all time favorite restaurant!!!  A friend visiting from LA wanted to eat here, so of course I couldn't say no!  Though Ruth's Chris is participating in Dine about Town, I decided to order from their Ruth's Classics menu.  I started off with the Gumbo (yummy), had the 6oz Filet with Grilled Shrimp with Brussel Sprouts, and for dessert, Cheesecake and Chocolate Toffee.  Ruth's Chris never ever disappoints.  The steak was excellent as usual.  It was the first time I tried their Brussel Spouts and I'm in love.  The Sweet Potato Casserole is the side I usually order....you've got some competition!  The atmosphere and service were excellent.  I had a really great time here!
author: Janet P.

description: This place has very good meat! Feeling carniverous?? This is your spot!
author: lashawnte b.

description:
Service was excellent- Matt you're very helpful and informed- thanks for the info on the Baccarat crystal...let us know when Louie is on his last leg.  
The steaks: the filet mignon was very tasty and tender- done just right to each person's specifications, the rib-eye melted in the mouth.  The sides were ok nothing out of the ordinary- too bad there was no creamed spinach- dang E. coli.  Deserts: banana cream pie- creamy, chocolate sin cake- will pass on the next time.  The piece de resistance was the whisky bread pudding- would actually go back for that one.
author: J S.

description:
This is the place for frikkin steak!! Cooked the way you want, with extra extra butter, extra fat, extra cholesterol, extra good, extra whatever the hell you want.....steak that melts in your mouth good!!!!

Definitely have to make reservations so you don't have to wait and the staff are extra friendly and free delicious dessert when it's your birthday!! My ususal, filet mignon cooked rare with mashed potatoes and asparagus as sides. And a nice glass of Cab......

Then you might need help getting up and walking to your car, and you might even curse at yourself at eating that much....but then when you get home and your stomach settles....you crave for more and wish you ordered an extra steak to go!

But then you open up your wallet to find that your frikkin broke.....
author: Star B.

description:
Funny, the first time I ate here, I was so unimpressed that I didn't even bother to write a review.  Maybe I wasn't hungry or was really spaced out...whatever.

So my fiance took me here for a dinner date last night and for the first time in a really, really long time I managed to clean my plate.  We had initially come for the summer deal they were having, a 3-course meal for two for only $89.  However, the items that we wanted just weren't on the special menu, so we opted to go a la cart instead.

I ordered the petite fillet and he had the ribeye, both with the bleu cheese crust and we shared sides of spinach au gratin and sweet potato casserole.  

Our steaks were presented on 500-degree hot plates, sizzling with fragrant browned butter and topped with a golden, garlicky, blue cheese topping.  Our sides came in separate ramekins, nearly as hot as our meat.  The medium-rare steaks were melt-in-your mouth perfect, cutting into my fillet was like cutting through butter.  Both of the sides were delicious.  We both burned our tongues digging in.  It wasn't until our meal was more than halfway consumed before we were able to eat at a comfortable pace.  That being said, I totally prefer burning-hot steak to steak that becomes cold and gelatinous about halfway through the meal, which is generally what happens nearly everywhere else.

Along with drinks (I had a Kir Royale, he had a Mojito) our bill came out to about $160.  Not quite the $89 that we had initially meant to spend, but we both agree that it was well worth it.  I can't wait to return...I do have a birthday coming up in a few weeks...

*funny story* I thought I'd mention that we were seated behind a couple that ordered chicken and fish.  How do you go to a world-reknown steakhouse and not order steak?  Totally weird.  On top of that, they were shocked to find that the seared ahi tuna entree they ordered was "practically raw".  Hmmm...something tells me that they're not from around here...
author: Nana K.

description: Great food. Everything I got was cooked perfectly and the flavors were perfect. It's just one of those typical steakhouses where you can't go often because of it's prices.  I think about $140 for my girlfriend and I with two glasses of wine, but will definitely go back eventually..
author: Colin H.

description: Thee best steakhouse in the city....it's expensive but worth the money.
author: P J.

description:
Perhaps it was over-hyped for me because I was not impressed. They seated us on time and the waiter was friendly but the food just wasn't anything special.
I ordered the DAT menu and got the fillet. The fillet was good quality meat that actually came medium-rare, the way I ordered it. The salad was very plain. Not bad but it was just mixed greens with balsamic vinegar dressing. The sides were horrible. The cream of spinach was disgusting. The mashed potato was not good either... how do you mess up these sides?? For dessert I got the bread pudding and it was good but a tad too sweet.
Had it not been DAT prices ($31.95 for a 3 course dinner), I would have given it 2 stars.
author: Bemmy B.

description:
A regular steak house, nothing fancy.
Messed up order (medium rib eye for m. rare ordered, rare filet for m.) and got a free dessert.  Not to impressed.

- I agree they are overrated for regular steaks.
- Wine selection is okay too.
author: Ryan C.

description:
I've never had a bad steak at Ruth's Chris, and I actually had the best steak of my life here too, so I am definitely a fan. The petite fillet never fails to satisfy, and they often have great specials that are worth checking out (the best steak mentioned before was a Kobe special that I wish they had all the time!). I've eaten here probably 10 times over the last 10 years, and always walked away satisfied. The wait-staff is always very good, the restaurant is quite clean, the main dishes (steaks!) are fantastic and even the sides are delicious (I personally love the creamed spinach and the sauteed mushrooms).

This is a somewhat up-scale restaurant, a place I would recommend for a date, a special occasion and/or a celebration, but make sure you make reservations as there can be bit of a wait sometimes.
author: Alexander O.

description:
Just recently dined here for my birthday. Food is good but their service is GREAT. When we arrived at our table, I noticed they had sprinkled Happy Birthday confetti on our table. I thought that was pretty cool. Our waitress, Christy, was awesome. Very informative, attentive, & knowledgeable. She was always close by when we needed something. It was also nice to see the manager swing by our table a couple of times & make sure we were all good. 
Now the food. For starters we ordered the crab cakes & stuffed mushrooms. The mushrooms didn't stand out much for me, but the crab cakes were super delicious! I had the petite filet mignon as my entree, the size was perfect, the tenderness was just ok, it tasted good, but I've definately had much better filet mignon at other restaurants. Their sides were also just ok. We ordered cremed spinach, pretty good, mashed potatoes, just your regular mashed, nothing special, asparagus with hollandaise sauce, the asparagus was just steamed, no flavor at all, sauteed mushrooms, they were just ok but paired well with my steak. My boyfriend ordered the rib eye steak which looked amazing, but I didn't try it. Another person in our group ordered the t-bone, and that thing was HUGE! Didn't try it either. For dessert, they served me a cup of creme & berries with dark chocolate toffee bars served on a plate with "Happy Birthday" spelled in chocolate, that was cute. I heard for your anniversary, they sprinkle rose petals on your table & give you champagne & chocolate covered strawberries. 
All in all, the experience was pleasant mostly because of the ambiance & impeccable service (which explains the 4th star). The food is good but I've had much better at many other places. This place is definately overrated & overpriced.
author: Claudia M.

description:
I really think that I can grill a great steak, but we had a gift card.  We had a really good dinner.

The salad wedge was almost a whole head of iceberg lettuce with a generous topping of blue cheese and more blue cheese dressing.  My ribeye was cooked to a perfect, medium-rare.  Great shoestring potatoes.  Dessert was complimentary for our wedding anniversary - nice touch.

The service was polite, but a bit confused when the dining room picked up a bit of business.

I think I can still grill a great steak, but once in a while, it tastes better when someone else is cooking.  Thank you, John and Chester, for the gift card!
author: Collin W.

description:
I thought that I'll never be able to afford to eat here but when RC took part in the dine about town 3 course dinner special, there was no way I was going to pass that up.  

My gf and I loved the soft warm bread, the salads were just ok, and so was the garlic mash.  but when our steaks came, we were like kids on christmas day.  our eyes glistened at the sizzling steaks and our nostrils flared by the wonderful aroma of herbed garlic butter melting over our pieces of pure joy.  Gf got the petite filet which was cooked perfect and my rib-eye was ever so tender.  We were so happy that we got this meal so cheap, we even splurged on a glass of wine.  To top off the night, we even had dessert.  the bread pudding was warm and oh so good.  It's just too bad I only had one bite because my tummy was in carnivore nirvana.  

Alright, back to the review (wipes away drool)...the price for a steak here is expensive.  And you need to pay for your sides also, so that's definitely no fun.  If you have never been here then it's ok to spend the money on a birthday or an anniversary.  Because it's definitely a must try.  Or you can be like me and just wait it out until the next dine about town.
author: Billy T.

description:
Service was awkward, inept, and rude. The steaks were mediocre, at best. 
I took my boyfriend here for his birthday, hoping for a special celebration for him. A mutual friend had called ahead and ordered a bottle of  Cabernet to be sent to our table, only the waiter brought a bottle of champagne instead. We were surprised to get champagne as neither of us drinks it much,esp not with steak. We found out later our friend had actually ordered a cab ( a really nice cab, actually, damn). 

The food was disappointing. The steaks were at least cooked right but were doused in butter. Maybe to hide the sub par quality and taste? 
Definitely will not be back, and I'm sorry my boyfriends birthday dinner was such a flop.

For these prices, excellent service and food should be a given. Neither happened at Ruth Chris.
author: Ariel W.

description:
I've eaten there twice. The first time, I had the prime rib. It was a juicy tender steak, but they topped it with butter and it made the steak heavy for me. It is a very pricey place. The second time, we ate there when it was having a special. SF nite out. There was a deal on a set menu and I had the Filet Mignon. It was a good steak and tender. I forgot the sides we had. 
This is a good place to go on  a special occasion.
author: Larry V.

description:
This place is probably one of the best steak house restaurants i've been to, its expensive but well worth it.

I had the Filet Mignon with a side of mashed potatoes and it hit the spot. You can literally cut the steak with a butter knife it was delicious. 

Service was persistent also a good thing. 

For anyone that goes here i would say you only need to order two things; a steak, and a side because you will be full after that.
author: ernie e.

description: I'm a harsh critic when it comes to steak houses because I've been to so many and have experienced some amazing steaks and sadly, I was expecting more from this place. I've heard great things about the steaks here and I thought it was great for the dine about town price ($35 for a 3 course meal) but I would not pay full price for the food here. Ambiance was nice, service was great, and food was pretty good but nothing special. I would only advise getting the blue cheese crusts only if you're a fan of blue cheese because it tends to become a little overwhelming/overpowering and the flavor of the meat itself is lost. The wine selection is decent and our waitress was very knowledgeable about food/wine pairings, which is always nice. Great place for a fancy date, they have a valet service if you can't find parking on the street and they are very accomodating if you're running a little late, give them a call and they will save your table and make sure to keep the kitchen open for you (if you have a reservation closer to the end of the night).
author: Melissa B.

description: Awe, I luv this place.  From the nights I went to here for pre concert dinner to my fiancee's birthday dinner.  The service is awesome as usual.  Favorite drink here is the sidecar, fresh fruit and a wholesome serving of cognac.  Bartender says fresh fruit makes drink deceivingly strong.  If you're a guy (or gal) and like meat, sizzling butter, and smell of meat sizzling in burger, you can't go wrong here.   Great balance of drinks, food, and desserts all around.
author: Johnny T.

description: One of my favorite steakhouses.  The steaks are served on a sizzling hot plate.  I have always had excellent service and fantastic food.
author: Izzy T.

description:
I loathe these "four dollar sign" restaurants.  You assume with the prices they charge, their service would go beyond what you would expect at Cheesecake Factory and the like.  But Ruth's Chris doesn't. 

If I sound like a bitch--well, I probably am--its only because I have high expectations for a place that will charge you $35 for a fist sized piece of meat. Yes, their steaks are good as should be expected, but it doesn't really matter when everything else was meh. My server was good, which I also already expected. He just wasn't excpetional. Ruth's Chris wasn't exceptional for that matter. 

FIRST PROBLEM: I wait at the bar and order a drink because my table isn't ready yet. When my table is ready, instead of the hostess offering to have someone bring the drink to my table when its done, he tells me, like he's doing me a favor, that he'll wait for me while I wait for my drink. 

I was once a server at a dinky bar and grill, whcih will not be named because I am embarrassed to have ever worked there, but even we knew better. 

SECOND PROBLEM: I told him we wanted to order from the Dine About Town menu and instead of offering us a menu or even explaining to us the choices, he just sort of waits while we "guess" what was on the menu.  

THIRD PROBLEM: We had to eat our salad pepper-less. I didn't realize it until I saw that all our surrounding tables were offered fresh ground pepper. 

FOURTH (minor) PROBLEM (but one nonetheless): The hostess doesn't offer to take my coat.

I would rather go to Outback or Black Angus.
author: Dorothy N.

description: This place is good. I enjoyed the steak without a doubt, but the side dishes are kind of small. That is my only dislike to say. That atmosphere is very upper middle class feel which is whatever to me. I just want to be feed, just make me leave full!
author: Mike b.

description:
Great steak! I give it 5 stars because Ruth's Chris always participates in San Francisco's Dine About Town (in January and June) and it is definitely the best deal in the bunch. You can get a 3 course dinner (appetizer, main course, dessert) for $34.95 and that is what just the steak would set you back on a normal night.

The steak (and mostly everything) is slathered in butter, but it sure does taste good. Don't go here on a night you are dieting, but know that every single calorie is worth it.

I recommend the petite filet, creamed spinach, and key lime pie!
author: Lauren K.

description:
Last September we got married and just before there were a lot of Germans in town who all wanted a truly American steak experience. So we booked a table here for 12 people and it was great. Admittedly, the steaks are not cheap but everybody was wowed by taste and quality. 
The service was really friendly and fast and very patient with all the questions the 'foreigners' had. Definitely a very pleasant experience. It could almost be a five star review, if only I was into corn-fed beef. I eat it occasionally but I try to opt for grass-finished whenever I can.
author: Alexandra D.

description: I am Dararith's friend who ordered the petit filet that was cooked well done instead of medium rare as stated and asked for. But we were so hungry we just ate it anyway. I did like my taste of the ribeye steak that I took from Dararith's plate, wish I had ordered that instead but definitely would not even have finished most of it. Overall, this is not worth the price or even worth it at all. Completely overrated. The service was pleasant though and the bread was good, but that's not really difficult to do.
author: T. D.

description:
I heard about that the "Recession Buster" special they had it's just way to good to pass up. if you dont get booze and can get our the door for under $80. The cow was great, the sides... god damn...to be honest i've ordered them take out for dinner... yeah.. 3 sides and a bootleg movie...thats a party.

I cant recall the waitresses name but she was super nice and walked my dumb ass through the menu without being snarky and they were "present" but not over bearing like... my water made it to the bottom before they filled it up ya know.

parking is Valet, but if you go at like 6pm its pretty open seating and the area meters turn off at 6pm .. so its a win win.

damn im getting some sides for dinner...the spinach is popeye status.

its a nice joint, wear nice clothes, no hats, keep it classy people its San Francisco.
author: Marcus B.

description: Absolutely delicious food. Had the best Ribeye steak ever!!!  and a great citrus mojito.  Waitress was amazing, and so was the atmosphere.
author: Hazy M.

description:
Came here about 30 minutes after they reopened for dinner so there was only one couple who was seated. Tell me why the host sat us (just my date and I) right next to the bathroom booth? He wasn't really courteous when we came in ... whatever... but he sat us far away and in the worst seat in the house. Luckily, the server was great and she made sure we were re-seated to a better spot. I got the filet, which was cooked perfectly, and cognac on the rocks. I know that these places give smaller drinking glasses for alcohol and put a lot of ice but there was maybe at most 1.5 ounces in my $28 glass of cognac. That was weak. 

Host was wack, drink was weak, but the food and server saved them.
author: Terrance M.

description:
I've been to a Ruth's Chris in CT...years ago.  But San Francisco's version is much classier, with a better bustle and butter smell than CT's could dream of.

I used to wait tables at Morton's so I feel a little dirty when I even THINK of eating at Ruth's Chris.  But the simple fact that I could get Prime MEAT on a Dine About Town budget ...let's just say I HAD to deal with the funny feeling inside to revisit their Steaks and Wines.

Of course, my dinner date and I threw the DAT menu to the side when we remembered how much better an 11 ounce slab of meat is (DAT offers a 6 oz filet), and how yummy ceasar salad is...you get the picture.  

We both ordered the same cut, although I asked for cold rare and he wanted rare +.  His was perfect, mine was very warm, but still red.  I mentioned it to the waiter, but had decided to enjoy the steak anyway.  I could deal with the extra ten seconds in the broiler.  

Our lyonnaise potatoes were perfect, crunchy, not greasy, with nice moist fried onions mixed in.  We loved the whole crab cake on the filet (oscar style), it was pretty rich.  The sauteed spinach was a huuuuge portion, but really good - not too buttery and the leftovers made sweet love to my eggs this morning.

The hot chocolate cake was really large and really flipping good.  Because often these lava cakes have a sorta dry, gummy, or hard outer cake that NEEDS the lava/ganache to make it good.  Not so with this version, the cake surrounding the ganache was moist, bouncy and worthy of being eating sans liquid center.  

I was most impressed with our waiter.  He was genuinely enthusiastic and geeky about wine (one thing I looooved about working at a steak house was the wine geekery instead of snobbery) and he made excellent suggestions, was honest when he didn't know something, answered a request for tastings openly, and even gave a wine we asked about a thumbs down that rang true upon tasting.  The wine we wanted was not available, but the replacement was similar and less money.  And stupid good.

Will I go back? Maybe.  And for SF, that's a compliment.  And yes, come hungry, and don't be ashamed of taking home leftovers.  Steakhouses offer some of the most AWESOME morning afters...which you can't say about many things in life.
author: Lindsay B.

description:
I really dont think you can go wrong with garlic and extra butter on a piece of thick meat. 

ahem.

did the dine about town thing here.  meat was good. spinach was too rich, and mashed potatoes were nothing to yelp about.
author: Michelle C.

description:
5 stars for the steaks!  Every time I go back, they never, EVER disappoint me.  I'm a New York strip kinda guy and my fiance preffers the Ribeye.  Delicious.  Add these 2 sides, Sauteed Mushrooms and the Spinach Au Gratin....done!  Food coma.  Nite nite.  

"How would you like your steak cooked, sir?" asked our server...
Me - "Medium Blood, please." 
Server - You got it!

They know steak.  I preffer Ruth Chris over Mortons, ACME, Izzy's etc...
Hmmm...I think I'll make my reservations online now for this weekend...excuse me...see you there.
author: Paolo E.

description:
I absolutely love the steaks here. I eat steak quite frequently and have a few gourmet recipes of my own that are crowd pleasers; but Ruth's Chris always makes them the way I love: with lots and lots of butter. 

This is not a place to eat at on a budget...like Gary Danko's or Morton's, you should expect about $100-$150 a person for a full course meal with a modest bottle wine. 

My recipe for a great meal at Ruth's Chris is as follows:

     1) Show up a bit early. Dress well. Get valet parking. Have a seat at the bar and have a cocktail while they get your table ready.

     2) Once seated, order either some wine or another cocktail while you peruse the menu.

     3) If you like big steaks, get the 9oz filet...if you like smaller, get the petite filet (5oz); I have always ordered the filet here and I have never been disappointed. They are served slightly charred on a red-hot plate of sizzling butter. YUM!

     4) Order a side of potatoes au gratin and broccoli with béarnaise. Note: the vegetables are normally served with hollandaise, but I think the buttery flavor of béarnaise goes with the steaks better than the lemon. Ask and you will receive.

     5) Make sure you get the steak at least medium...a meat of this quality is ruined by anything more done. If you don't like rare steaks, don't buy a filet. Filet of beef, like duck, should be served medium with a warm, red center. Overcooking shouldn't dry them out so much as change the overall texture and flavor. If you order any other steak (such as the prime rib or the NY strip), you are missing out on the main attraction. 

     6) Enjoy your steaks with a nice glass of red wine that is ordered WITH your meal. The staff is very knowledgeable about the local wineries and they go through frequent wine-tasking and wine-training events. I've never been disappointed when asking for a recommendation, even for a winery I've never heard of or with a varietal that one normally wouldn't pair with a buttery steak.

     7) Order the crème brulee and an espresso with Bailey's and you won't be disappointed. The custard is served at room temperature, or sometimes warm, which I feel is the best way to enjoy crème brulee and the coffee with irish creme just hits the spot.

The manager should come by at least once during your meal to make sure everything is perfect. If it's not, they have always been friendly and courteous with remedying any problem.

Finally, relax and enjoy the romantic atmosphere. I have never been rushed from my seat, even during the busiest of nights and have always felt like I had as much time as I need for my entire meal.
author: Jason H.

description:
I went here for dinner.  I thought it was a bit expensive, but nice atmosphere and great service.

I had the filet mignon and it was a bit tough, but tasty - I had it cooked medium rare.  The lobster bisque was too salty for my taste.  The asparagus with hollandaise sauce was really good.  My husband had a seafood plate which was also very good.

I may go again if I was in the area.
author: MJ W.

description:
Like many on here I decided to give this place a try for Dine About Town. Why not??? Well, it was well worth it. I went with two co-workers on a Tuesday night. We easily found street parking, however, I was very much prepared to pay for valet as I often do in the city. 

We arrived 15 minutes early due to the fact that there was no bridge traffic. They weren't quite ready for us, so we opted to hang in the bar where I got a drink. My two coworkers decided that the drinks were too pricey for them, so they just hung out. Sooo..boring!! Right about the time our reservations were for, the host came and took us to our table. Not bad at all!!

We all decided on getting the 12oz steak. I got the spinach. The guys got mashed potatoes. The bread came out...and OMG...it was great bread. Thank you for not serving sour dough. This bread was soooooo good!! Our salads came out right after that. Then our steaks and sides. I have to say, if you like it medium rare, order it rare. The plates and butter on top were so sizzling hot, that mine was almost over cooked. However, it really didn't bother me because the meat was very tender and buttery. I will remember to order it bloody next near. Then it will be perfect. The potatoes were great and my spinach was pretty nice. I think I would ask them for a different side with not so much cream next time. I think we could do that. 

For dessert we had a choice between the Key Lime Pie (yumm!! A favorite of mine) and Bread pudding. Both of the guys got bread pudding. It was good, but they both thought it was way to heavy after the meal. They were kind of jealous of my pie. It was tasty. 

After all of the buttery goodness, I wanted to die. The food was great, but that butter was a killer. I would do again!!
author: Andrea T.

description:
DAT at Ruth's Chris?  This was a fantastic deal ($35) and would definitely do it again if they are available in June.

Bring your own bottle of red and have a fine meal on a budget.

The biggest surprise of the night was the freshly baked appetizer bread and bread pudding.  I could have eaten the bread all day.  I shouldn't have been surprised at how yummy the bread pudding was.  Fluffy, a little bit of texture, hint of bourbon and not too sweet.

Spongebob Awesomeness:  Order the oscar crab cakes as a asparagus/béarnaise treat to compliment your meal.  I've been to 4 different Ruth's Chris and I'm impressed by their consistent quality.
author: Ronald M.

description:
Rating: 3.5 stars

Great deal for DAT!!  Can't beat $35 for salad; 8 oz filet, 12 oz rib eye;  BBQ shrimp; side: mashed pototatoes or creamed spinach; and dessert: bread pudding or key lime pie.

The salad was so so.  Mom and fiance enjoyed their rib eyes.  I had the BBQ shrimp which was pretty good.  The sides were good, but not great.  My fiance and I dined here two years ago and I remember the creamed spinach being better.  Desserts were good though!  No complaints on either.

The awesome thing was we brought our own wine.  There's a $15 corkage fee, but it was still worth it.  I think the cheapest bottle at RC is around $50.  This is why I love Yelp!  You learn all these things b/c RC definitely does not advertise that you can BYO.

I'm not sure if we'd dine here on a non DAT day, but highly recommend for DAT.  We've done it two years in a row now.
author: Michelle H.

description:
As everyone has said, Ruth's Chris is doing the whole city a favor by offering an excellent Dine About Town menu. Seriously. $35 for a salad, steak, spinach, and desert. Typically, that steak alone will set you back $35 at a restaurant like this. So I'd say go now...but DAT ends today, so...go next year!

As for the food, the salad was passable, the spinach was pretty great, and the dessert (key lime pie) is in the top-5 key lime pie's I've ever eaten (see my reviews from Key West, FL for more info). Anyways, the steak. I had a 12oz ribeye, which appeared to be much more than 12oz, but I'll take their word for it. It was in that "Ruth's Chris style" of coming in at 400 degrees with a copious amount of heart-clogging butter sizzling audibly. Which is kind of great, in it's unique way. I try to consider myself a meat purist, so that much butter was something I was a afraid of. But it worked. Maybe it was the temperature, but it wasn't just some steak with butter on it. It was steak where the butter went THROUGH it. It baked itself into the meat. Which made the meat wonderful, if not a little less than pure-steaky in taste. But really, I ate the thing in record time, it was excellent.

Before the meal, I had a tanqueray martini which was standard and perfect, if you're sitting there in a suit jacket and trying to look more sophisticated than you are.

So, a couple minor knocks on the place. Our reservation was 8pm, but the word is out on the DAT menu, and there were TONS of not-so-Ruth-Chris-type people there looking for a deal (ourselves completely included in this group). But yeah, our reservation was for 8, and we weren't seated until 9. On a Monday night. Still somewhat unacceptable. Also, they seated us at an audibly-challenged booth inside the bar area, which isn't what you'd hope for in a nice steak house. Not the best ambiance I've ever seen for a Ruth Chris for sure.

Nevertheless, they were accommodating and the actual service once seated was pretty good. The food was fantastic. And the Dine About Town menu was a complete steal.
author: Tolga E.

description: Best steak in the world!, its crispy and juicy. good service and nice ambiance.
author: Diana T.

description:
My fiancee loves this place, I'm sure it has something to do with the food being drenched in butter!  

We love coming here for DAT, since it's such a good deal!  We both had the 12oz ribeye, creamed spinach, and one of each dessert (bread pudding and key lime pie).

The steaks were DELICIOUS!  They even started adding add ons, such as lobster tail, blue cheese crusts, etc for the DAT menu which are also great.  My only complaint was that they didn't have the potatoes au gratin this time for DAT.  The desserts were good, I prefer the key lime pie as it isn't as sticky sweet as the bread pudding.
author: Cheryl L.

description:
The parking garage underneath is kind of scary.  I was waiting for a masked man to pop out , but of course, everything is fine. :)  Our waiter was definitely an actor, so animated.  Ok, let's talk food.  You can order the Ruth Chris Classic and get a soup or salad, main dish, side of choice, and dessert.  I got the seafood gumbo.  Definitely good!  It would be almost a main dish.  The bread was really good too.  The ribeye was amazing.  You can order the Oscar addition which is a crab cake and asparagus on top with a sauce.  The sauce was a bit rich, so maybe I'll order without.  The steak was bomb.  I ordered it medium rare and the plate comes out hot (I was told by our waiter at 500 degrees) so I think it kept cooking.  I'll try rare next.  The sides are huge portions, so we shared.  The garlic mashed potatoes are light and airy.  The sweet potatoes were amazing!  Au Grautin was ok.   The dessert included a cheesecake with bark.  The bark was not good and the cheesecake was just ok.  Overall, good experience and they have great thick napkins in the bathroom.  You can also get matches on the way out. :)  

If its your birthday, they throw Happy Birthday confetti at ya!
author: Neville B.

description:
There's not many places that are expensive, but worth the price.  This is place is one of them.

A friend of mine took me here for my birthday....Wow!  The place was kinda small, but the tables were arranged in a way that it was easy for people to get to their seats.   I love how they pair a particular red wine with each cut of meat.   They explain it to you in the menu...a beginner's intro to wine pairing.   Ask them to explain how they cook the meat to you.  All I remember was that it was some insane temperature to really lock in the juices of the meat.  Excellent!

The best part for me was the sweet potato casserole side dish.  It's so fricken good.  The waiter told us that he sometimes just orders that with a side of ice cream for dessert.

The portions are a good size.  We finished our plates, but had no room for dessert.  Being that it was my birthday, the waiter told us that we were entitled to a complimentary dessert....mind you that the dessert is big enough to share.   He just said that we could choose one and he would just wrap it up for us to have later.  

Everything about this place just works together so well....the wine, the meal, the dessert, the service.   My mouth is watering just thinking about it.
author: Warren C.

description:
Quite pricey, but quite delicious.  Never had I tried such a soft filet mignon. Outstanding!  It's great with fries, and the fried onions. yum. 

Want something cheaper? Then you won't be disappointed with the stuffed chicken.  It's amazing!  

Damn, parking sucks around here. You  might have to give in to valet.  And even though you reserve, you still might have to wait around.
author: Jay M.

description:
I Dined About Town at Ruth's Chris.  The reason we chose this restaurant was simply it is too balling for me to eat at this restaurant on a normal day and be filled ($60+). Either I'd have to wait for a close friend/family members birthday, get a girlfriend with the whole reason of eating at Ruth's Chris for an Anniversary dinner, or... win the lotto.

Salad was just salad. Nothing to write home to your mother about. Perhaps I the wrong choice on the entree. I got the Ribeye, a steak I usually enjoy. It wasn't as "marbled" as the menu had claimed it to be. Worth the $42 bucks it usually cost? Probably not. At least I got to try it at DAT prices. The key lime pie was okay. Store bought tasty, which is not tasty enough for a place everyone should have high expectations for.

The highlight of the night was the waitress + the bread. The bread was bomb. Sadly, not enough to justify the price in my book.
author: Garrett W.

description:
It had been awhile since we last ate here but decided to go back for dinner on their $89.00 for two Summer Sensation Special.
Not a bad deal considering how costly it can get. 
Crusty french bread with butter is served. They offer sparkling or still water. If you don't specify "tap", you'll have to pay for your bottled water!
We each got a first course, soup or salad, then we ordered the Mixed Grill Combo. It included a Petit Filet Mignon, Half a Roasted Stuffed Chicken breast, a reasonably sized yummy crab cake and half of a grilled steak tomato.  Very good and very filling. On top of that, we each got to order a side dish. We picked a starch ( garlic mashed potatoes) and sauteed mushrooms. A shared dessert topped off our dinner.
For those on a budget, this is one of the best ways to go fine dining.
author: Julie M.

description:
Having tried Harris, Bix, House of Prime Rib I have a bit of a basis for comparison, and I wouldn't recommend putting Ruth Chris at the top of your list for steaks in the City. We were lured in by a $50 American Express promotional coupon. Had we not enjoyed the discount, we wouldn't have enjoyed the meal as much.

Ambiance and Service: There isn't much ambiance to speak of - the tables are very, very close together and the space feels cramped. Decor is not memorable and does not invoke the fabled feel of Harris or HOPR. Server was friendly, prompt and knowledgeable. The only service snafu was a good 20 minute wait between ordering and the appearance of our appetizers- with no acknowledgment from the server. 

The food: Crab cakes were absolutely awful. Not only did the crab taste "canned," (oily, mushy, etc) but there is clearly a fair amount of filler in the cakes and the whole dish becomes a greasy, mushy mess. For $20, skip it.  The steaks were, I'll admit, OUTSTANDING. Having not tried the butter on steak combination I was weary, but really, I didn't find the butter to be overwhelming. I thought it made the meat even more tender and delicious. The petit fillet was large enough that I took over half home for the next night's dinner.  Creamed spinach was better than average. We could really taste the spinach, not just the cream. Mashed potatoes had a layer of oil on top, were so pureed they reminded me of the re-hydrated potatoes out of a box and barely tasted of garlic. Sides were huge however- definitely share and be prepared to take home.
We didn't opt for dessert after such a heavy meal. 

Bottom Line: Skip it unless you have a promotional coupon that reduces the (high) price tag, and if you do go, get the best steak that you can ala carte.
author: Jenni D.

description:
Uh oh, am I going to be bashed for saying that in my opinion there's too much hype surrounding this place?  I know I know, I've already heard it from hubby who would give it 5 stars plus.

The atmosphere is nice... dimly lit, quiet, and fancy.  We went for Dine About Town and it was no problem getting the correct menu.

Hubby had the 12 oz. ribeye and I had the 6 oz fillet with shrimp.  I do admit that his steak was excellent.  The shrimp were also very good.  The fillet wasn't the most tender I've ever had and I haven't ever had fillet at a restaurant that charges Ruth's Chris prices.

The butter (I'm a total butter addict) was the best I've had in the U.S.  The bread was piping hot.  The creamed spinach and mashed potatoes were really good.  By the time we got to dessert, I'd had too much rich food already, so a bite into the chocolate sin cake made me queasy, but it was very very chocolatey and I'm sure no chocoholic would turn their nose up at it.

So with solid food and no real complaints, why the three stars instead of four?  For me, it's a matter of taste.  If I'm going to splurge on my calories as well as my money, I want food that I'm going to remember... that's going to have flavors that are an experience.  Here, a steak is a steak is a steak.  I can buy a good cut of meat from the butcher shop and slather it in butter and replicate this at home for a fraction of the price.

Would I dine at this restaurant again if it returns as a participant of Dine About Town?  Maybe.  Would I give away a gift certificate if I received it as a gift?  Depends on how much it's for... $100 or up, I'd probably be willing to fork out the rest for a dinner for two with my hubby.  Would I go there to eat at their normal prices?  Absolutely not... I have bills to pay!
author: Dani P.

description:
its not easy to have good steak.  it starts with a great cow, then a great cut, then how you broil and season it doesn't usually matter that much because the flavor of the meat is what you really want.  (MR is best though to really taste the meat)

SF does not have good meat.  or at least i have yet to find a piece of good steak in SF that is not some grade of wagyu.

i have had 3 different pieces of steak here and the meat was not very flavorful, had no textures or good marbling, kinda tasted like cardboard and made it so that even good wine could not salvage the meal.  like all disappointing steakhouses i try, i end up eating the baked potato in the steak juices (if there are any) and call it another bad steak night.
author: Wayne L.

description:
Mileu:
Nice Dark Wood Finished restaurant.  It looks like a high class restaurant.

Service:
Excellent.  Servers were on your beckon call pretty much.  You pretty much got a waiter to yourself.  Good service.

Food:
Their cowboy rib eye steak is excellent.  I love how half my plate is covered with butter.  So yummy.  i can most definitely go back here and eat.  Don't EVER forget to get their sweat potatoe crusted side order.  YOU MUST EAT IT.  It is the best thing ever.  Maybe I should not voice this out loud cuz it does run out.  I've had that happen to me before here and it ruined my dining experience.  Yes, it is that good.
author: M L.

description:
Way better than mortons, HOPR. Dine about town deal you just can't beat; 3 course w/ side, very staple selection. 12oz steak was very good; not sure if I believe the "1500F sear" and "500F plate". I'll bring an egg the next time...oh and i requested the blu cheese crust on my steak; made it o soo good!

 only gripe: if they say "steak house salad", does it mean it's a "steak house" salad, a "steak" house salad, or a house salad w/ steak?

it's a "steak house" salad; no steak in salad :(
author: Jeremy W.

description:
The service here was awesome! The waiter was so entertaining, and even told us of stories when the 49'ers would come and order hella food (of course, they're huge guys right??). 

We tried the kobe beef (mmmm, melts in your mouth) and chicken (ok). Mashed potato side dish was ok too, I liked the sweet potato pie better.

Seared ahi tuna appetizer is a must-order. SO GOOD.

Facility is small, but then again we were like a party of like 11. We were lucky to find a parking spot right on the street, in front of a guitar place right next door.
author: Meryl C.

description:
I'm not a big steak person but I really liked this place. The number one reason was the customer service. Staff was very attentive and polite. They also help suggest a perfect wine for whichever steak you so choose. The plate the steak comes out on is extremely hot and you're not suppose to touch it or you will get burned. Because I'm on a diet my gf and I ordered the summer special for 2 for 89.99. You get 2 petite cuts, 2 salads, 2 sides, and a dessert. I have to admit I found myself eating more of the sides than I did the steak. If you go there do order the potatoes Au gratin and creamed spinach. 

I'm not a connoisseur of steak but I think this place is great. Except for parking.
author: David W.

description:
High end steakhouse.  Pricey, but you get what you pay for right?  The service is amazing!  They also only serve but the best in quality.

The plates come out at a steaming hot 500degrees (or as stated!) to keep your food warm.

Yeah, so I totally forgot they told me that.

Dad: Do you want some of my chicken?

Me as I pick up plate; Oh sur... OW!

The folks at the restaurant immediately offered me cold water, a cold towel, some numbing burn cream, etc.  And checked in with me at least 3 times.  

The inside of the restaurant is a bit dark, even opposed to Hungry Hunter in South San Francisco too which is also a bit dim, and could be lightened up just a tad...
author: Leslie Y.

description:
My husband is a HUGE steak fan and this is his favorite steak house. He loves their ribeye and always orders that with a side of mashed or scalloped potatoes. I usually get the filet and a vegetable side dish. 

He loves everything about it, I love mostly how much he loves it and that's why I cannot ever dislike that place. However, for me personally, the steak is just floating in way too much butter, which I don't like. But the meat, side dishes, even appetizers were always lovely and I enjoyed our night out at this restaurant whenever we went.
author: Jana C.

description:
delicious!!  of course the service was impeccible and so was the food.

the scenery was very romantic and the place is very sheek.

the food just melted in my mouth!!  but i did burn myself when i accidently touched that hot plate ... (but it's such a good idea and it kept my food warm the entire time)
author: Pia V.

description:
One of the best meals I have had in town yet.

Dine About Town Week - we had no groceries for dinner, so decided to go out instead. I called up and they said if you come in before 6, we should be able to take you.

We quickly changed, and hiked over mouths watering for Steak!

They took us at the bar and were VERY nice and helpful.

We had the dine about town menu of salad, petite fliet, mashed potatoes and key lime pie and bread pudding  to boot.

It was heavenly. On a sizzling plate - the steak never got cold and the butter was delicious!

Success with a dine about town participant - for a chain, I was impressed... I mean it's no Izzy's in term of local flair - but izzy's also doesn't have sizzling plates!
author: Annie M.

description:
I was satisfied.  I had the Kobe beef which is always good seared.  I don't think it needed the butter on top.  The wine list is extensive.  Liquor abounds.  I ordered a vodka and soda water 12.50-it better'd been Grey Goose.  I digress.  This is a chain but it's full of regulars and b&t types like me.  
I liked it and would be a regular (as in every year) but I don't live in the city and I want to try the other steakhouses.
author: Frank A.

description:
I don't get what the hype about this place is. It steak with none of the fixes unless your order the sides. I got the Cowboy Ribeye steak cooked medium. It was more like medium well. For the sides we shared an order of asparagus, hash brown potatoes, and sauteed mushrooms. The hash browns were very good, and looked more like a pie. 

The steak looked quiet side alone sitting on the plate. There was no ajus sauce on the side, you have to order that as a side option. Horseradish at request. But getting the attention of the serve was slow process. 

The steak was good, the appetizers were good, but not great. Yes I would go back, but the prices are so outrageous, it would really have to be on special occasion.
author: Twist' D.

description:
I loved the Ribeye, and in reference to MaPu's post, I was sober for at least the first part of it, and it was damn close to char-broiled perfection.  Herbs and butter on top, potatoes, veggies (yes, cheese-laden spinach counts), and a bottle of vino.  Hard to top that.

I take away a star because this place serves items a la carte, and everything is damn expensive.  Worth the price if you can swing it, though.  :)
author: Derick P.

description:
Yes yes, this place has good steak. But you've got to have a bigger and better selling point than just good steak at a steak restaurant.

The mashed potatoes and creamed spinach were too much, too creamy and too over-the-top. The waiter was really nice to us, but he dinged us with the $30 worth of H20. Apparently he was feeding us bottles of mineral water and constantly filling, and each bottle was $10, and we went through three. We had no idea about any of this, so what should have been a not-so-expensive dinner turned out to be pretty pricey cause of that damned water!

I was so full after the steak I forgot what we got for dessert, cause I didn't eat it. But, I think it was some kind of bread pudding? It obviously wasn't too good otherwise you bet I would have had some.
author: ting b.

description:
Two stars for service
One star for food
I have always heard wonderful things about Ruth's, so last year my husband took me here for Valentine's day. The service was excellent, but the food lacked miserably. Everything is al la carte and extremely overpriced for the quality. The thing that sticks out in my head the most is their potato au gratin...if you are going to charge close to $ 10 for potatoes at least make sure they are fresh and not frozen. My husband is a chef , so when we go out to eat he points out all the good and especially the bad. I started of with the lobster bisque, it was very nasty. The consistency was lacking by all means, it tasted lumpy and gritty. Very gross. I dont recall the steak , so it was'nt all that great. It didnt leave a lasting impression on us, and Im unsure of what the fuss is all about. Be prepared to spend money here.
author: Lori T.

description:
One of many steak houses that I've tried and I think it's the most priciest that I've been to so far.  The food was great, I had a prime rib but I also tried some of the porterhouse cut from my cousin.  The prime rib I had was medium rare just the way I like it but next time I'll probably get rare because the meat literally cooks on your plate since it's so hot.  So by the time i get to the end, my medium rare became a medium.  The bread with butter... is freakin good.  Not something you want to fill up on but I love butter and it was light fluffy butter...... mmMmm.  

The service was good, the waiter refilled water frequently and checked on us to see if everything was ok.  Also had a sense of humor so thats always a plus. Place is pricey but i give it 5 stars for great food
author: Warren G.

description:
Meat: phenomenally tender, delish, though a leetle too salty and pricey.
Sides: salty and bad for you*
Dessert: totally skippable
Decor:  Gentleman's club (not that kind) of yore
Service: They put up with one wriggly toddler and 3 maniacally giggling adults who brought their own decorations, so...good on them.
Sum:  If you want your out-of-town visitors to spend a lot for feeling disturbingly full, this is your spot.  

*That creamed spinach hits a certain spot, though.
author: sheena b.

description:
The steak is good, service is decent, ambiance isn't bad, but the price is too high for what you get. Sure it's "prime," but I just feel that for the bank breaking prices, you should be able to get something a little more...BLA-DOW. 

Besides the price, the only other complaint is the chain-franchise factor. Poor waiters gotta give you the spiel about the meat, and wear cheesy uniforms, and the overall ambiance reminds you of a hyped up apple-bees. Even franchise chains could hire some designers to establish some decent decor and appearance to their restaurants. 

Maybe I'm just old school. Let me find some old as dirt steakhouse where the cook has been making steaks for 40 years and the booths look like old hotel couches and I'll be happy.
author: JT X.

description:
Long wait even with reservation. Probably a lot of people love this place.

Too much butter in their food. It was not so good and oily. Good for the butter lovers.

Service just ok. 

The last time there was a while ago, and it was probably the last time.
author: friendly b.

description:
Tried Ruth's Chris for the first time the other night.  I think it was one of the best steaks I have ever had - it was like butter!!  Got the Filet prepared medium rare, with the pepper creme sauce on the side.  I ate the whole thing - it was perfect.

The BBQ shrimp we started with was really good too.  They have entree size as well.

Bread was warm; salad split for 2; service was on pointe.  I have no complaints and look forward to goign back.
author: BeatsEats K.

description:
Nah not good.  Fried Steak for tons of money basted in butter and so hot I can not touch it.  Nope.  No thanks.  For a chain, I have had better still.  Harris's and Bobo's still better.  go there for a better meal.  

Also, made a reservation and still had to wait 30 minutes for my table in the back so we would spend money at the bar.  Tricky.  Wrong move.
author: Doreen D.

description:
My boyfriend took me here for our past anniversary... yumm! Part of me felt bad because it was also his birthday and he paid the bill... (Actually, it's not my problem he asked me to be with him on his birthday, right?)

Aren't boyfriends supposed to pay for anniversary dinners??? ;)

Anyways, dinner was soo scrumptious! I'm not a big steak eater, but who knew that butter tastes soo good on steaks! I ordered the filet and my bf order this humongous steak -- I forget which one. The side orders we're pretty generous and delicious, we got the mashed potatoes, asparagus, baked potato, and the sautéed mushrooms. For dessert, we got cheesecake, which I didn't care for too much... but overall the dinner was great.

Plenty of food left over, so the next day was a treat all over again.
author: RACHELE D.

description:
This place does not disappoint. This was my second time eating here through Dine About Town and I left happy both times.

We ordered the rib eye steak, mashed potatoes, creamed spinach, bread pudding and apple tart. Everything was great. Rib eye was drenched in butter, perfectly seasoned, and cooked well (medium rare and medium). The mashed potatoes were simple, but delicious. The creamed spinach wasn't too overwhelming, perfectly seasoned. I liked the bread pudding more than the apple tart. The apple tart was a bit too sweet for me, but it came with ice cream so that helped to cut the sweetness.

Overall, great restaurant. I wouldn't suggest going here if you prefer restaurants that are on the quieter side, because it can get pretty loud in there. My only complaint about that is that the waiters don't really do much to make sure people maintain a moderate volume level to prevent irritable customers. It didn't bother me much, but I can see how it would bother others.
author: Michelle P.

description:
Ruth's Chris is a premium steakhouse that has a well-deserved reputation. If you want a special meal, have out of town guests, etc. You can't go wrong.

I went during Dine About Town, and got the special rate. For the special rate, it was certainly worth the price. If I had to pay full price, however, I may have had second thoughts. 

The ribeye I found decent, but nothing spectacular, and when you go to a high-end steak house, spectacular is expected. On the other hand, the filet lived up to expectations. Highly recommended.

The markup on the wine seems to be a bit over the top. Bringing your own will give you the satisfaction of getting what you want, as well as not feeling you are being taken advantage of.
