My lamb tasted really gamy but my friends liked their dishes. they had t-bone, filet minion, and rib eye. the one friend that had rib eye told me it tasted better last time he had it here. im definitely getting something else if i come back. wished the lamb tasted better.
author: Linda A.

description:
Ruth Chris: One of my favorite place to go for steak.

Been here for so many times! 

Every time I come here, I ordered the same thing -  Rib-eye. Mouth watering!! The butter just hit the spot. The meat is sooo juicy and tender!

-1 star for their unfriendly service.
author: Olivia H.

description: my family and I had an amazing time here. good service, good food, and good ambiance...nothing can beat that overall satisfaction. this will be another favorite added to places we like to eat at...=)
author: Foodie F.

description: The best-est ribeye ever! Who would of thought, serving steak covered in sweet sizzling hot butter!? Awwwwwwwww yeah!
author: Dirty S.

description:
The selection of sides here is a bit old-fashioned but that doesn't make them any less tasty.  Memorable dishes included the crab-stuffed mushrooms, calamari, and mashed potatoes. 

Most people including myself ordered the ribeye.  Everything is saturated with butter which makes it all the better-- my steak came medium (I usually get medium rare) but it was still tender and moist.

Service was prompt and friendly and they took good care of our group of 13.  Price-wise you get a pretty good deal with the combination-- full-sized soup/salad, entree, and dessert for $40 or $50 depending on the entree.  Steaks a la carte are in the $40+ range.

All in all a great place. People may hate on Ruth's Chris for all the butter they use to make up for not-as-good meat, but as long as it tastes good, I'm not complaining.
author: S L.

description: Get the freak outta my way! These are the BEST stuffed mushrooms on the planet!  Love their rib eye and garlic mashed potatoes. My meal was perfectly prepared and delicious. Served piping hot with the freshest of ingredients. They know how to serve food. Yum.
author: Isabella L.

description:
Service: 5/5
Food: 4/5
Wait: 4.5/5
Price: $$$
Presentation of food: 4/5
Presentation of restaurant: 4.5/5
Overall: 4.5/5

our server Jesse was super ultra friendly and very attentive. He made our first time experience here a great one. the boyfriend and I had came here for there Dinner Set Menu (Dine About Town) which is like $35-$40/per person with appetizer, entree, and dessert. I had their Chicken stuffed with cheese, the chicken was great but the cheese was overwhelming; its not a layer of cheese but literally cheese everywhere once you cut into the chicken. It was a big portion as well, I had to take the rest to go! lol. came with a side of either mash potatoes or cream spinach, I had the Mash Potatoes which was really REALLY good I must say. We started off with their salad that needed a tad bit more Balsamic Vinaigrette. Dessert was a little slice of chocolate cake with a side cup of small fruits and some sort of yogurt I think. It was good, the cake was a little dry though. But overall my experience here was great.
author: Eva H.

description: Steak was amazing, but the service from our waitress was absolutely horrible. Our salad came out at the very end of our meal and I had to ask the waiter 5 times before I received my drink. We complained to the manager and she gave us a gift card.
author: anna s.

description: Softest steak ever. Their berries & cream is astonishing - I order it every time. This is my favorite steakhouse.  Be prepared for a hefty check though.
author: Fiona M.

description: We managed to get a last minute reservation there.  Absolutely loved the ambiance and service.   Our steaks were good but next time we will order them a little less done, because they do cook on the plate.  We had the fixed price menu, which was good value for money.  The wine that was recommended was wonderful too.  The staff go out of their way to make your meal a special experience.
author: Cara P.

description: Came here last night, wasn't really that impressed. Last time I was here was for my Senior Ball in highschool, so i figured I'd give this place another shot. I took the bf here since I owed him dinner. Since he loves steak, he chose this place. I guess I could be biased since I was a vegetarian and isn't really fond of red meat anyways. I ordered the Petite Filet and Shrimp. The shrimp was good and the mignon was tender, but it tasted soo.... ugh... meaty and bloody... My bf NY strip was very very firm and had to return it since it was too tough. He got a filet mignon instead. The bread was good, my lobster bisque soup was okay, the texture was weird and it got cold super fast! Overall, it was okay, but not worth $150. I wish I would've spent my $150 at Roys... Boo. Oh yeah, and our server wasn't that attentive... Double BOO.
author: Jojo N.

description:
Let me begin by mentioning that this is my first review on Yelp.  My experience at Ruth's Chris last night made me inclined to create a Yelp account to save future diners from having the same experience as myself.

To note, I've eaten here on at least 4 prior occasions- eating both off of the a la carte menu as well as the dine about town menu.  This review is for the dine about town experience.

To begin, we were 15 minutes early for our 7:30 reservation and had a seat at the bar.  At 7:40 I checked on our reservation status at which point I was informed that they were still seating 7:15 tables and we were at the top of the list for the 7:30's.  At 8:05, we were brought to our table.

Our server was fine, but certainly not what I'd expect from a restaurant of this caliber.

When it came time to order, my girlfriend opted for the $39.99 Chef's Menu with the Filet and Shrimp as her entree.  I selected the $49.99 option with the Ribeye.

The salads were delicious.  Delicious enough to earn the 2 stars I've given.  When the steaks came out the experience, for me, took a turn for the worse.

My Ribeye was so incredibly tough and chewy that it was profoundly difficult to even cut through.  I've eaten ribeyes here before from the a la carte menu and this simply wasn't Ruth's Chris quality steak.  They clearly ordered inferior cuts of beef to serve as part of their tasting menu.

Frankly, I feel taken advantage of.  Perhaps if you're not willing to take a shave off of the margin of your ribeye, don't have the ribeye as an option.  Or at least give the customer a heads up that they're not receving the same quality cut that they may have experienced in the past.

Considering the other quality steakhouses in SF (Harris', HOPR, etc.), this will be my last time at Ruth's Chris.
author: Jim W.

description:
Fabulous steakhouse! Wonderful atmosphere! We went on a Friday night at 7 pm and were not rushed out of the restaurant by any means, we didn't end up leaving there until around 10 pm. We went to celebrate a birthday and the tables was decorated with "HAPPY BIRTHDAY" confetti, a really cute touch. The staff are all wonderful and offer great suggestions for meal choices. I got a stuffed chicken dinner with green beans and mashed potatoes and might I say YUMMY! I also got their sweet potato side dish, to share, and I honestly have to say they are the best sweet potatoes I have ever had in my life!!!!!!! I could have eaten a plate of just sweat potatoes. 

The only negative comment that I have about the entire restaurant, menu, and food is the bread they serve. The restaurant is in San Francisco so you would think that they would take advantage of the local bakeries and offer some fresh baked bread. Nope, the bread is nothing special by any means
author: Nicole L.

description:
Three great things about Ruth's Chris:

Number 1: Excellent Steak
Number 2: Excellent Steak
Number 3: Excellent Steak

Don't go there looking for the "in crowd" go there if you are looking for steak that you can cut with a butter knife. 

It's like little tiny pieces of heaven that you get to eat!
author: Isaac N.

description:
Sure, you're looking at a bill of about $90-$130/person, but the Ruth's Chris experience is well worth it. I never thought I'd say such a thing about a restaurant, but this place is THAT exceptional. 

My favorite dishes? I love the filet mignon with the blue cheese crust, and for dessert, the bread pudding.

UPDATED 05/03/08:
Changed my rating from 5 stars to 4. Went back recently, and my steak was clearly medium-well to well-done, when I asked for medium. The food is still outstanding, but I do expect my steak to be cooked exactly as requested--always--especially for the price you're paying to dine there!!
author: J K.

description:
I'm sort of still wondering how I ended up here, especially since I don't eat red meat.  But beggars can't be choosers.  (Translate: I didn't pay for the meal.)

Actually, I'd probably go back just for the crab cakes.   

For the entree I had the salmon, and it was a huge, huge portion.  (Note: Don't gorge yourself on the bread, no matter how warm and tasty they may look.)  It was one of the most flavorful salmon I've ever had, with hints of both sugar and spice.  Didn't have dessert, unfortunately, cos, did I mention the warm and delicious bread?  Okay good.

Our server was also extremely attentive, and even though our dishes took over 20 minutes to come, she made sure our drinks (and the delicious warm bread) were always filled.  

The only cons I could think of was the price, the dim lighting (seriously, why do all upscale restaurants insist on dim lights?  They make my head hurt), and the large amount of oil that my salmon swam in.  Then again, that's probably why it tasted so good.
author: Kelly C.

description:
Ok, so Ruth's Chris is a chain...but the steak was good.  The thing is, I like prime ribs and definitely House of Prime Ribs makes it better than Ruth Chris.  The service was good, the portion was huge, and the ambiance is so-so. 

Here was the menu:

Lobster Bisque: good, but I had better.
Green Salad: hmmm....just like any other
Crab cakes: pretty good
Tuna: didn't like it
French fries: nothing special
Buffalo prime rib: good
Baked potato: just like any other
Mashed potato: " "
Broccoli: just steamed
Molten chocolate cake: very good!!! I liked this the best.

Overall, the dinner was average chain steakhouse; like I mentioned earlier, I prefer House of Prime Ribs.  This is a good restaurant if you're looking for meat.  Keep in mind that it is very very buttery.
author: Jenifer T.

description:
This place was about to get 3 stars for my past experiences but they decided to serve me the best ribeye i've ever had.  I swore ive had it here before and I certainly know the filet well.  However, the fates that be decided to make this one steak better than the rest before and the memory of the taste still lingers.  I know the previous steaks have been adequate-good, but to knock it out of the park without any warning.  Sigh. 

I wonder why the quality is inconsistent.  No matter.  I feel lucky to get such a choice steak.  However, I have my doubts on the next time.
author: Blake S.

description: I normally love Ruth Chris but this one was the worst ever. Took my friends that were visiting from Austrailia to this one while we were in SF for Halloween. I figured it would be as good as the ones in Orange County where I live. But NO. The Lobster bisque had ZERO meat in it. Was just broth. When I asked they said It was the last of what was left sorry. Then my stuffed chicken wasn't cooked enough and was rare inside like a steak! I mentioned it and they took it away and forgot to bring it back. Then when they started clearing our food I asked where my chicken was. And they forgot! It was halloween so they were in a hurry to close. So we got rushed, bad food and terrible service. I was very disappointed. The bill was over $300 for that nightmare. I called later to complain to management and they said they would refund part of the meal by gift card in the mail. Never recieved it. Will NEVER go back to this Ruth Chris. I love the other 8 I have been to though.
author: Cynthia D.

description: This is my FAVORITE restaurant. Who wouldn't like filet mignon that comes on a 500 degree plate w melted butter? Plus, if you get the meal deal you can get a side, salad, steak, and dessert for like $40.
author: El G.

description: cowboy ribeye + creamed spinach + sweet potato casserole + a glass of 2006 cab=heaven  i will definitely be back here.
author: Maureen A.

description:
My husband and I Went to Ruth's Chris Steak House for the first time last night to celebrate an early Valentines Day Dinner . when I had called to make reservations, they asked me if we were celebrating a special occasion and I told them No, just an early valentines day, so when we arrived they had our table set with little sequin hearts all over it ( we were the only table set like that)
Also the bartender Andy was amazing, he made the best margarita I had ever tasted! 
as for the food! PERFECT!!!  yes its expensive but you get what you pay for! 
To sart out we had mushrooms stuffed with crab,  good size portion for an appetizer, we also had the wedge salad which was very fresh and the blue cheese dreeing had big chunks of cheese.
I had the fillet mignon and husband had the cowboy rib eye, we had 3 side dishes that we shared...sweet potatoe casserole, sooo yummy, it was like having dessert with dinner , we also had the asparagus with hollandaise sauce,, that was cooked to perfection, then we had the garlic mashed potatoes, very creamy and flavorful! believe it or not we had desset after all that, I had the bread pudding with whiskey sauce and husband had the chocolate carmelized banana pie! 
from the service, to the drinks and down to the dessert everything was fabulous and I can not wait to go back!!! this is my new favorite restaurant!!!
author: Jody B.

description: Love this place.  I can't give it 5 stars because it is not five star service or five star food but it is really really good.  Its very consistent.  I always know when I go there I'm gonna get good food.  The sides are great to take for breakfast the day.  I'll always go back.
author: Amy W.

description:
So far one of the better places I've tried in the bay area. The service was pretty good. Our waitress speaks with a smile on her face. It really shows that she appreciates our business. 

I ordered the ribeye medium rare, bf ordered their special kobe style ribeye, medium. Our steaks literally came out sizzling on the plate just like as the waitress described. Ordered two sides, fresh broccoli and the lyonnaise potatoes. They were both pretty good. The kobe beef was very tender but of course it can't top the kobe beef we had in Japan. My ribeye was decent. It was juicy but not as tender as I thought it would be but very flavorful. The proportions was just right. I was able to finish my ribeye and we finished our two sides. He had to pack his kobe back tho.

For dessert we had their speical the molten chocolate cake. pretty good, not too sweet just how i like it. I love how molten chocolate cakes are topped off with the ice cream. The cold ice cream and the warm cake mixed together just makes my taste buds jump all over the  place.

Great experience overall. This restaurant isn't very roomy but I like how the tables are bigger than many other restaurants. I hate it when two people are crammed into a tiny table. But most restaurants are like that and I have no option but to bare with it. Luckily it's not like that here or at least I haven't noticed any yet.
author: Flora W.

description: I felt the menu was over priced even though I enjoyed the food I have been to other restuarants that I feel are comprable and were not as expensive. That being said, The steak was wonderful and I enjoyed the mashed potatoes and creme carmel for desert.
author: Carrie M.

description:
Two words, Ruth's Chris. Best steak in town and probably #1 on list of top restaurants. I like to keep it simple, so I usually just order the 3 course meal. My favorite selection would be the seafood gumbo appetizer, a mashed potato side, and the world famous filet mignon steak. Word has it that the filets they use are strictly from corn fed cows and the steaks are marinated through a special dry-aging process. This makes a super tender, buttery filet that melts in your mouth and blows any other steaks out the water. Oh, and they also add a couple fancy little tasty shrimps on top as well. The mashed potatoes are deliciously creamy and the sea food gumbo makes a great appetizer. I've also heard a lot about Ruth's Chris's Potato Au Gratin, but haven't given it a try yet. Next time for sure. Always be careful and watch your hands when they serve you, as the plate comes out sizzling. Wash this all down with a tall glass or two of red wine and you got yourself a 5 star meal! I would also highly suggest you to make a reservation before coming in and if youre wondering, there is also valet parking in the front. If this doesn't fit your budget, no worries, keep your eyes out for the annual dine about town specials. You'll be able to get deals on various resturaunts around SF that can save you a pretty little penny.

I've also tried the Ruth's Chris in Fresno, Ca(Sadly, it is a chain). No valet there, but the steaks are equally amazing and the venue is a little bigger.
author: thai n.

description: Great place for all kinds of food. I went for lunch on Easter and me and my friend had a great time. The food was excellent. I only dont give 5 stars for 2 things: the mash potatos wasn't as good as I expected to eat in any steak house or restaurant. The other thing was that the service wasn't the best, even though the waiter was very friendly and try the best that she could. What make me want to comeback:the meat Off course,  ceasar salad, thin fries, and the coffe
author: Alex M.

description: Recently dined here with my boy. Superb service. Ordered the filet mignon. the meat melts in your mouth(i know you've heard that phrase before, not too original) but it really does.Oh the house bread and butter excellent.I wanted to get a doggie bag just for that house bread and butter.Our waiter is great. For sure we are coming back.
author: joe p.

description:
Went to Ruth's Chris Steak House last night to celebrate a friend's birthday dinner.  The interior of the restaurant is quite nice, dark wooden walls, dim lighting and comfortable booths all give it a nice ambiance.  Right when I sat down though, the person seating us told me flip flops are not allowed in the restaurant.  I understand the restaurant states a casual work attire, but I say men wearing a T-shirt and jeans and even shorts.  So to talk to me about my flip flops and how inappropriate it is in the restaurant, a little difficult for me to excuse them and let it go.

There was a lack of service till the check came, then the service picked up a little which was a little annoying.  As for the food, over priced and not even close to what I expected it to be.

For the appetizer, we ordered the fried calamari which was a little too sweet everyone.  For the entree, I picked the lamb chops with Au Gratin potatoes and sauteed mushrooms, while the friend got a fillet steak with the cream spinach and garlic mash potatoes.  I had requested the lamb chops to be cooked medium rare and it came to me practically fully cooked.  There was a lot of fat on the lamb chops and some parts were even burnt.  The Au Gratin had a decent flavor, but they sliced the potatoes were way overly thick to enjoy.  The fillet steak was not even warm but close to being chilled when I tried it.  The cream spinach was bland and as well as the garlic mash potatoes, which was also a little thick and chunky for my taste.

Overall, I expected a lot more quality from this place especially at the price they charge.
author: Kamui K.

description:
My husband and I have dined at Ruth's Chris twice -- and both times, had to wait for a table for about 30 minutes despite having a reservation. About a dozen other people were also waiting. I don't care how busy it is, a reservation means you shouldn't have to wait, or go to the bar and start drinking before your food. However, our waiter was friendly and helpful with my special dietary needs.

The food was good but not great, considering the price and the wait. My cocktail (Hemingway Daiquiri) was the platonic ideal of cocktails taste-wise, but the ice wasn't fully crushed which made it seem cheap. The menu seems to cater toward a very non-San Francisco taste, since it's a chain I suppose, with very greasy, potato-y, or cheesy sides, and butter on the steaks which is completely unnecessary. Butter on a $70 kobe ribeye? Is that really necessary? Sugar and pecans on the "sweet potatoes" (which I'm pretty sure was actually yams) -- also not necessary.
author: Erica M.

description:
Great food & great service.

The family & I frequent this establishment. We almost always get the same items off the menu. A couple of cowboy rib-eyes sizzling in butter, a medium & a medium well, mashed potatoes, spinach, crab cakes, lobster bisque, kids' steak (careful w/ HOT plate!) & creme brulee. Their food is solid. You can't go wrong. They are also very efficient at giving more bread & butter that we end up taking a lot home. Free breakfast in the morning-even better.

We have celebrated a few special occasions here & this place could easily be our favorite steak house. I love the manner in which they address us-Mr. & Mrs. + our last name. They even say "sir" when speaking to our son. Very classy. Service is consistently excellent.

I do realize that this is a chain of restaurants-I don't mind. No food snob here.
author: foodi e.

description: i went to ruth chris to celebrate my birthday. food was fantastic and I had a wonderful time.
author: Hieu C.

description: The filet was phenomenal!!! The best steak ever.  The entire experience was so special and fabulous. I loved it!
author: Kira K.

description: Sunday, Octorber 21, 2012, 6pm.  The reception greeting ladies were very rude.  I am a regular.  I live up the street.  They could not figure out how or where to seat me.  Asked to wait.  Waitpeople kept coming up and asking what was going on.  They said they were trying to figure it out.  The preparation on my steak was terrible.  Sent back once could have sent back again.  Asked for medium and came out bright red in middle.  Sent back and checked to find it was now almost well done.  I do better at home and I am not a professional kitchen.  No comp for bad steak.  Other tables sending back and many got comps.  Bad night?  Maybe.  But I won't be rolling down the hill again this year. jmo
author: jerome m.

description: I am the biggest fan of Ruth's Chris Steakhouse, the first time my husband and I went was in San Diego to celebrate one of our anniversarys for being together. One of our friends said if we love steak we should try it. So we did, and ever since we cant get enough. I suggest eating the filet mignon, it is to die for!!!! it melts in your mouth. the only thing that sucks is that the main  entree or anything does not come with sides.And almost everything is a la carte. but if you are ever in the area I say try it!!! It is sooo delicious! they also have other locations not just San Francisco and San Diego. Just go to their website www.ruthschris.com to find other locations.
author: Reyditha E.

description:
i honestly dont know how to rate this place. food turned out to be okay but i had a good time.  not sure if it's because of the atmosphere or my awesome date.  anyhow, from the DAT menu, we had:

APPETIZER:
-GREEN SALAD ... i love their croutons. best ever.. tastes like cheeto puffs.  but they only place two of these suckers on the plate. bummer

ENTREES:
-BLUE CHEESE CRUSTED RIBEYE  ... i didnt finish this. i actually took my date's filet instead.  but i do love the blue cheese crust
-PETITE FILET ... it's okay. better than the rib-eye.  then again, i prefer filet over ribeye anyway

SIDES:
-CREAM SPINACH ... go ahead and skip this one
-MASHED POTATOES ...  this is yummy. well seasoned.

DESSERTS:
-KEY LIME  ... delicious!  very refreshing after a heavy meal
-BREAD PUDDING  ... it's okay

i wish i could remember the wine we had. it was good.

not sure if i'll ever be back due to the prices here.   if the food's fantastic i probably would but definitely worth it for DAT.
author: Joanne H.

description: Ruth's Chris Steak House is a great place to get a really good ribeye; bone in or bone out.  The service is really great and the surrounding is very elegant.  Our server was Jesse and he did a great job describing the menu and warning us about the hot plates.  The benefit of the hot plate was to make it so that your steak stayed nice and hot throughout the entire meal.  I would definitely recommend this place to anyone who enjoys a good steak
author: Jason D.

description:
I swear I've written a review for Ruth's Chris before.  Did the infamous YELP monster eat my review?  

I came to Ruth's Chris about 2 weeks ago to take advantage of the Dine About Town special.  We had made a reservation for 6:30 on a Friday night and was expecting huge crowds as it was also the last weekend of the DAT special.  I was correct.  There were tons of people waiting outside and to top it off we almost missed our reservation.  The traffic on the bridge was horrible (it was the same weekend as the A's vs Giants series).  So we called to to let them know we are on our way and would be about 15 mins late.  They indicated they only hold the reso for 15 minutes and then will give it away.  Thankfully we got there in 14 minutes and was seated immediately.  Our waiter was top notch and the food was delicious.  My wife had the DAT special 10oz rib eye and I decided to go with the "Summer Special" which for $15 more than DAT got me the regular size cut of beef, better choices of salads and any of their desserts (not limited to one choice like the DAT menu).  The waiter suggested a great glass of wine to be paired with our meal and over all superb dining experience.
author: Henry S.

description:
went there last night for a friends birthday and i was very disappointed...

seems like i was the only one that hasnt gone there, so i was pretty excited to hear that we had made reservations to eat there...no matter how bad i thought the food was last night, i suppose its still a "landmark" restaurant in the City and a place everyone should go eat at least once...

menu was pretty simple, which is what i prefer when i go to a steakhouse.

staff was pretty friendly.

oh Lord the food....

we started out with the beef carpaccio appetizer...
the beef was cut razor thin...so thin that we had to scrape it off the plate to "spread" it on like pate onto the croustini it came with...also the sauce that they spread on to of the carpaccio was very "BLAH"...all in all a pretty bad dish that i would never get again...

second course was the salad...
i asked if they had a similar salad that was comparable to that of the "other" place right down the street that has the BEST SALAD EVER (h.o.p.r.)...the waiter told me sorry because he had never gone there before as he was not a big fan of prime rib! ahahahah....anyhow, i ordered the caesar salad...the salad was okay...little too salty for me, but might have been salty because of the mountain of parm rigi that they threw into the salad! 

finally the main course!  16 oz rib eye ordered med/rare...
came out on a sizzling flat iron covered in butter or some other grease...first cut into the meat was bad...second cut into the meat was bad...third cut into the meat....u get the idea right?...the meat was cooked perfectly med/rare as i asked BUT it just wasnt tender...i know that the rib eye cuts are usually leaner with less marbling than other pieces, but mine was a little too tough...the flavor on the meat considering it was soaking in butter was not that great either...and there wasnt much of a crust on my steak either...i eventually asked for some creamy horseradish to help get the steak down and it did help...but i ended up taking a doggie bag for the leftover steak to re-marinate for taco night later this week...

note: everyone i talked to told me to get the hash brown as a side because it was sooooooo tasty....
it wasnt.  it was just a big ass hashbrown that was cooked well with a nice crispy crust, with some parsley sprinkled over it...they have the same thing at IHOP and DENNY'S if any of you are into hash browns...

all in all...didnt like it...dinner came out to 280 (including 20percent grat.)  would i go again? if youre paying im in...if its ur birthday and you want steak....i got a big G. Foreman Grill at the house that puts a great crust on any piece of steak for ya!
author: Kyu L.

description:
I take my pen (keyboard) to proclaim that, for my money, this is my favorite steakhouse in the area. Other than Alexander's (which I refuse to go to because I do not like some of the investors), I have been to most of the better steakhouses in the area like Morton's and Harris'.  Even so, my favorite steakhouse by far continues to be Ruth's Chris.  

There's nothing particularly special about the appetizers. The salads are decent and the seared ahi is pretty good, but obviously people are here for the steak so that's what my rating is based on.  Man, and what a steak it is!  My favorite cut is the ribeye and it's FABULOUS.  Sure, the prodigious amounts of butter may have a little something to do with it, but frankly, that's a cheat I wish more steakhouses would use. Ribeyes are already a nice fat cut of beef, but the butter just elevates the entire steak.  Moreover, I like how the steak is served on what is essentially the American equivalent of a sizzling platter (I end up holding my napkin up protectively over my face and clothes like I would when ordering anything teppanyaki).  That extra sear seems to make the steak even more tasty.  However, because the sizzling platter continues to cook the meat, I would recommend that people order their steaks one degree less well-done than they would typically prefer, and to turn the steak over after a few minutes.  I've also had the filet, which I didn't think was nearly as good as the ribeye, but I'm partial to ribeye so to each their own. 

The sides here are pretty good.  Their garlic mashed is also topped with a crapload of butter, making it even richer and more delicious. The vegetables were run of the mill but the bread is great. It's french baguette-ish, always nice and hot, and absolutely perfect for sopping up all that steak/butter juice.  I don't think I've had a single good dessert here but I've found that the steak is so good it doesn't matter.  I do recommend getting a big steak, even knowing you won't finish it, because the leftovers are nearly just as good and it's such a great feeling to know you have an awesomely decadent lunch in your near future. I usually ask the waiter to pack the bread as well and I don't care if it does look sheisty, so there!
author: Tammy L.

description:
I had been hearing how great this place was for years.  When we wanted to try a new spot for our anniversary we decieded on Ruth's Chris. 

Wow what a mistake!  The best thing about this place was the decor and service.  

When the hot bread arrived I thought I was going to be in for a treat.  I ordered the petit filet and shrimp and my husband ordered the lobster and  steak.  Immediately the flavor was bland on the shrimp and the steak.  Then I ordered the separate sides, creamed spinach and baked potato and tomato salad.  The creamed spinach was missing something it didn't taste good at all.  I couldn't eat it. The best part of the meal was the baked potato.  My husbands lobster was overcooked and dry.  

For the amount of money we spent on our dinner I was hoping for a realllllyyyyy good meal.  Now I know I will go to Izzy's next time.

I don't know how anyone could come back to this place.

I will not recommend this to anyone!
author: Serena T.

description: It was an excellent place for anniversary. This is the top of the line choice for special occasions. The food looked and tasted like made just for you and the quality service made me feel that I picked the right restaurant. Noise level is medium. The only inconvenience is you must make reservation almost a week ahead of schedule because this place is busy. I would definitely go back again for the food and service.
author: Luke L.

description: This is my fourth time here. I can't explain how amazing the food is. I am always satisfied when I come here.. The first time I had the New York Steak . It was tender and it was also cooked perfectly. I also had the rib eye which is the best. The rib eye just melts in your mouth. I tired the fillet and it was a okay. I'm not a huge fan of fillet. I recommend getting the mash potatoes as a side. The string beans are a little bit too salty. And the pear martini is the best.......I would love to common here often but its very pricey.......
author: Tiffany L.

description: Got the filet medium w some cabernet.. about $65 + tip.. One of the best tasting steak I have ever had. Desserts are pretty good too.
author: R G.

description:
hands-down, one of my fave steak houses.

not just because my first experience was a special night shared w/ hubby as we trudged up the hill from the orpheum theater to catch an early dinner before watching miss saigon for my bday (it was a hike up but definitely worth it!)

not just because it was where i was first introduced to malbec.

and not just b/c my mother-in-law's name is ruth and my middle name is chris(tine). LOL.

no, i love ruth's chris b/c every visit is rewarded with consistently excellent service and food.

hubby and i celebrated vday here and were once again treated to a memorable experience.  after booking weeks in advance (and only finding rezzies available at 5:45 or 9:00) we were prepared to meet a crowd.  sure enough, it took about 20 minutes to get seated and they weren't taking walk-ins.  but no problem....definitely worth the wait.

our waiter, scott, was incredibly gracious, charming and knowledgable.  hubby and i opted to order off the vday special menu - he got the ribeye and i got the filet.  both came with tasty ceasar salads (perhaps a tad salty), a choice of side, and a preselected dessert.

i ordered my filet medium-well - sacrilege, i know, but i'm filipino and grew up on tough well-done t-bones! =P i'm learning to appreciate a pink center but i'm always wary that for chefs, medium is closer to rare...scott wisely recommended that the filet be butterflied, given its thickness and it came out perfectly - nice and rosy but not at all bloody, nor tough at all- just the right match for my glass of malbec.  hubby's ribeye was rich and fatty in an indulgent bad-but-so-good way.  he even commented that not once did he need to reach for the salt-shaker, which he ALWAYS does, even before tasting his food sometimes - a true sign of well-seasoned (perhaps salty for some) food!  he couldn't finish his 16oz cut but i had no problem w/ my 11oz portion! plus yummy garlic mashed potatoes and i helped hubby w/ his creamed spinach.

both of us had the special vday dessert - a mini chocolate mousse served in a chocolate shell (so creamy good, not too rich and w/ a taste similar to chocolate cheesecake) and a berry-topped sweet cream (like a zabalgione).  the perfect ending to a perfect dinner.

bonus: $10 valet!
author: Jen P.

description: i think that among all the steakhouse chains, this is the best one. I love their tbone steak and the shoestring fries... suupper awesome. very good place to eat with families and friends.
author: Laura t.

description: I love coming here whether it is for a special occasion or just a friday,saturday night to come and fine dine. One of the best steak houses around. If you do not mind spending at least $100 for a wonderful dinner and experience this is the place. The app.soup or salad with your main and desert i'd recommend. You can always share as well. Just wonderful filet mignon, Best I have ever had anywhere.
author: Bob M.

description:
Pricey but good. 
Don't bother getting any sides, they're all bad. but the meat is fantastic and the deserts are GREAT! but again, don't waste your time on any side dishes... you wont really eat them. $7 is highway robbery for 4 asparagus anyway- god damn
author: Rich V.

description:
Harris'   GREATER THAN   Ruth's Chris

this is why;

-  ageist hostess sat us in the bar area (even with reservation!)
-  server spoke like he was an elementary school teacher
-  filet was dry, over cooked for my liking
-  "steak salad" does not have steak in it
-  salad and desserts tasted like they had been sitting out a while

not bothering to go back when there are TONS of great places to get a quality steak in sf.  ruths chris is absolutely overpriced and ambiance caters to people over the age of 60.
author: E. R.

description:
I must say Im  a big Ruths Chris fan.  By far my favorite restaurant for steaks.  They're always so tender and juicy. 

I also love most of their sides.  They have a great spinach salad.  

Now it does get a bit pricey which is why I dont frequent as often as Id like to, but worth the money in my opinion.
author: stephen s.

description: Not for me.  I wanted steak, not butter.  My stomach was not happy after dinner.  Plus the price.. ouch!  I should have talked to their loan officer first to see if I qualify for dinner.  I like to taste more meat.  Otherwise, service was fine and the atmosphere comfortable though a bit dull.
author: Otto F.

description: We ate here the other night and my Filet was cooked Medium rare  to perfection.  It came out so buttery, haha.  Everything seems to be cooked in butter.  Especially the appetizers.  The service was excellent also but took a little longer than I expected for our Entrees to come out.  Overall we had another great experience dining at Ruth's Chris.
author: gordon g.

description:
ever wondered why the steaks here taste so good? 

i'm sure the pound of butter melted onto the plate didn't hurt.
author: Andrew P.

description: Let me just say the food was fantastic. Unfortunately, the service was the worst service I have ever had at a fine dining establishment. I spent $100 here by myself for a meal while in town and I've had better service at McDonald's. It took a minute to seat me at a table in the bar section. Ten minutes for the server to show up. He never came up and followed up to see if I needed another beer or anything else. I shouldn't even have left a tip that's how bad it was. I don't know if service is this bad everywhere in San Francisco but I know at the Ruth's Chris around Baltimore this waiter would be fired if management saw how he treated me that night.
author: Greg J.

description:
In regards to the review by SoFi O:
A restaurant cannot be held in contempt because some of the patrons there are fat or smoke outside in front of thier kids.   And staff should be "cordial" to all customers!!  That means they are a good staff.  Who are you?!

Anyway...I ate at Ruth's last night with 2 friends, we are all around 25 and none of us were distracted by the other guests there at the time.  We had a fabulous dinner, a cute little server with a fun attitude, delicious martinis and dessert.  We sat for 2 hours, did not feel rushed and the managers both came over to make sure everything was perfect throughout our meal. 
The experience is not a cheap one, but we knew that going into it.  I will go back to this one and when in another city, I might just seek out one there too.

Btw-there is butter on almost everything.  So what?  I asked for my NY Strip with no butter and it was no big deal and still a fantastic steak.   I have some left over and unlike SoFi O, I will be eating my leftovers later.  With delight.
author: Lady D.

description: This is a great steakhouse if one is into the high fat, high cholesterol and high risk in a heart attack kind of food with the amount of butter the chef uses to cook the food--especially the red meats. I HATE BUTTER! I requested very very little butter with my steak and imagine my horror when my New York Steak came with lots of melted butter. Granted the steak tasted good--very flavorful and juicy--but my stomach was having indigestion and going crazy on me. I've been here twice already for friends' birthdays and both times I had to endured the butter. For $100.00 meal at Ruth's (food & wine), it made my stomach unhappy and my conscience feeling so guilty that I ran an hour the next day to ease my guilty conscience.
author: Allison H.

description:
The last time we went to Ruth's Chris Steakhouse was over 15 years ago and the only thing I remembered was that the place was cold and drafty.  Well that didn't change.   I wore my coat over my shoulders throughout the dinner.

I ordered the filet because of other people's high reviews and the photo on their website.  When I got it, it looked like a 7 oz sirloin steak at Outback.  It was about 1 inch thick, not the 2 inches on the website.  It was okay.  Tasted like a sirloin.  Hubby had the cowboy ribeye.  He enjoyed it.  The lyonaise potatoes were fried slices of potato and then tossed with sauteed onions.  Garlic mashed potatoes wasn't very garlicky.  Creamed spinach okay.  We shared a creme brulee.  I've had creamier ones at other restaurants.

When we got the bill the filet was $39 not $43/$45. which tells me that I got the filet from the Chef's menu (which is their pre fixe menu).  From other reviews the portions are smaller on the  pre fixe menu.   The waiter should have know that I wanted the larger filet since we ordered our appetizer, salads and sides from the regular menu.

Otherwise the service was very good.  If we decide to go back, I guess it'll be another 15+ years.  

Rather go to the HPR, the sides are included.
author: M. K.

description: We came here to celebrate my son's 18th birthday. The waitstaff was  very good all were very attentive and friendly. Three of us had the "Ruth's Classic" for $49.00 you get your choice of a salad, entree, side and dessert. I had a tasty Caesar salad, a 16 ounce Rib-eye cooked to perfection, a side of spinach and a duo dessert of berries and cream and a chocolate mouse served in a chocolate shell, the desserts were just the right size after a big filling meal. We ordered additional sides, the mushrooms are a must and the shoe string fries were just OK, someone got heavy handed on the pepper. Tip, if two or more of you order the "Ruth's Classic" the sides are large enough to share with one another so order different sides.
author: Mani R.

description:
For review #300 on Yelp, which coincidentally takes place upon my one-year mark on Yelp (March 2007), I thought I'd review "Old Faithful".
That is, Ruth's Chris Steakhouse.

Now I do not know who Ruth is, I definitely don't know who Chris is, and I am not sure what the relation between them is except that he is apparently hers, but I do know that this "chain" of steakhouses is always reliable, and there is something to be said about consistency.  

Funny, I remember the first time I walked into a Ruth's Chris.  It was the one in Seattle, and I must have been 20 years old at the time, on a date.  One bite of the steak, and I was in love - with the restaurant, not the man, but to this day, I still remember him as the guy who introduced me to Ruth's Chris.  

What Ruth's Chris serves up as meat has always been very good steak.  While at 20 years of age, I thought it was the best steak ever, I can't quite claim that now but it is always very good, and I'd much rather have that than a steak that is sometimes awesome, and sometimes lackluster.  This is the kind of place where you can always take a date, have a client meeting, or gather with friends and KNOW that you will have a good meal.  It's costly enough to be fancy (as everything here is ordered a la carte) but not pricey enough to make you hesitate.  The wine list they offer you with their huge selection of meats is excellent - - huge variety of reds, a fair share of whites, and wines from every region you could imagine.

I suspect that a significant percentage of the world's butter is consumed by this chain of restaurant, or more accurately, the patrons of this chain restaurant.  Combine the overly generous use of butter with a good quality hunk of meat, and you have yourself a good American dinner.  Ordering a la carte is totally my taste, too, as many times, what I want on a menu is accompanied by something I don't feel like eating on that particular day.  At Ruth's Chris, you pick whichever side you want, be it a baked potato with the works, or creamed spinach, mushrooms, fries, or what have you.  It's then served "family-style" and portioning is usually large enough to feed two people.

Two cocktails, then two orders of meat, one side dish, and one bottle of wine for two people will usually run you approximately $100 per person, assuming you order a $70-$80 bottle of wine.  

Every Ruth's Chris always offers a Chef's Special for the evening.
What one does NOT do at Ruth's Chris, is stray from the regular menu, in my opinion.  I've ordered the Kobe Wagyu Steak here, and also had the regular Ribeye Steak - and their regular Ribeye was just as good, if not better, than what they were calling their Wagyu.  While I don't doubt it was imported from Japan, it occurs to me that ordering Kobe should be reserved for the fancier steakhouses, such as Cut in Los Angeles, Alexander's or Delmonico's, or even Del Frisco's in Las Vegas, which served up one outstanding Kobe Steak.  At Ruth's Chris, I'd suggest you stick with their regular menu, and if you want the high-end steaks, go elsewhere.  The extra $25 you pay here to get a Kobe beef steak is not worthwhile.  Their Filet Mignon, Ribeye with Bone-in, Porterhouse, and even the New York Steak, which is usually my least favorite cut, is quite delicious here at Ruth's Chris, and is ALWAYS served exactly as requested, or is redone immediately, should you not like how it's cooked.

The ambience of the place is such that one might assume the dress code to be business casual or higher.  In days gone by, Ruth's Chris had a stricter dress policy, in my opinion, but with the emergence of the higher end steakhouses, they seem to have relaxed considerably on this.  You can pretty much come here as dressed up or down as you like, though I'd definitely recommend wearing long pants and any shirt with a collar of some sort.

In my mind, on some nights, there simply is nothing like a juicy steak with a great glass of wine -  and for this purpose, Ruth's Chris always fits the bill.  If you have not been here, definitely try it out.  For this particular San Francisco location, note that there is valet parking in front for $10, and there is a bar at which you can wait for your table.  I'd highly recommend reservations as this place is usually packed, second only to House of Prime Rib up the street where your wait will be even longer.  It's good food, good ambience, and with the right company, always a memorably good time.
author: Grace K.

description: First time eating at Ruth's last night. I had the petite Filet with Shrimp and a side of fries. The entire experience was mouth watering deliciousness. I wasn't very hungry because I had eaten a few hours before, however my stomach completely forgot about that as soon as our waiter informed us about the 1,000+ degree oven that would cooking our steaks. So hot in fact that it seals the outside of the meat so the juices remain in the steak sizzling from the inside.....yum!
author: Steven Z.

description: havent been back lately but for all the times in the past i've been there since 2004 its always been nice. ribeye steaks (not the cowboy ribeye) are good with less butter (requested) and sides have always been great. good atmosphere and service. bar selection is good, wine selection is great esp. if you order their off menu wine from the cellar.
author: Jw T.

description: Exquisite. Best Ruth's I've ever been to. The finest wine I've ever tasted was a Napa valley recommendation, here. This is how a RC should be!
author: Raster M.

description: Came here a long, long time ago and remembered it as a great meal. Came back here a while later and it reassured me to write this review. The steak is definitely some of the highest quality, most juicy, tender I've ever had. The sides are just okay, and the desserts good. The service is good too, but we caught them on a busy night. Besides from the steak, nothing else compares to Joe DiMaggio's, but I guess it is a STEAKhouse, and that's what matters most right?
author: Elaine H.

description: How can you not love beef served on a plate of sizzling butter?  The hubby and I did the Dine About Town gig, but he opted to upgrade to the Ribeye.  I should have done so, too, because his food was so amazing.  For desert, we had carrot cake and choco mousse.  I have a major sweet tooth, but both were just a tad too sweet for me.  However, for $34.95, it's a great deal at Ruth's Chris!
author: Linh L.

description: Went here for my first dine about town experience to celebrate an anniversary. The steak well lets just my steak was exceptional. Great service and great food. Since I eat like a bird and always finish only a third of my entrees, I had a lot of steak and po-ta-toes to take home. Gave the leftover steak to pops and said wow that was bomb ass steak, my response would be " it better be cause that shit is like 60 dollars." My father was um speechless.
author: bella h.

description: I love Ruth's Chris, but this location needs to be seriously updated, thats the only reason it gets 4 instead of 5 stars. It's a high end restaurant and this location does not feel high end to me, at least not like the other Ruth's Chris'.  Great food, great service, still a great place to eat.
author: Benjamin K.

description:
I've been here twice and I was impressed both times. Maybe its because I'm a fatass... or maybe its because I'm a sucker for anything with butter in it (Paula Dean is my culinary hero), but the butter basted steak was excellent. The sides were just as delicious, and the appetizers were great ways to start off the dinner. 

Going down the list of things I had... 

- The gumbo was well seasoned, and had the right amount of spice to make it tangy but not leave my tongue burned for dinner. 
- The seared tuna was fresh, still rare in the middle and melted in my mouth like butter. It was a very light appetizer but the seasoning was just ok. 
- The potatoes au-gratin was flavorful and chunky... a great accent to a steak dinner if you ask me. 
- The creamed spinach is possibly the most surprising dish, as I am certainly not a spinach lover by any means of the imagination. This one was flavorful and smooth. It makes my mouth water just thinking about it. 
- The ribeye was GREAT. I got this with extra butter... just to give my heart something to work with. DELICIOUS!!!! 
- If the ribeye was GREAT, then the cowboy ribeye is in a category of its own. I can't describe how butter and a big cut of meat fits, but if there was a marriage of epic proportions, this would fit the bill.  A must have for any fatass looking for some artery clogging goodness.

To sum it all up... a must visit.
author: Ray P.

description: In my previous life, when I was young and thin and had a lot more hair, I ate here monthly, and never would have considered rating it anything less than five stars. But in my present incarnation, with cholesterol concerns and fat gram counts playing leading roles in this play I call my life, I can rarely splurge on a plate of melted butter topped by a slab of beef, not to mention the bowl of creamed spinach on the side. Why must something that tastes this good be so bad?
author: Gourmet G.

description:
ok, mobettabutta, a salamander, good stiff drinks......

why the low rating? well, what doesnt taste good in a pound of butter? you gotta bring your a game to impress me. i like that this is one of the few places that bothers searing your steaks. not exactly the way i want it, but at least an attempt. 

the salamander is badass. i want one for my kitchen. 

i should really be giving it 4 four stars, but being so overpriced, the a la carte thing is cool but yo, take it easy on the gouging. minus .5 stars. another minus .5 for the heart attacks i suffer walking to my car.
author: Euge L.

description: Corkage: $15 per bottle.  If you drink all the wine you brought and by a glass of wine, the corkage is waived.  Alright!
author: Brittney B.

description:
scallops were good, crabcake was great, mushrooms was great

now on to the steak, I have to say it was one big ass steak. Quite delicious...i do regret not ordering the Kobe though, but there is always next time lol,

the sides being potatoes, creamed spinach, aspargus all pretty good. I mean my calorie intake probably shot up the roof but hey, coming here every once in a while wont kill ya~ 

o yea dessert was quite tasty, and the cappuchino comes with a sugar stick which is pretty neat i have to say~
author: phillip w.

description:
If I were to rate this place on the company I had, it be a FIVE STAR COMEDY!  Damn - Yelpers are funny! 
Not really a good combo, laughing til your sides hurt, when you're trying to shovel down a humogous Tbone steak.  
As the others noted, service was great - we were not at our best dining behavior, but neither were the rest of the patrons. Our waitress and assistant-waiter were cool working the loud crowd and meeting our needs.  
But coupled with the quality of food and the price - I wouldn't really give more than 3.5 stars.  My T-Bone while texture-wise, was broiled nicely medium-rare, it wasn't as flavorful as I would've liked - USDA Prime still needs a generous sprinkle of salt and pepper, folks. And I wish they didn't nickel & dime you for the sides - I don't need a $10 side of potato au gratin nearly as big as my steak, but a $2 portion might've been nice. I did start with their Seafood Gumbo, cuz of a damn talk thread that day; boo - not as good as my stepdad's.
I personally think Harris' or Brazenhead have just as good steaks, for considerably less cha-ching. Exhaust all other options before dining here, and then eat your money's worth of their BUTTAH (yeah, that's right BUTTAH).
author: CINDY K.

description:
Ruth Chris has one of the best Ribeye's I have ever had in my life.  In particular, the Cowboy Ribeye (priced at $47) was the most tender and flavorful Ribeye I had ever enjoyed.

The overall establishment itself is relatively upscale.  The atmosphere is clean, sophisticated, and inviting.  The attention and service was good, as was expected from a pricey establishment. 

We went on New Years Eve 12/31/08 when there was a special of a $39.95 entree which consisted of stuffed Lobster Tail and a smaller cut of Filet Mignon.  The Lobster Tail was a complete let down.  There was no freshness or sweet taste from the lobster meat.  

A tip to people that want to enjoy delicious Lobster Tail, I would recommend going to Costco directly and buy their frozen lobster tails, frozen fresh/wild caught Honduras Lobster Tails - now those have flavor!  The filet mignon was good, nothing special to note.

I took off 2 stars because I was very disappointed that our waitress pushed the sides as if we were supposed to order them.  Now I'm not sure if you are required to order them, but after ordering the Cowboy Ribeye with a cost of $47 for the entree itself, which was large and satiated my appetite, I did not appreciate the hard sell of over priced sides.  

In this case we felt inclined to order mashed potatoes and mushrooms.  None of them were worth the hefty price tag for sides (they say you are supposed to order them to share family style with your entree).  

Overall, the Cowboy Ribeye was by far the best Ribeye I had ever laid my hands on, but the expensive sides proved too much of a rip off in my eyes.
author: Edmund Y.

description:
***DAT 2007 Review***

Another stop on the tour. Though getting there was a beeyatch. There are enough reviews, so I'll focus on my wonderful adventure. Took a crazy cab ride from my hood from a guy who just did not want to be driving that night. It's basically a $5 cab ride. Except the guy claimed to not know where it was and I didn't bring the address with me. I say it's around Van Ness and California, which was a good guess. Cabbie mumbles something which actually sounds like an address and shoots off. I'm looking for the address on my phone, so I'm not paying too much attention to his driving. Until I start sliding from side to side as this guy swerves around cars. These aren't cars stopped on the side, he's driving like a maniac flying in between other cabs. Isn't there a cabbie code where they don't cut each off? Or more like guidelines... Anyway, after a little while looking down at my phone, I have a splitting headache. It's my version of being car sick. I tell him what the address is, and he says he knows. Uh, a minute ago he said he didn't know. And somehow he magically conjures the address? WTF? So obviously that doesn't please him and he speeds up. Going down the hill on California to VN, he basically bottoms at several intersections. Finally pulls up to the corner. And he becomes all nice. Ya, here's a tip for you crackhead....

So on to RCSH. Though my head was still aching, not letting that get in the way of stuffing of my face. The DAT menu is the same as last year. Not because I was there, but because it still said 5th Annual. First course was the salad, nothing special. Though I do recommend the remoulade dressing. Second was a 12 oz ribeye, 6 oz filet or some chicken thing. Obviously not getting chicken. They were out of the ribeye, but the waitress said we could substitute a 12 oz buffalo ribeye. Compadre ordered the filet. Typical meaty goodness. I had the buffalo with the blue cheese crust. Not bad, but not a ribeye either. Also comes with a choice of mashed potatoes or creamed spinach. Dessert was key lime pie or bread pudding. The key lime pie was nice and tart. The bread pudding was good, though barely lukewarm. 

This location is on par or slightly lower than others I've been to. Our waitress was wonderful and gave us really good service. I'm bad at remembering names, but she was good. 

But, while we were waiting for our table, the hostesses and some staff were chatting. Which is fine, but they were talking about going out and this and that. Not in soft voices either. Then as staff changed the table and wiped the glasses and silverware of finger prints, which is a nice touch, again they would be chatting. That's just annoying when it's the adjacent table. I really don't care to hear about your plans for later and why you're trying to convince someone to hang out with you and your friends.
author: The Sock S.

description: I honestly don't understand the allure of an expensive steakhouse in a city so brimming with sophisticated, innovative, flavorful food. They cook everything in butter, then salt and pepper it. That's the extent of their taste palette. You might as well be at a strip mall in Ohio. The kicker for me was the broccoli, which was a bunch of broccoli, steamed on a plate. I thought "Wow, you're not going to do ANYTHING to it?" It doesn't get more bland than this. The world gives America curried lamb, sushi and risotto...we send them McDonald's and Pizza Hut.
author: Kirk R.

description: The first time I went to Ruth's I would've given it a 5 but the second time around was a 3.  So 4 star it is.  I had the petite filet and got suckered in to getting the blue cheese topping by the waitress.  I realized that I no longer like filet mignon and not a fan of the cheese topping.  I tried my friend's rib eye and that was freakin delicious .  So get the buttery rib eye people!!
author: Lisa P.

description:
This place has the best steak in SF (+1 *), delicious sides (+1 *), great service (+1 *), nice ambiance (+1 *), some "meal deals" (+1 *).  Came here for a birthday date night and was not disappointed (even though they somehow lost my reservation that was made a week prior and checked on later).  They still managed to give me the booth I requested and had us seated and peaceful before I had time to get too worked up and complain.

Maybe I'd take off a star for how g** d*** expensive it was, but really, you don't go to Ruth's Chris every night.  I felt like we got our $'s worth.  The "meal deal" stated was a tasty, simple bowl of seafood gumbo, a 6oz petit filet mignon with 5-6 delicious seasoned shrimp on top, side of mashed potatoes and a sweet dessert medley $39.99.  The birthday boy got a petit filet and 8oz seasoned lobster tail (side of bubbling butter and lemon in cheese cloth for extra flavor and dipping) with a creamed spinach side- this was NOT on the meal deal list - about $75.  Add a couple glasses of pinot noir and we had the perfect meal, service, setting, etc.  I took my dessert to go and he was offered a free dessert of choice off the menu for a bday treat, got the cheesecake to go as well.  We had an amazing doggie bag with some left over sides, a chunk of steak, a shrimp, piece of lobster and 2 full desserts...Heaven still the next day.
author: Sarah B.

description: Okay.  Steaks are normally delicious and tender but thought no care was taken during dine about town. medium rare should not be mistaken for medium well! Despite that, they should still take care of the meat itself. We ordered plenty of wine and sides but still no love. Other than the mediocre steak quality service was pretty good - staff was super friendly and nice.
author: Clay L.

description: I ate here last night for Dine about Town and I will not bother posting the menu but I thought it was great for the money which was $34.95 plus I paid an extra $3 to add Blue Cheese Crust to my Petite steak which was worth it.  Mashed potatoes and creamed spinach were OK (better at Izzy's) and the dessert was so-so.  Carrot cake (too rich), chocolate mouse..good.  The steak was great though and the service was very good as well.  Definetly recommend for DAT.
author: Mark M.

description:
I like Ruth Cris. The bar is more kick back than other steak houses, and the food is very good in general. The servers are usually a bit young, and most don't seem to be professional waiters like the old school places Harris and Alfred's. 

Of the dozen times I've been there, two or three, it has actually been pretty bad. In particular, the seafood can be weak. Once I was served the end cut of a filet which is ridiculous. The bartenders are awesome guys, and I enjoy eating at the bar.
author: Andrew Z.

description: Hadn't been to the RC in about a year, but stopped by twice in the past couple of months, and it remains top-notch.  The staff is exceptional and always treats me like a VIP.  Jose and Arturo rock, and always lead me to great wine finds.  Steak is always 5 star, and sides are great.  All in all, and I know it is a chain, but I truly rank this as the best steak in SF, and I've been to them all.
author: Lena D.

description: My wife and some friends went there for some steaks, and honestly I expected better.  For the prices, I expect near perfection, and there was nothing particularly grand about my meal.  Granted, the vegetables and potatoes were very good, but the meat was average.  I hear so many good things about the place, but for the prices they won't be getting a second chance.  The Prime Spot in Oakland had MUCH better food all around, as well as parking.
author: Jesse G.

description: Went here nearly a decade ago with my old dotcom crew and went back a few weeks ago during Dine About Town.  The girl had the ribeye and I had the filet mignon.  Ruth's Chris is good but they love cooking in butter.  A lot of butter.  The presentation, I must say, was disappointing and the plate was super hot.  This is something Forbes Mill, Harris Ranch, and Alexander's wisely do not do.  It was super crowded and just disconcerting.  The meat was good and tender, but it wasn't aged enough for my tastes.  I guess in SF, this is the best steak you're going to get, but I'll take Alexander's over this any day.
author: Dave K.

description:
The first really great steak I had in a restaurant was at Ruth's Chris around six or seven years ago. Since then I've eaten at many more restaurants and come to realize that their steaks are only pretty good.

The first thing to note is that their steaks are "wet-aged' versus dry-aged. Wet aged is cheaper b/c the cuts of meat are sealed in a plastic bag, and let to age in their own blood and juices. This also prevents any loss of edible meat. In dry-aging, the meat is hung in rooms at certain temperatures and humidity. After a month or so of aging, the outer layer(s) of the meat are cut off. People say the flavor is greater in dry-aged than the mushy wet-aged meat.

Second, they use a crap load of butter to top off and during the grilling of your meat. There are few things that won't taste really good if you use that much butter. You could take an Outback ribeye, and tell them to use one stick of butter in the process of the cooking and you would probably get similar results.

To be fair, the steak was grilled as ordered (but hey, it SHOULD be at any restaurant) and the meat does come out with a nice seared exterior and juicy interior (if ordered medium-rare, rare, or black&blue). 

So why only the three stars? I think there are better steakhouses out there with better cuts of meat and slightly lower prices. Alexander's in Cupertino might not be cheaper, but they do have dry-aged beef, and their non-steak dishes are more varied.
author: Cary W.

description: Let's see...Love the Filet Mignon although if you're a slow eater like I am, it tends to get a little too salty as I get to the last few pieces since it soaks up all the oils and fat on the bottom of the plate. Love the potatoes and mushrooms. Love the creme brulee! Love the cocktails!
author: Tracy Y.

description: 2 things that makes this place good: the filet mignon and the mushrooms. These are the must-haves whenever I, or anyone, comes here.  I guess this place would deserve another star if they didn't make me wait 15-30 mins. past my reservation time EVERY TIME. The fact that our waitress neglected us for half the night didn't help either. But the food is yummy.
author: Julie L.

description: i lost a bet over a 49'er game last year (hey, i knew the odds but i'm a loyal fan anyway) and had to bring someone here for dinner. being a lover of filet mignon i was pleased with this place in general, but still prefer harris' and Bobos WAY more over Ruth Chris. Environment to me is also a bit more formal/colder than the other places. all in all a decent steakhouse, just nothing really amazing about it. above all though, just don't go to mortons, i can't Yelp that enough.
author: Michelle I.

description: My first time there and it was an excellent experience. The ambiance is great, fancy... very pricey but worth it!. I had the cowboy steak and oh boy it just melts in my mouth. It might be due to all the butter, but who cares! Average price of a steak is about $50 or so.
author: Nhung T.

description:
sooo i came to ruth's chris last night with my family. my dad had been raving about this restaurant for quite awhile. anyhow, since i didnt know much about the restaurant, i didn't really have any expectations.

first off, i always really care about how well a host/hostess treats you. i think it's because i am a hostess at a restaurant myself and it sucks to see how some hostesses act given the job that they are in. anyhow, our hostess wasn't all that nice. she didnt smile once and seemed annoyed when she was seating us.

next thing, it was loud as hell in this restaurant. not normal loud. annoying loud. i could barely have a conversation with the people at my table. i know this is not the restaurant's fault for having loud people. however, it is their fault for fitting about 40 people into a dining room the size of my bedroom. so -1 star for that.

however, our waiter was very nice and stayed at our table for the time that it took us to order, which felt like forever when its with my family. going on with the food (worth mentioning):

ruth's chopped salad- wow, amazing salad.. i dont think ive ever had a salad this great. this was actually my dad's order and i felt bad because i ended up eating almost the whole thing.

calamari- the calamari itself was very good. but the sauce on it.. not so good. since when was calamari supposed to be so sweet? 

petite filet & prawns- this is the dish that i ordered. so, the prawns were yummy on this plate. the filet was good, but not praise-worthy considering the price ($50 something plate). ive had a better filet mignon for 40-45 dollars. 

oh and next thing.. WHY do you have to pay $8.50 per side? basically, the main entrees here come w ith nothing but your steak, and u pay another $8.50 per side that you order. now i usually wouldnt complain about paying $8.50 per side, but their sides are not good.

chocolate duo & creme brulee- very good. the chocolate duo was pretty much a brownie desert you can get at any restaurant. however, the creme brulee was made very well. very soft, creamy, and smooth.

overall, service was good and the wine the server suggested was good too. and even though the food was good, it's still overpriced.  for the four of us in my family, our bill came out to about $375, and i thought it should have been between $200-275 at most. 

plus for valet parking considering it is in the city, even though it is 10 bucks. 

however, i do want to try other locations (vegas and southern california), because i hear that those locations are up to par.
author: Tiffany K.

description: Went with a group of friends and had an enjoyable meal.  3 rib eyes which were cooked to perfection and barely needed a knife to cut them.  One steak and lobster, and one cowboy rib eye which were both good.  The sides of hash browns and mashed potatoes were huge portions.  The mashed potatoes weren't anything special, the hash browns were tasty.  The dinner ended with chocolate mousse and a carrot cake.  The chocolate mouse was amazing, didn't really like the carrot cake.  Overall the food was good.  The service could have been better for a yelp $$$$ rating - my water glass was empty several times, incorrect sides were initially brought out.  I would recommend this for a nice meal, not a romantic night out.  I prefer Bobo's and House of Prime Rib, however would return.
author: David D.

description: The best Cowboy Ribeye ever!  Must be the butter it's fried in.
author: Porkchop S.

description:
I had the shrimp dishes, it was just okay, wasn't great, wasn't anything there that makes me want to go back.
another american fine dining restaurant i'll never go to again, unless forced by celebrations with friends/family.
we had some kind of spinach dish..i forgot what it was called..it's blended..cream of spinach maybe. didn't like at all..we sent it back..gross.
service was okay. the setting of the restaurant is actually quite odd.
ambiance...eh.

didnt impress me. if i ever do go back, i'll be trying something new. at least they have more variety than harris resturant. im thankful for that.
author: Janet W.

description: The food here was great. I loved the appetizers, entree, and dessert. The service was professional and prompt, and we got to sit by the window facing the street. The atmosphere was fun and fancy. Everything was great, and since it was my birthday, I got a great dessert :)
author: Sara W.

description:
I've been waiting to come back to this place for three years.  I visited the Kailua-Kona Ruth's Chris in 2007 and I must say I'm disappointed of the rating for the SF chain. I do believe they deserve a better average rating. For those who truly had an awful time I feel bad for you guys. I honestly believe a person is not just paying for food or drink, but for the grandeur of it all.  People pay lots of money to eat here and to celebrate here and to enjoy fine dining here and if you have a problem, they really do try to accommodate to your needs because they understand that without your good word of mouth they lose business, reputation, and, of course, money .  If you really don't like what you're eating, speak up to the staff and they'll get you WHAT YOU WANT! It's great!

This restaurants serves extremely well corn-fed beef, fresh fish and seafood, and a variety of things for different palates. But this steak house definitely knows their beef! They know how to correctly sear meat to keep the juices in and to correctly cook meat to the desired temperature. If anyone has ever attempted to make beef as juicy and tender as them its me! I've tried many a-times but its that 1800 degree oven that I lack. I've never had steak made to my liking as well as they do it. In fact, because of all the extra butter I put on my Petite Filet, the roasted tomato that came with my dinner, cut the heaviness of the meat and made a taste sensation that was food-gasmic!! The acidity of the tomato was so perfect with each bite of the steak, that every time I put it in my mouth my tongue salivated just a tad bit more to have all those flavors coat everywhere inside my mouth . Truly amazing in flavor contrasts! I felt the same way every time I took a bite of their sauteed mushrooms. Each time I chewed the mushroom it would release a wonderful aromatic mushroom juice. OH IT WAS SOOO DELICCIIIIIIOOOOOOOOOUUUS!!! Now, my husband, Jon, disagrees with my rating because he feels the other dishes like seafood and chicken were average. But I'm not going to a steak house for other things I'm going there for their steak.  So my rating still stands. As for sides, the unhealthier the better. As for desserts, creme brule is my top choice with the custard slightly warmed (Jon doesn't like it this way but ate most of it), extra sugar coating and extra berries. 

The service is impeccable. The general manager runs a tight ship there. They understand the importance of notice to small detail and aid in making memorable dining experiences for their customers.

I recommend reservations a day in advance at least for the weekends and a price consideration of $80-$120 per person on an average night not including their summer promotion of $89 per two people.
author: Bern R.

description:
by no means terrible on its own, but when compared to other steakhouses, i personally found it severely mediocre.

i'd go to morton's (then harris'...) before this.  and i wouldn't come back here again, because i have no reason to.
author: Erika C.

description:
Not again.  I no longer eat grain-fed, about to die, beef.  So, I really shouldn't eat here.  I had the chicken which could be used for a desiccant.  Perhaps the French fries suffered from a conversion to healthier fat, but they were so greasy that they remained uneaten.  I'm glad the waitress forgot the order initially so they were comped.
Desserts tasted sweet, but had no other flavor.

With a bottle of Zin - DAT - still over $150...for two.

The people were nice, the dining room is pleasant, so not one star.
author: T T.

description:
Went to SF with girlfriends for a shopping, and eating splurge. SF was having a Taste of the Town, where participating places had pre-fix Menus. Sadly they didn't make reservations but accepted walk ins, so at 500pm, as soon as they opened, we were there to put down our names.
We were promptly seated. The place has an old boys club feel to it, and the lighting is dark. The Prefix menu had 12 oz ribeye, and that was what all of us ordered, we had it topped with a blue cheese breaded topper (to me it was too salty, with not much blue cheese, I'd skip this for the additional 3.00). My friend ordered the potatoes/cheese gratin as an additional side dish, I'd skip this as well since the meal was more then enough with the side dishes that were included. Their drinks were great, I ordered the Lucille Merlot, and my friend has an Orange Mojito which was refreshing and very non-alcoholic in taste. The side dish or potatoes and spinach were both good and buttery. The steaks were heavenly and they were marbled nicely. Dessert was a choice of either Lemon Pie, or Bread pudding, both were lightly sweetened, and very good, sadly I only had room for one bite. Our waiter Josh was very nice and came back to refill our glasses and drinks. The establishment was very friendly and gave us wonderful service.
author: Tulie L.

description: this place is worth every dime!!! food is all top of the line great food and service. if you know your quality in steak you'll love this place may i add they have a full bar!!!
author: HAppYippyayhay H.

description:
We went to Ruth's Chris Steak House after a college graduation in Oakland (graduation ran very late) and we missed our reservation at another place in San Francisco. So as we were driving over the Bay Bridge, we started to look on yelp.com to find somewhere to go for a great dinner. We called Ruth's Chris and they gladly took our name. When we arrived the place was not very full but it was almost 10:30pm. Our waiter Josh was great and very helpful because our party never been there before. Josh explained how the steaks are cooked and what kind of beef they use. We took his recommendations and never looked backed. 

Most of the party had the petit filet mignon course and everyone was delighted. I tried something else--I had the fresh fish course which was wild Alaska salmon. It was outstanding. As for the sides we had the roasted garlic green beans, roasted garlic mashed potatoes, and sautéed mushrooms. I have nothing negative to say about this place, the food or our waiter.

We will be back!
author: Loree K.

description:
Along with Scoma's lunch, this place is the best value for your buck when you order from the DAT menu.  Luckily, we were able to get some great reservations at the last minute and squeak in under the wire to take advantage of the menu.

The decor is not much to talk about - basically, dark wood, dim lighting, private booths, and wine cabinets- the place just screams masculinity and steakhouse.  We were seated at a booth next to the waiters' station, which made for some interesting eavesdropping during the dinner.  

We started off with the house salad, which unfortunately came a little too dressed.  There was a heaping glop of the vinagrette in the mixed green salad, which overwhelmed the delicate greens.  However, it did come with the best croutons I've ever had - they were probably deep-fried in beef fat and butter.  

I got the 12 ounce petite rib-eye, medium rare, with the side of creamed spinach.  The ribeye came screamingly hot in a plate of melted butter, but the creamed spinach was closer to room temperature...not that it stopped me from devouring all of it.  My rib-eye was a little too fatty for my taste - I left about a 2 ounce portion of fat and tendon on the plate.  Though the steak was perfectly done when it first arrived at the table, it started heading towards medium by the time you were done, from the heat of the plate.  That made the steak a little tough, but overall, still one of the best steaks I've ever had.  Some of my tablemates ordered their steak with the bleu cheese topping - it was delicious and the mildest bleu cheese we've ever had.  My dad got his steak Oscar style, which meant a crab cake, 3 spears of asparagus, and bernaise sauce on top of the steak.  Delicious, but I'm not sure if it was worth the extra $14.
